Agatha rolled her eyes and began absentmindedly messing with the seam on the cushion again. They were both being ridiculous and were way off base. Rio was no longer the type of woman that she was attracted to, she liked more mature women – not necessarily older women, but women who conducted themselves in a more grown-up way. Rio didn’t take things seriously enough, everything was either a joke or some sort of game to her and that was something that Agatha did not enjoy in the slightest.
If she was forced to, at gunpoint, then she could maybe admit that Rio was attractive. Only in the conventional sense, it didn’t mean that Agatha found her attractive. They were two very different things. She wasn’t in denial about anything, they were just simply wrong.

The seam on the cushion had fully come undone now and she was gently rolling some of the stuffing into a ball in her palm. The texture of it was somehow soft and wiry at the same time, the kind of fibres that felt like they should make a creaking sound when rubbed together, but she couldn’t hear anything.

Agatha sighed. “I’m not denying anything, you’re just incorrect.” She didn’t look up, but she heard Jen’s gasp and could feel Lilia’s eyes going wide as she took in the words.
“The fact that you couldn’t look at me while you said that implies that you know how wrong that statement is.” Lilia said. “But it’s clear that we’re not gonna get any further tonight so I shan’t rise to it.”
Agatha finally looked up and regarded Lilia with a cautious look. “Great, so does that mean that this topic is dropped and we never have to speak of it again?”
Lilia pursed her lips as she considered the question. “Sure. For now. But you’re going to have to confront this at some point, Agatha. It isn’t healthy to continue on like this.” She raised an eyebrow and pointed at the cushion that Agatha had basically destroyed. “I want that mending as well.”
Agatha rolled her eyes and put the cushion back in its spot on the settee. “I’ll buy you a new one.”
“I don’t want a new one. I want you to fix that one.”
Agatha made a noise of malcontent and said, “fine,” through gritted teeth.

She sat up properly and turned to Jen, giving her an apologetic look. “I’m sorry for what I said and how I said it earlier.”
Jen smiled. “You don’t need to apologise. I’m not saying that I like being your target, but it’s better that it’s me rather than some poor, unsuspecting shop worker or student.”
Agatha dipped her head slightly in embarrassment before coming back up to meet Jen’s eyes. “I appreciate that, but I’m doing it anyway.”
“I accept.” 

__________

When Agatha got home around an hour later, her mind was swimming. Of course that could partially be due to the wine – she really should stop driving to these Saturday night get-togethers. She was rooting through her drawers for a t-shirt to sleep in and was stopped in her tracks. Buried right at the bottom of a pile, pushed so far into the back corner was an old, crumpled, white shirt. The design was so faded that it was barely visible but she recognised it instantly. She pulled it out and laid it on her bed, staring at it.

It was an Oasis shirt from a decades old tour, insignificant in the fact that it was one of many old pieces of band merch that she had collected over the years, wholly significant in the fact that it wasn’t hers. She had never been a fan of Oasis, if one of their songs came on while she just had a playlist going in the background as she was doing something then she wouldn’t turn it off, but she didn’t actively seek them out. Wanda, however, was a very big fan of their music. The shirt was hers. A relic both in age and meaning.

The first time that she had slept at Wanda’s house she had spilled something on the shirt that she had brought to sleep in and Wanda had given her the Oasis one as a replacement. She had taken it home with her after that weekend and kept it the whole time they were together. Wanda often teased her about wanting it back because she wanted to sell it, but she never made any attempt to actually get it back, letting Agatha continue to use the shirt as a pyjama top.

Agatha sat on the edge of her bed next to the shirt. Looking at it now nearly two years after their break -up, she didn’t know how to feel. There was nostalgia attached to it, memories of a better time when she was happy. Memories of living with Wanda and Billy and being the family unit that she never got to experience growing up. Memories of when Wanda made her feel like the most special person in the world. But those memories were tinged with sadness and anger and hatred.
They were blurred by the image of Agatha walking into the bedroom, her bedroom, to see Wanda and Vision tangled in the sheets. The edges of the polaroids that she had turned those memories into were charred from when she had tried to erase them, tried to forget about those four years and put them behind her.

When she had hurriedly packed her suitcase that one afternoon she must have accidentally grabbed the shirt along with her other clothes. It was entirely possible that, since she’d had it for so long and worn it so often, she had forgotten that it wasn’t actually hers and had picked it up out of habit. Either way it had been a mistake and the shirt had ended up being accidentally shoved into the back of her drawer and hidden away.
Until now when the universe decided that it wanted to fuck with her.

She ran her fingers over the fabric and gently traced the faded logo that was printed on it.
“Why now?” She asked to her empty bedroom. There was no answer of course, she would have questioned her sanity if she had heard one. Still, that didn’t stop her from wanting one, needing one.
Every part of Wanda had been erased from her life, save for the ones that she couldn’t actually shift like their jobs and Billy. Now this.
She should throw it away, burn it, just get fucking rid of it. But she stayed sitting next to it just staring at it, completely at a loss for what to do. She could give it to Billy, he had a collection of ‘vintage’ band shirts, or at least he used to – the fact that Oasis were nowhere near old enough to be considered vintage aside – it could be a two-birds-one-stone situation. She’d be able to get rid of the shirt and when Wanda saw him with it, it would fuck with her.

Agatha let herself indulge in the moment of schadenfreude that the thought provided. Knowing that Wanda would recognise the shirt instantly and would also have to hear Billy tell her that he got it from Agatha made her smile darkly.
But she couldn't do it. She couldn't use Billy like that, that was something Wanda would do and she would not, under any circumstances, act the way that Wanda acted. Even if giving Billy the shirt was purely because she knew that he would like it, there would still be some part of it that was about getting to Wanda. She wasn't going to do that to him.

She folded the shirt up and put it on top of her dresser to decide what to do with it at a later date, and pulled a different shirt from her drawer to sleep in. She crawled into bed and pulled her quilt up so that it rested under her chin and let out a long, heavy sigh. Agatha wasn’t a spiritual person, she didn’t believe in fate or destiny but she couldn’t help feeling like finding that shirt now carried some meaning. Finding something that belonged to her ex-fiancée the same night that her friends had unceremoniously shoved her into the realisation that she might like someone else couldn’t just be a coincidence could it?

As she laid there with her eyes open, knowing that sleep wasn’t going to come any time soon, she couldn’t stop her thoughts from wandering through the twisted path that was Rio Vidal.
She couldn’t recall all of their interactions in perfect order but there were ones that stood out more than others.

There was their first official meeting, the one that Rio had shown up to ten minutes late sporting an obvious hangover. Agatha had admired Rio’s confidence in still coming in to face her, despite the potential embarrassment and possible chastisement, but of course Agatha had let her off with a warning. A courtesy rarely awarded to anyone, but that was only because of the way that she had acted previously, it wouldn't have been fair to reprimand Rio. Then again, she never usually cared about what was ‘fair’. If a student acted out of line, they acted out of line and were treated accordingly.
But she was allowed to offer politeness to people when she thought they needed it. Rio was deeply apologetic and clearly embarrassed by the situation so reprimanding her wouldn’t have served any purpose.

There was the day that Rio had decided to start bringing Agatha a coffee for their meetings. No other student had done this, it was probable that no other student had had the confidence to do this, but Rio had. Rio had taken the time to actually find out what her order was and bring it to her. Of course she’d had to play a joke first by offering her that horrid iced coffee before swapping the cups and looking entirely too happy with the reaction that Agatha had given her, but she had still gone out of her way to find out what Agatha ordered and made it part of her routine going forwards.

The time that they’d had an argument about Agatha not wanting to tell Rio the age she was when she first read The Odyssey flashed through Agatha’s brain. Rio had so casually thrown Wanda out as a threat as if she had known that it would make Agatha back down, and it had.
Lilia had helped her realise that she had overreacted and she had to admit that she regretted it. She shouldn’t have flown off the handle the way that she did, it didn’t achieve anything, it only made Rio double down and made the whole situation worse than it needed to be.

But none of this equated to liking her. Using the word like in that context made Agatha’s skin itch. It was immature, juvenile. She was forty two for christ sake, she didn’t like people, it was a very high school way of phrasing things. Even when she was in high school she hadn’t used that phrase, she hadn’t cared enough about the girls that she slept with to get to a point of liking them. She only needed them to be around long enough to piss off her mother and step father.
An argument could be made in favour of her liking Wanda, but Agatha preferred saying things like, ‘I find her attractive’, or, ‘I’m drawn to her personality’. It was more mature and more articulate. It was just better.

The memory of her dream about Rio came careening into her skull and it made her cringe. She thanked every deity imaginable that she hadn’t brought it up earlier that evening, Lilia would never have let her hear the end of it.
She maintained that it didn’t mean anything, that dreams weren’t a representation of your wants or desires. It could have been anybody in that dream, the fact that it was Rio was completely irrelevant; she just happened to be the face that Agatha’s subconscious had randomly picked.

Agatha was officially done with this spiral that she had sent herself on, so she rolled onto her side and tried to go to sleep. She shut her eyes and focussed only on the dark expanse that the back of her eyelids created. She tried to quiet her brain by using an old technique of reciting the phonetic alphabet in time with her breathing, but by the time she had gone through it for the third time, she decided to give it up as a bad job. Her mind wasn’t going to let her sleep.
Why did Lilia have to choose now to remind her how good she was at her job?

__________ 

Agatha woke up the following morning very aware of the fact that she hadn't had enough sleep at all. She wanted so badly to go back to sleep and get the rest that she needed. It was a Sunday after all and she had nothing to do, but she forced herself to keep her eyes open and roll out of bed. She drowsily brushed her teeth, noticing the dark circles under her eyes straight away, and did her morning skincare routine. She wasn’t convinced that it even did anything but it was more out of habit than actually expecting results at this point.

She changed into her usual Sunday attire – her old Yale hoodie and a pair of navy sweatpants – and padded downstairs to get some breakfast. Treating herself to a truly lazy Sunday she opted for just a bowl of cereal and glass of orange juice, too tired to even bother making a cup of coffee, and curled up on the sofa. She was part way through a Gossip Girl rewatch, a guilty pleasure that she actually felt no guilt towards in the slightest, so she picked up where she left off as she munched on her cereal.

When she had finished her bowl she retrieved her sewing kit from the spare room and picked up Lilia’s cushion that she had all but destroyed the previous night. She considered taking the easy option and just doing a running stitch along the seam, but it wouldn't match the other seams and she could already feel Lilia’s disappointment at her even thinking about phoning it in. She would have to suck it up and do a ladder stitch. It wasn’t that she couldn’t do a ladder stitch, it was that they were annoying and she often had to restart them at least three times to get it right.

She finished the seam and admired her work. There were no loose pieces of thread hanging out, which had been the reason the cushion had come undone in the first place. If that hadn’t been there, then she wouldn’t have been messing with it and she wouldn’t have had to fix the shoddy sewing work. Technically speaking, the cushion coming undone hadn’t fully been her fault and she would only accept partial blame for it.

She attempted to zone out and only have her attention on the TV, following Chuck and Blair’s numerous antics and trying not to see Joe Goldberg instead of Dan Humphrey every time Penn Badgley was on screen. But her mind couldn’t stay still. It kept wandering off in different directions that ultimately led to the same destination. She was beginning to wonder if she’d ever be able to stop thinking about Rio.
Maybe Lilia and Jen were right…

Agatha had caught herself staring at Rio more times than she wanted to think about. She never intended on doing it, it just sort of happened. Her eyes would subconsciously drift in whichever direction Rio was from her and then they would stay there until Rio caught her, or she caught herself, and she’d have to make up some thinly veiled excuse for why her attention had been focussed on her for so long.

Using ‘I find her intriguing’ as a way to explain it away to herself could only work for so long before she had to admit what was really going on. Despite her detestation of the word, she had to use it. She liked Rio.
She’d liked Rio since she’d first seen her in the crowd of first year students that had attended her first lecture of the year, since she’d called her out on being wrong about the origin of Heracles’ name.

“Which part of you are you protecting?”
Lilia’s question repeated in her head. Which part of herself was she protecting? Her heart was the obvious answer but it was more than that. There was some part of her that was holding back, it had stopped her from realising that she had feelings for Wanda for nearly a year before Jen and Lilia had basically held an intervention for her to make her see it… She was beginning to sense a pattern.
But that apprehension had turned out to be correct. Wanda had cheated on her two times, she had said yes to marrying her, worn the ring that Agatha had bought and still slept with someone else for a third time. Who was to say that this time would be any different? 

__________

Agatha was finishing up her Monday morning lecture and Rio hadn’t attended. After their last conversation Agatha hadn’t expected her to, but part of her had stupidly still hoped that she would have.
Billy gave her a smile as he walked past her towards the door and she asked him to wait behind. When everyone had left she said, “I was wondering if you’d like to come round for dinner at some point this week.”
“Yeah, for sure. What day did you have in mind?” He replied, an excited smile making his eyes shine.
“Whichever day works for you. You can bring Alice as well if you want.”
“Oh, amazing.” He looked towards the door where she assumed Alice would be waiting on the other side. “I’ll ask her and text you later?”
Agatha ruffled his hair. “Sounds good kid.”

She waited for Billy to leave, giving herself five minutes before following him out, nipping back to her office to pick up the cushion, and walking across campus to Lilia’s office. She knocked on the door and walked in upon Lilia’s approval, holding the cushion up and waving it a little before putting it on one of the chairs.
Lilia smiled and stood up from her desk, making her way over to Agatha and picking up the cushion to inspect it. “This is a lot neater than I was expecting, Harkness. I’m impressed.”
Agatha scoffed. “I am offended that you thought my sewing skills would be anything less than excellent.”
Lilia chuckled. “Well I know your kind are known for their nimble fingers, but this is precision work. Some people just don’t have the talent.”
Agatha rolled her eyes but didn't deign to respond to her friend's silly comment.

She stayed standing in Lilia’s office, wanting to say something else but struggling to find the words. Thankfully Lilia picked up on her awkward demeanour. “Was there something else you came to me for, Agatha?”
Agatha swapped her weight from one foot to the other before steeling herself and forcing the words to come out of her mouth. “Yes actually.” She paused to clear her throat. “I realised yesterday that you might have a point… about Rio.”
Lilia laughed and sat in the chair. “Obviously.” She gestured to the chair opposite her. “Sit. I have half an hour.”
Agatha gave the chair an apprehensive look. “Thanks, but I don’t need another session. I’m not in denial anymore.”
“This isn’t a session, it’s two friends having a chat.”
Agatha rolled her eyes but sat down anyway. “Nothing is gonna come of it, so I don’t know why you’re so invested.”
Lilia lifted an eyebrow. “Why do you think nothing is going to come of it?”

Agatha thought about it for a moment. Were there any actual reasons that she could give, or was this just self sabotage?
The age gap was a glaringly obvious one. There were twelve years between them and thinking about it like that made her feel uneasy.
“Because she’s a student. She’s my student. Also, she might not be single.”
Lilia nodded her head in understanding. “Fair points, but you don’t know that she isn’t single.”
Agatha made a sound of dismissal. “Please, a woman like Rio? I would put money on the fact that all the twenty-something-year-old queer girls on this campus are falling over themselves to chase after her.”
“Careful Harkness. You’re sounding a little jealous.” Lilia said with a smirk.
Agatha rolled her eyes. “Piss off. Even if she is single, she’s still a student so I would never pursue anything with her anyway.”
“A PhD student.” Lilia corrected. “She’s not a teenager. And it’s not illegal, just…” She waved her hand through the air while she was trying to find the right phrasing. “Morally grey.”

Agatha shook her head. Morally grey was one way to put it for sure. “It’s also fucking embarrassing.” She ran her hand through her hair. “I’m forty two years old with a… crush ,” she made a face like the word left a bad taste in her mouth, “on a thirty year old who also just happens to be one of my students.” 
Lilia leaned forwards, resting her elbows on her legs and sitting her chin on her clasped hands. “It’s okay to embarrass yourself a little in the pursuit of human connection.”
She said it like it was the easiest thing in the world, like it wouldn’t get Agatha fired if Rio reported her for unwanted advances or sexual harassment.
Then again Rio hadn’t reported her for anything thus far so maybe she wouldn’t. Maybe she liked Agatha as well, maybe it wouldn’t be such a bad idea to at least try. But of course Agatha had already fucked up any chance of it happening by acting like a prize idiot in treating Rio like shit and cutting off their meetings. Even if she wanted to, she had no way of progressing with this now. She had ruined it like usual.

Agatha sighed. “That may be so, but I’m pretty sure I’ve made her hate me by now.”
Lilia gave a kind smile. “You never know unless you try.”
If only it were that easy. “And how do I do that?”
“You’ve got to figure that one out for yourself, I can’t do everything for you.”
Agatha hated it when Lilia was right, but she couldn’t fight her, she knew that she had to do this by herself.

Chapter End Notes

This slow burning fire is finally getting stoked tee hee

Chapter 15: Wanda

Chapter Notes

It's the return of everyone's favourite ginger!

See the end of the chapter for more notes

If someone had told Wanda that at forty-two she would be a divorced mother to an eighteen-year-old, who spent most of her time sleeping with someone who was twelve years younger than she was, she would have laughed in their face and told them that they needed to seek help. Yet here she was in the early hours of Monday morning, coming down from her fourth orgasm in a row, feeling the tears induced by overstimulation roll down her cheeks as she ignored texts from both her son and ex-husband in favour of the thirty-year-old that was currently between her legs.

She collapsed back against her pillows breathless and numb, the noise of her phone buzzing on her nightstand barely making its way through the post-orgasm haze that she was currently in.
“You should probably check that, it’s been going off for a few minutes now.” Rio said as she stood up off of the bed. “It almost put me off my game.”
Wanda breathed out as much of a laugh as she could manage before saying, “well I’m glad it didn’t, that was some of your best work.”
Rio laughed softly and finished getting dressed, making her way out of Wanda’s bedroom.
Wanda propped herself up on her elbows and shouted after her. “What, no goodbye kiss?”
She didn’t need to see Rio to know that she was laughing and shaking her head.
She listened for the soft click of her front door opening and closing, letting her know that Rio had left.

She leaned back again, this time shifting herself so that she was leaning against the headboard. She found herself craving a cigarette, there really wasn’t anything that matched the feeling of a cigarette after sex, but she hadn’t smoked in years and there were none in her house. She would definitely have to remember to buy a packet for next time.
She sighed at the lack of nicotine and picked up her phone, there were six messages. Five from her ex-husband and one from Billy.

Vision: Happy birthday mother of my child!

The message was followed by three gifs all portraying various different ways to say happy birthday. One was a cake with a sparkler candle, the second one was a tortoise in a party hat and the final one was a cartoon of a pea that had a smiling face and sticks for arms and legs that said “Hap-PEA Birthday!”

Vision: I didn’t get chance to post your card so I’ll swing by your office in the afternoon to give it to you

She tapped out a quick reply.

Wanda: Thank you! I’m free between two and three

Vision: Roger that! 🫡

She smiled and opened Billy’s message.

Billy: Happy birthday!

Wanda: Thank you darling 😊

Billy didn’t reply further so she took that as her cue to get ready for bed. Her legs complained as she tried to stand up, though she was thankful that it was a reminder of how tightly they were clenched around Rio’s head rather than a reminder that she was another year older, but she managed to get to the bathroom and back without them giving out and crawled into bed again.

Her Monday morning lecture wasn’t until ten so she would usually get to campus around nine, but given that it was her birthday she knew that the Head of Department would put on a pseudo party in the staff room under the guise of an emergency meeting.
Sure enough when she woke up and checked her phone there was a message on Teams.

Dottie Jones: Meeting in the staff room at 8am sharp. Everyone must attend.

Wanda smiled, everyone knew that she did this for people’s birthdays but she clearly enjoyed it so no-one said anything against it. It was also just a kind gesture since she bought some decorations, a cake, candles and a few snacks out of her own pocket for every staff member in the Ancient History department who had a birthday during term time.

Wanda showered, got ready for the day and set off to the campus, making sure to swing by the petrol station first to pick up a packet of Benson and Hedges to enjoy post coitus – and at fifteen Great British Pounds per pack, she would make fucking sure that she enjoyed them.
When she had quit smoking nearly a decade ago it had mainly been because the prices had risen too much and she couldn’t justify paying that much every time she bought a new packet. Oh how she wished for those prices again. Fifteen pounds was an absolute joke.

She put the cigarettes in her bag and walked into the Ancient History building, heading straight for the staff room. She opened the door and was greeted with a cheer of “happy birthday!” and a few party poppers going off, covering her in streams of brightly coloured tissue paper. Though she knew it was happening, the smile that she wore was genuine as she looked around the room and saw the happy birthday banner on the wall with a foil balloon held down by a weight floating next to it. On one of the tables in the centre of the room there was a cake with a pile of cards in envelopes and a few gift bags sitting next to it.

Every lecturer in the department was there, except for Agatha but that was a given, and they all gathered around her as she was ushered towards the cake for the candles to be lit and Happy Birthday to be sung. They all clapped when she blew out the candles and she started opening the cards. A few of them had some money in them and there was one that had an obnoxiously large badge that was pink, sparkly and read ‘birthday girl’ in all caps that she was instructed to wear for the entire day. She tried to put up some resistance but folded pretty quickly and pinned it to her cardigan.

The cake was cut and split between everyone and people started to slowly filter out to go teach their lectures and do whatever work they needed to do, leaving Wanda, Dottie and a couple of stragglers who were making the most of the free snacks.
Dottie turned to Wanda. “I’m sorry it wasn’t much, but I hope you liked it.”
Wanda smiled. “Dottie, it’s lovely that you even thought about it. We all appreciate that you do this for us.”
Dottie returned her smile. “It’s just a shame that not everyone joins in.”
Wanda knew who she was talking about, she was referencing Agatha’s lack of attendance.

Agatha hadn’t gone to a single one of the birthday gatherings since they had broken up and Wanda didn’t blame her. The staff had treated Agatha pretty harshly when Wanda had told them the lie that Agatha had cheated on her, a lot of them judged her from afar and conveyed their dislike of her through their facial expressions and body language, but a few of them had had the courage to actually talk to her about it. They had  asked questions, asked how and why she could have possibly done that to Wanda and told her that she was a terrible person for hurting Wanda like that. Agatha had ignored them and done nothing to defend herself or try and set the story straight. She had just let them believe the lies that Wanda had told them and it had confused Wanda but she was also grateful that Agatha hadn’t pushed back because she didn’t know how she would have handled it.

Wanda had gotten everyone on her side so easily, and at first she liked it. People were being extra nice to her, checking on her and making sure that she was never alone with Agatha. They were offering to take a couple of her lectures if she needed some time to herself and offering to have her and Billy round for dinner so that they weren’t alone in the house too much.
She took on the gestures and accepted them all because, while the story they all knew wasn’t true, she was still hurting. She was still going through a break-up and was trying to soothe Billy through it as well.

Billy had been the reason why she had lied. Wanda had loved Agatha, she really had, but it went beyond that for Billy. She realised not long after she had first introduced them that Billy had formed an attachment to Agatha, a bond that connected them more than he was connected to her, his mother, and she had been jealous. Billy went to Agatha with everything, she was his best friend, his favourite person on the planet, his support system.
After he had come out to the two of them Agatha had later told her that he had actually come out to her first and that she had convinced him to come out to them together so that Wanda’s feelings weren't hurt.

She had seen the break-up as a chance to claim back some of the love that he had supplied Agatha with in the four years that they had been together, a chance to show him that she could be everything he saw Agatha as and more. So when she had lied to him, she’d had to lie to everyone else as well. She had to keep the ruse up so that she could keep Billy.
Wanda had been scared that if he had known the truth straight away he would have followed Agatha out of the door and never gone back. He would have chosen Agatha over her and the thought of it tore her heart in two.

Two and a half years on though, she regretted it. Agatha was always able to take hits and let them roll off her like they were nothing, but after being with her for four years Wanda was able to tell when the jabs had hit their mark. The subtle twitch in her eye, the small beat as she composed herself before responding, the slight downturn in the corners of her mouth. Wanda had seen all of these in every interaction Agatha had had with their colleagues following the split. Wanda was safely cocooned in the web that she had spun and she had left Agatha to fend for herself against the elements.

The fallout had died down and people had moved on from making their remarks but the damage had been done, and any relationships that Agatha had with the other staff members in their department had been destroyed. The window where Wanda could have made things right had long since closed, and she was left looking through it, watching Agatha exist on the outside, forever tarred with the brush that Wanda had painted her with. And now that Billy actually knew the truth, knew that it had been Wanda that had cheated on Agatha and she had manipulated everyone including him, their relationship had been strained. She hadn’t told him why she had lied, but just knowing that she had was enough to make him distance himself and she knew that there was no way that she could fix it.

Wanda moved her gaze away from Dottie's eyes when she replied. “You can’t really blame her though. She never fully recovered from the way that she was treated.”
“Yeah, I suppose.” Dottie put a reassuring hand on Wanda’s shoulder. “Well anyway, happy birthday. I have to actually go do some work now so I’ll see you later!” Dottie gave her shoulder a squeeze before leaving.
Wanda stayed for another few minutes, gathering up the cards and gifts to take to her office and prepare for her lectures. 

__________

Around half past two there was a knock at Wanda’s office door and Vision walked in with a big grin on his face.
“Happy birthday!” He sang as he handed her the card he had gotten her. She opened it and affectionately rolled her eyes as she read the front of it.
The card read ‘Happy Birthday To My Favourite Ex’ and he had added ‘wife’ to the end of it. “Thank you for clarifying that I’m your favourite ex wife and not just your favourite ex.” She said with a chuckle and she moved to hug him.
He reciprocated the hug and said, “Well I can’t have you being confused, my favourite ex is someone else and she’ll be very annoyed if I mix you up.”
“Oh I bet she will.”
He laughed and pulled back to give her a kiss on the cheek.

Despite not being able to make their marriage work they were still affectionate with each other, which was the reason why they had continued to sleep together after their divorce. They still cared deeply for each other; they just weren’t in love with each other and that was okay. It was less okay when they had slept together while Wanda was in a relationship but that wasn’t something that they had ever actually talked about. Now though, Wanda had some information that she hadn’t previously known and she had to ask him about it.
“Did-” She sighed and took a step back. “Did you tell Agatha that we… that I cheated on her more than once?”
His smile dropped slightly and he put his hands in his jacket pockets. “Yes I did.”
“Why?” Her tone wasn’t accusatory, she genuinely wanted to know.
“Because I thought that she had a right to know. If she found out some other way further down the line then it would only hurt her more and I’d caused her enough pain already. I didn’t want it to come back at a later date and re-open the wound.”

She couldn’t fault him for it, he was a sweet soul and a genuinely good guy. She didn’t say anything, just nodded and looked at the floor. This was the first time that they’d come close to discussing this topic and it was clear that neither of them knew how to broach it. How is that conversation meant to go?
Vision shifted his weight from one foot to the other in the awkward silence that had taken over the room. “Has Billy wished you a happy birthday yet?”
Wanda looked back up at him. “He texted me this morning but I haven't seen him yet. He doesn’t like interacting with me when we’re on campus in case someone figures out that I’m his mum.” She gave a soft chuckle.
“Ahh yes, he can’t have you ruining his… do they still call it street cred?”
Wanda snorted. “Not for a couple of decades at least.”
He laughed and pulled her into another hug, resting his chin on the top of her head as he spoke. “I have to get back to work, enjoy the rest of your day.” He left her office, saying a final happy birthday before he shut the door.

About ten minutes passed before there was another knock at her door.
“Come in.”
The door opened slowly and Billy gingerly popped his head around it. Wanda smiled because she knew that he was checking that the coast was clear. “Hi sweetheart. You’re safe, don’t worry.”
He stepped fully into the room and shut the door softly behind him before looking around. He hadn’t been in her office before so this was new to him.
“It’s like a more professional version of your home office.” He said, voicing his thoughts. “Less pictures of me.”
Wanda laughed and picked up the frame on her desk, turning it so that he could see the picture. It was of her and Vision with a seven-year-old Billy between them, standing in front of the Lands End signpost from a holiday they went on in Cornwall.

He took the picture from her to get a closer look. “Was this the holiday when we saw the dolphins?”
“It was yeah.” She smiled at the memory. “It was also the one where your dad took you out on that speedboat  and you screamed so loudly that you lost your voice.”
Billy laughed. “Yeah because he nearly flipped the boat! You would have screamed too if you were on it.”
He gave the frame back to her and she put it on her desk again, making sure that it was facing towards her and not out into the room.
“You don’t have to do that if you don’t want to. You can have it where people will see it.”
Wanda dipped her brows in confusion. “I thought you didn’t want people to know that we’re related.”
Billy shrugged. “I’m kinda over it now. People are gonna find out at some point and I suppose there are worse people to be related to.” He flashed a cheeky grin.

She smiled and shook her head. “Are you being nice to me because it’s my birthday?”
“Maybe.” He drew out the word and reached into his bag. “Speaking of which, happy birthday!”
He pulled out a card and a small box from his bag and gave them to her. She opened the card first. On the front it said ‘Mum, you’re one in a melon’ with a picture of a watermelon drawn with eyes and a smile, and on the inside the melon was chopped into segments and it said ‘I love you to pieces!’
She smiled and stood the card up on her desk before picking up the box and unwrapping it. It was a square velvet covered box with a hinged lid. She flipped it up and she gasped lightly when she saw the necklace inside it. It was a gold chain with a red W charm and blue B charm attached to it.

She took the necklace out of the box and laid the charms in her palm so she could get a better look at them. “Billy, this is…” She trailed off, not being able to find the words. It had been nearly a year since she had told him why Agatha had really left that day, nearly a year of him distancing himself from her, nearly a year of their relationship being strained. She hadn’t expected him to buy her a present, she wasn’t even expecting a card. Hell she would have been fine with him leaving it at the text he sent that morning. But he had bought her a card, he had bought her a present and he had gone to her office to give them to her.

She could feel tears starting to gather at the corners of her eyes and she had to blink them away. “Thank you darling, I love it.” She stood up and walked round her desk to give him a hug, but she hesitated before wrapping her arms around him, unsure if he would want her to do it while they were on campus. They might have been in her office but someone could still walk in. 
“Mum you can hug me, it’s okay.” Billy said as he pulled her in, giving her a gentle squeeze. “I’m busy this week because me and Alice want to get a head start on our coursework for the semester, so if you’re good to wait until Saturday we can do something for your birthday then.” He pulled back from the hug. “Maybe go out for a meal with dad?”
Wanda smiled and nodded. “Yeah we can do that. I’ll text him and see if he’s free and then let you know if he’ll be there or not.”
He returned her smile. “Sounds good. I’ve gotta go or I’m gonna be late for my lecture.” Before opening the door he said, “happy birthday, I’ll see you on Saturday!” and then he left.

Having this moment with her son gave her hope that maybe he was ready to start forgiving her, maybe he didn’t hate her as much as he did eleven months ago. Her attention went back to the picture on her desk and she picked it up again to look at it before putting it back down, making sure that it was facing into the room.

__________

The rest of the week crawled by. Wanda had Rio go to her house again on Tuesday night, she had left a couple of birthday cards and the foil balloon strategically placed in the hall in the hopes that Rio would notice them and give more attention to the birthday girl – not that Rio wasn’t already forthcoming with the attention that she gave Wanda, but there was always room for improvement – and it worked beautifully. She came three times before they even made it upstairs and lost count when they eventually got to her bedroom.
She definitely enjoyed her cigarette afterwards.

Vision let her know that he was able to go for dinner with her and Billy on Saturday evening and Wednesday, Thursday and Friday were spent marking the essays that her first and second years had turned in, which was something that Wanda hated. She liked reading the work but there were only so many times that she could read essays answering the same question before she started to feel her brain turning to mush. She had been entertaining the idea of having one of her students be an unofficial TA for a while. It would help lighten the load a bit and would mean that she didn’t have to read the same thing over and over again.
There was a time when she and Agatha would have traded their coursework and marked each others for a bit to stop it from getting stale, but that time had passed so she was back to doing it alone.

By the time that Saturday came around Wanda was ready to have an evening out with her son and his dad. She treated herself to a morning in bed reading her book before begrudgingly leaving the cozy nest that she had made to sort herself some lunch.
She had just sat down to start eating when she heard a key turn in the door followed by boots on the hardwood floor.
“Mum are you in?” Billy’s voice floated down the hall.
“I’m in here sweetheart.” She replied from the living room.

After a minute, Billy appeared in the living room holding two comically large bags filled with clothes. “Did you walk all the way here with those? I would have picked you up.” She said as she stood up off the sofa to take the bags into the kitchen. “Jesus Billy, is this all the stuff you moved in with?”
He moved to help her put the clothes in the washing machine. “Not everything. Just jeans, hoodies and bedding mostly.” He took the clothes off of her and told her that she could sit down and that didn’t have to help him. She tried to continue helping anyway but he said, “mum, I’m eighteen. If I can’t use a washer by myself at this point then there’s no hope for me.”

She couldn’t argue with that so she went to sit back down and continue eating her lunch. “Do you want any food making?” She asked.
“No thank you, I’m saving myself for tonight. That edamame isn’t going to eat itself!”
She could hear the smile in his voice, that kid really did love his edamame. “You might want to throw that hoodie you’re wearing in as well, the smell of it is starting to spread.”
She heard him mutter, “rude,” but heard him unzipping it and stuffing it in the machine anyway.

A few minutes passed before Billy wandered back into the living room and sat next to her on the settee, swinging his legs up to rest his feet on the coffee table. She turned her head in his direction and raised an eyebrow. “Billy Maximoff, I didn’t raise you to do that.”
He tucked his hands behind his head as he relaxed back into the sofa. “No but my dad did.” He said with a cheeky grin.
She snorted softly but kept her gaze on him until he took his feet off of the table and shifted so that they were crossed on the sofa. “I guess I won’t get comfortable in my own home then, damn.” He said sarcastically but there was no disrespect in his voice and the grin never left his face.
“You can be comfortable in any way you want, except that one.” Wanda said, matching his smile.

As she continued to look at him affectionately, the shirt that he was wearing caught her attention. She was sure that she recognised the shirt but she couldn’t place him wearing it. It must have been an old shirt though because the design had almost faded into non-existence. “Is that a new shirt?”
He looked down at it and pulled it so that there were no wrinkles obscuring the print. “Yeah!” He replied excitedly. “Well, it’s new to me. I think it’s actually from the early two thousands.” He turned his back towards her so that she could read the back of the shirt.
The back wasn’t as faded as the front and the words that were printed on it hit her like a truck.

Standing on the Shoulder of Giants Tour
1999–2001

Followed by a list of cities, countries and venues. She told him to turn back around and sure enough, she could now make out the red and orange letters that spelled oasis on the front.

There were only two people that he could have gotten that shirt from and she hoped to god that her first guess was correct. “Did your dad give you that?” She asked apprehensively, repeating ‘please say yes, please say yes’ in her head as she waited for his answer.
He shook his head and her stomach dropped. “No, I got it from a friend.” He furrowed his brow as he took in the look on her face that she wasn't able to hide. “Why? What’s wrong?”
“Which friend?” She asked with a bit too much bite.
Billy must have realised that she knew exactly who he meant because he suddenly looked very guilty, which made her heart ache. He shouldn’t have to feel guilty about spending time with someone who used to be so present in his life, not when they used to be as close as they were and not while they were mending their relationship.

He looked down as he spoke, not able to meet her eyes. “Agatha.” He said softly.
Wanda swallowed and tried to even out her voice. “She gave you that shirt?”
“Mum…” he trailed off and took a deep breath. “I told you that I don’t want to be in the middle of you two. I was at Agatha’s for dinner a couple of nights ago, I saw the shirt in the hall, she said she was giving it to charity and I asked, well begged is more accurate, for her to let me have it instead. I didn’t think that it would be such a big deal.”
Wanda leant forwards and took Billy’s hands in her own. “It’s not a big deal sweetheart, Agatha and I are on civil terms now. It just brought back some memories that I wasn’t expecting.” She gave his hands a gentle squeeze and let a small smile form on her lips. “I’m also not sure how I feel about a shirt that I got when I was seventeen, fitting my eighteen-year-old son better than it ever fit me.” She added, attempting to bring some lightness back into the mood.

It worked a little bit because Billy breathed out a laugh and smiled. “When did you two bury the hatchet?”
“We talked last week, it went… It went as well as it could have gone.” The hatchet was far from buried and Wanda was acutely aware of the fact that her conversation with Agatha did not go well by any stretch of the imagination, but Billy didn’t need to know that.
“I can go upstairs and change if you want.”
Wanda shook her head. “No you don’t have to. If you spill anything on it at dinner though, I will be taking it off you. A shirt this good deserves proper care.”
He put his hand on his chest in mock offense. “Are you implying that I don’t take care of my vintage clothes?”
“Vintage? That shirt is only twenty five years old! By that logic I’m-” She stopped and thought for a second. “Actually, I don’t want to finish that sentence.”

They picked a random movie to watch while they filled the time until Vision picked them up to take them to the restaurant, but Wanda couldn’t focus on it. Seeing that damn shirt out of the corner of her eye was distracting her. She had assumed that it had gotten lost at some point, or accidentally thrown away since it was so faded, but no. Agatha had had it the whole time. She had taken it with her when she moved out, kept it for two and a half years and now she had given it to Billy knowing full well that he would wear it and Wanda would see it. She wasn’t sure what kind of game Agatha was trying to play, but she was going to put a stop to it.
She picked up her phone and sent Agatha a message.

Wanda: We need to talk

She didn’t need to wait long for the reply.

Agatha: I doubt that

Wanda: Let me rephrase. We will be talking on Monday.

Agatha: Let me know how that goes for you

Wanda clenched her jaw and exhaled through her nose. She was going to put this out of her mind until Monday, Agatha wasn’t going to ruin her night with Vision and Billy. 

__________

Wanda knew when Agatha’s downtime was on a Monday, she knew when her downtime was every day. Agatha hadn’t changed her schedule since before she got her professorship and Wanda was choosing that Monday as the day that she would make her regret it.

Wanda waited outside Agatha’s office for a few seconds to check if she could hear anyone in there with her, but it was silent so she walked straight in.
“It is basic manners to knock upon a door and wait for permission before entering.” Agatha said, not looking up from her laptop.
Wanda smiled and forced sweetness into her voice. “Oh, I think we’re past basic manners at this point. Don’t you, Agatha?”
Agatha’s head snapped up at the recognition of Wanda’s voice. She tensed her jaw and slowly removed her glasses, setting them on the keyboard of her laptop before placing her elbows on her desk and resting her chin on her clasped hands. “Well this ought to be good.”

Wanda stormed forwards, stopping at the edge of Agatha’s desk. “That’s all you have to say to me?”
Agatha leaned back in her chair, a ghost of a smile on her lips. “Oh no, I have plenty to say to you, Wanda. But we are at work so there is an element of decorum that must be upheld.” She ran her eyes up and down Wanda’s form. “Which I see you are doing so beautifully well.” Her voice was low and controlled like she knew that she was in command, and this made Wanda’s blood boil.

She leant forwards and put her hands on the desk to support her, trying to mimic the way that Agatha had done it just over a week ago. “And where does hypocrisy fit into your decorum?” She asked, keeping her voice level.
Agatha looked wholly uninterested in Wanda’s accusation, rolling her eyes. “Wanda, if you have something to ask me please get to it instead of dancing around it. Unlike you, I actually have some work to do.” She sat upright in her chair again and slipped her glasses back onto her face, returning her attention to her laptop.
Wanda reached forwards and shut the lid of the laptop. Agatha threw her hands up and mumbled, “is this becoming a trend?”

Wanda had no idea what she meant so she continued on the track she had started on. “You accuse me of using my son to play games with you and then he comes home and just happens to be wearing that shirt? Your sanctimonious display got me for a second, I won’t lie. But now I know that you’re no better than how you see me. Maybe you were just projecting.” Wanda straightened again and crossed her arms over her chest, a satisfied smile spreading across her face.

She watched Agatha’s face, looking for anything that might hint at a crack but she was holding strong. “I assure you Wanda, I have no idea what you are talking about.”
“Cut the bullshit Agatha. Billy told me that you had him over for dinner and gave him the Oasis shirt. My Oasis shirt. The Oasis shirt that you took with you when you stormed out of the house two and a half years ago.” Wanda knew that Agatha was just trying to toy with her but she was tired of it. Agatha had attacked her in her own office and Wanda had just let it happen, but she was standing her ground today like she should have then.
Agatha rolled her eyes again. “That’s what this is about? It was in a pile of clothes that I was going to give to charity and the kid saw it and wouldn’t take no for an answer. It’s just a shirt Wanda, it doesn’t mean anything.” A look of knowing flashed across Agatha’s face.

Agatha was lying, there was no question. Wanda had zero doubt in her mind that Agatha had found that shirt and come up with this plan to fuck with her. Agatha knew the significance that shirt held to Wanda. It was more than just a simple item of clothing, it was from the concert that Vision took her to on their first date. It was a symbol of her family, of how that date led her into falling in love and having her son, the most important person in her life. It was a symbol of accepting Agatha into said family and having her be present in Billy’s life in a parental role alongside herself and Vision. It was a damn sight more than just a shirt and Agatha knew that.

Wanda kept her arms crossed, balling her hands into fists but Agatha continued before she could speak. “I’ve never had an interest in Oasis. If you hadn’t spent so much time with your legs wrapped around your ex-husband, you might have known that.”
There it was. Wanda had wondered how long it would take Agatha to go there, it always ended up there.
“This isn’t about that.” Wanda bit out. “This is about you using an innocent teenager, a teenager whose world used to revolve around you, as a way to get back at your ex-fiancée.”
Agatha laughed darkly, like she couldn’t believe what Wanda had said. “And now you’re weaponising my past relationship with Billy to try and make me feel guilty for doing something that made him happy. I was giving the shirt to charity in an attempt to avoid,” she gestured at Wanda, “whatever the fuck this is.” She leaned back in her chair again. “Did this make you feel better? Did you get the result that you wanted? Or are you going to admit that any way you happen to be feeling about seeing that old shirt again is a direct result of your own actions?”

Wanda could feel her pulse hammering. She had gone into this thinking that she would be able to catch Agatha off guard, to gain the upper hand. But Agatha had managed to stay one step ahead like she always did, Wanda would never be able to match her no matter how hard she tried. She had lost once again and was going to be leaving Agatha’s office feeling defeated. Since they broke up, arguing with Agatha had always been a losing battle, there was very little that Wanda could do now to come out on top and that fact made it very hard to keep a level head.

The heat in Wanda’s chest started to creep into her face, a stark contrast to Agatha’s calm and collected demeanour. If she clenched her fists any tighter, her whole upper body was going to start shaking so she jabbed a finger in Agatha’s direction and snarled, “stop manipulating my son.” before turning and storming out of the office.
“Always a pleasure chatting with you, Wanda.” She heard Agatha call after her but she couldn’t respond. She slammed the door and practically ran back to her own office because she didn’t want anyone to see her until she’d had a chance to calm down.

She shut her door and immediately collapsed against it, sliding to the floor and pulling her knees up to her chest. As long as it was hers to wield, Agatha would use Wanda’s mistake as a weapon, and it would work every time. Wanda was powerless against it and that was entirely her own fault. 

Chapter End Notes

It's my birthday so don't shout at me for doing another Wanda chapter pls

Chapter 16: Rio

Chapter Notes

I used google translate for the Spanish so please don't shout at me

Edit: (12/07) I forgot about Wednesday night band practise so I've amended the times

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Had that actually just happened? Had she actually just spoken to Agatha Harkness like that and lived to tell the tale? How many people could say that? Rio was probably the only one, she had to be. Why had Agatha let her get away with it, and what was that look on her face? 
Anger? No, she'd seen Agatha angry and that wasn't it.
Fear? Also no. Agatha wasn't scared of her. The thought was laughable. 
So what was it? Arousal? 
Okay, maybe Rio's head was still a bit scrambled from being in Wanda's office earlier but could you really blame her? 

She made her way to the library because she'd walked all the way to campus so she might as well make it worth her while and get some work done. Her favourite corner was free so she set up camp and started perusing the shelves, pulling out five or six random books to start with.
‘It is important that you can do independent work and think for yourself.’ Agatha’s words replayed in her head as she realised that the sections of the books she was focussing on were all about the Labyrinth or the Minotaur, the things that Agatha had been teaching about on Wednesday.
Maybe she had a point, but Rio was too petty to admit that right now so instead she told herself that it was because Theseus’ story interested her and she hadn’t covered it in her research yet.

She managed a few good hours of working before her brain was begging for a distraction, just half an hour of solace before returning to the grind. She opened a new tab on her laptop and went to YouTube to watch some drum covers of the songs the band had narrowed the setlist down to. She had managed to get away with learning the intro and making up the rest thus far, but she knew that she really should try and learn them properly before they had to perform.

She was halfway through a cover of Call Me by Blondie, trying to quietly tap along with it so as not to disturb the other people using the library, when her phone lit up showing a new message in her group chat with Billy and Alice.

Billy: Yo Lars are you around?

Rio scoffed. You mess up the groove one time and you’re nicknamed after the drummer from Metallica.

Rio: I’m in the library

Billy: Should’ve known tbh that’s on me

She rolled her eyes and went back to YouTube – her research for the day was definitely over because this was far more interesting right now. By the time the song finished she could see two people approaching her in her periphery. She hoped that they weren’t going to try to share her table but she only turned her attention to them once they were standing on either side of her. It was Alice and Billy.

She took out her earphones and looked at each of them. “Can I help you?”
Billy pulled out the seat next to her and sat down. “You’re coming to the Halloween thing tonight, right?”
Rio hadn’t even noticed what date it was. Usually on Halloween she would be getting dressed up and going out with her friends to the gay bars, drinking god knows what and then waking up god knows where, next to god knows who. But the day had completely slipped her mind this year, and she suddenly felt FOMO about the fact that she wouldn’t be causing chaos with her friends. She hadn’t even factored Halloween into her packing to come to England.

Rio shook her head. “I have nothing to wear so I’m gonna have to pass.”
Alice sat on the table instead of the free chair and started swinging her legs. “We can find you something between us.”
Billy snapped his fingers as a thought came to him. “You could be Reggie from Julie and The Phantoms!"
Rio looked at him confused. “Who?”
“No, fuck that.” Alice cut in. “Danny from Grease!”
That wasn’t a bad idea actually, but she still wasn’t feeling it. “I think I’m gonna sit this one ou-”
Billy and Alice continued talking over her.

“My mum and dad were Danny and Sandy when I was like six and I had to stay at my uncle’s house that night.” Billy shuddered slightly as he recalled the memory.
“But your dad’s blonde?” Alice started. “And your mum’s… not blonde.”
Billy shrugged. “He used a temporary dye and she wore a wig. It’s not rocket science.”
Rio put her hands up and said, “okay,” definitely too loudly considering the fact that they were still in the library. The two of them stopped talking and looked at her and she lowered her voice again. “First of all, the two people you suggested for me are guys and I’m not sure if I should be offended or not. Second, my hair is too long to be Danny and I’m guessing it would be for that other one you said as well.”
Alice waved her hand, dismissing Rio’s comments. “You could tie your hair up and quiff it at the front, it would achieve the same effect. I’m assuming you have a white t-shirt and you already have the leather jacket and skinny jeans.” She spread her arms like it was an obvious answer. “Seems like Danny is a done deal to me.”

Rio sighed and looked at Billy who was just staring at her with a goofy grin while nodding his head. She closed her eyes and tipped her head back, sliding forwards in her chair until her head touched the back of it. She took a deep breath and breathed out, “fine,” which prompted a whoop from Billy and earned them all an annoyed shush from the people around them.
Billy and Alice stood to leave. “We’re doing pre-drinks at ours so get there around seven.”
Rio widened her eyes. “Seven? What time does this thing start?”
“Nine.”
Nine? Nine? Either she was getting old or the start times for these events were getting unreasonably late.
The shock must have been evident on her face because Alice patted her on the shoulder and said, “You can’t back out now, see you later.” And with that, they both left, leaving Rio to question her decisions. 

__________

Rio was giving herself one last look over in the mirror and she hated that Alice had been right about her hair. It was simple but it really did make her look like a female Danny Zuko minus the curl, and she looked damn good. She twisted to the side to get a view of her butt in the mirror and nodded approvingly. She had found her tightest pair of jeans, these ones were a size too small so they weren’t comfortable to sit in but she’d survive knowing that she looked this good. Finishing the look with a basic black leather jacket – there was no way in hell that she would be wearing her expensive one to a university Halloween event – and a pair of black converse, she headed out the door and towards the campus housing that Billy and Alice lived in.

They had told her to go to the back where the door that opened into the living room was being held open by a fire extinguisher. She walked in and said, “you know any random person could just walk in here?”
The people in the room all turned to her in unison. She recognised Billy, Alice, Eddie and Ash but she had no idea who the other three people were – Billy and Alice’s housemates, she assumed.

Eddie gave a low whistle followed by, “damn Rio.”
Ash nodded. “I second that.” They walked over to Rio and handed her a bottle of beer. “Billy has something for you.”
“For fuck sake, what now?” Rio took a drink of her beer and looked over at Billy who had the same goofy smile as he did earlier in the library.
He proudly held up a large square of black paper that had the T-Birds logo drawn on it in white pen. “Gotta make sure people know who you are.”
Rio rolled her eyes. “You are not putting that on my back.”
Alice held up a box of safety pins and shook it back and forth, making them rattle. “Oh yes we are.” She matched Billy’s smile. “Turn around please.”
Rio was really glad that she hadn’t worn her expensive jacket.

When they had finished pinning the logo to her jacket Billy introduced her to everyone – she almost immediately forgot their names and instead referred to them by the names of the things they were dressed as, but no-one complained.
The pre-drinks were kicked off in style with a game of Ring Of Fire and her bandmates weren’t kidding when they said that Billy couldn’t hold his alcohol. The more drunk he got, the more he kept messing up the rules and having to drink more. Two and half rounds in, Eddie swapped his drink for water. It was unclear if he noticed or not but he kept drinking it regardless.

It had been nearly a decade since Rio had played this game but the muscle memory kicked in pretty quickly. She made sure not to answer anything that was posed as a question, nor did she ever have her drink less than a thumbs length from the edge of the table. Who knew that drinking game rules she learned in her teens would be useful in her thirties?

By the end of the fifth round everyone was pretty nicely buzzed and the two decks of cards that had been spread around the kings cup – which was a fucking stein of all things – were getting thin. Four out the the eight kings had been pulled and the liquid inside the cup was looking horrid. Whoever the poor soul was that had to drink that was, they were in for a nasty time. Rio pulled a seven from the pile and subtly pointed her left index finger upwards, keeping an eye on everyone around the table to catch the person who was last to follow suit.
“Ah bad luck Beetlejuice,” She said, pointing at him, “Time to drink.”

Another couple of rounds later there was only one king left in play, and the likelihood of breaking the circle was just as big as picking up the final king. There were three people before Rio. Alice picked up a five, but the circle remained intact. Lara Croft picked up the final queen, but no broken circle. Ash picked up a four, which meant all the girls had to drink, but somehow the circle was still going strong. Rio’s turn came and she took her time picking her card, standing up to get a better look.
“Clocks ticking Rio.” Eddie said. “Gotta make a choice.”
“Don’t rush me, this is delicate work.” She said, not taking her eyes off the cards as if the right one was going to make itself known to her. About ten seconds later, she made her choice and picked up a card.

Time seemed to slow down as she lifted the card from the table – though that could have been an effect of the alcohol – and gasps echoed around the table as the realisation set in that the card she had picked had broken the circle. She groaned and flipped the card anyway to see what it was. It was the final king, a double whammy.
“Oh fuck me.” She said as she sat back down.
The guy who was wearing a lion onesie looked at her with his eyes full of sympathy. “Yikes bro, that’s a bad do.”
Rio gave herself a final moment to prepare before she picked up the cup. The liquid was a disgusting shade of brown and the smell could not be described in any of the known languages on planet earth.

The seven other people began chanting “We like to drink with Rio, ‘cause Rio is our mate. And when we drink with Rio, she sees it off in eight…”
As soon as the countdown started she put the stein to her lips, immediately screwing her face up at the taste. It was the most vile thing she had ever had in her mouth, but she wasn’t going to pussy out in front of a group of undergrads so she kept going until the cup was drained.
“Joder, quiero morirme.” She muttered before leaning forward and resting her forehead on the table in front of her

Billy, now sobered up thanks to the water, asked, “What did that taste like?”
She lifted her head just enough to look at him and managed to say. “Your mom.”
“You’re not her type.” He replied with a cheeky smile and she put her head back down on the table.
“Soy demasiado vieja para esta mierda.” She said to herself when she felt a hand patting her back reassuringly.
“You took that like a champ, dude.” Eddie said before clapping his hands and continuing. “Okay, fifteen minutes to piss, finish your drinks, have a tactical chunder if you’re Rio, or whatever else you want to do before we head to the bar.”

Rio slowly sat back up. She’d only been slightly tipsy due to her incredible retention of the rules, but that cocktail of death had gone straight to her head and the room was starting to spin. She made sure to have some water before they left, though it didn’t do anything to help. It just sat on top of all the other liquid that was moving around her stomach. She knew pre-gaming would be a bad idea.

They set off to the bar and could hear the music coming from it before the building even came into view, the Halloween party in full swing. Beetlejuice offered to buy Rio a drink for enduring the kings cup but she insisted that she just wanted water. The short walk and the fresh air had helped slightly, but she’d done this enough times to know her limits and she’d need at least an hour before she could even think about alcohol again. 

After some time her head and stomach started to settle so she had a few more drinks and danced with Billy, Alice, Ash and Eddie. 
Around midnight she decided that it was time for her to call it a night – much to her friends’ disappointment. They made some attempts to get her to stay a bit longer since the bar was staying open until four, but she stayed strong and said her goodbyes before making her way home. 
When she got in she went straight to bed, looking forward to a lazy weekend. 

__________

Sunday afternoon band practise was a good one. They drilled the songs over and over trying to make sure they had them as tight as they could be.
“I'm still not sure about Seven Nation Army.” Ash said. “Are You Gonna Be My Girl is a better fit for us I think.”
“That’s just because Seven Nation Army isn't actually played on bass, isn't it?” Rio asked with a smirk.
Ash turned to face her. “It's not just that… but yes that is the main reason.” They said with a light laugh. “I'm also thinking of you, because the drums for Seven Nation Army are boring as fuck.”
“The whole song is boring as fuck.” Alice chimed in and Billy agreed.
Eddie put his hands up. “Okay. Seven Nation Army is out and Are You Gonna Be My Girl is in. Let's run it.”

They finished their practice and went to the bar for a couple of drinks before parting ways.
Rio made herself some food and settled in front of the TV. About an hour later she got a text from Wanda asking, or more accurately, telling, her to go over – which she happily did.

She was happy with her arrangement with Wanda and she tended to let Wanda take the lead on when and where they would be meeting. It was usually in the evening at Wanda’s house, which worked better for Rio because it meant that she could leave and didn’t have to deal with the awkwardness of asking Wanda to leave her apartment after they were done, and Rio was pretty sure she could find her way to Wanda’s with a blindfold on at this point. But there was something about it that she couldn’t quite identify. It felt like there was something missing, though she didn’t know what that thing was. The sex was good, great even. Wanda understood the assignment and was happy with Rio leaving afterwards. She made the odd joke about Rio staying for dinner or giving her a goodbye kiss but they were just jokes.

Wanda was another notch in her bedpost that gave good head, so why was there something that didn’t feel quite right? She had been casually sleeping with women for the better part of a decade and she had never had this feeling before so why was it happening now?

It wasn’t the fact that Wanda had a son, Rio really couldn’t care less about that. It wasn’t the fact that Wanda was older than her, she liked older women. So what the fuck was wrong with this situation?
There shouldn’t be anything wrong.

__________

Wednesday morning came around and since she didn’t have to be in Agatha’s office for nine o’clock, Rio didn’t bother setting any alarms. But it appeared that her body clock hadn’t received the memo and she woke up at eight on the dot. She groaned and rolled over trying to go back to sleep but it was futile since her brain was wide awake and ready to start the day. She begrudgingly sat up, her mind might be under the illusion that she had things to do this morning but she sure as hell wasn’t going to do anything. She had her Wednesday mornings back and she was going to enjoy it.

She spent the day becoming one with her couch and playing her Switch. Technically playing Hades for ten hours counted as research since it was mythology based, so she was still doing work, she just wasn’t frying her brain by reading massive walls of text over and over again.
She was, however, embarrassingly bad at the game. She could make it to Asphodel pretty easily if she got the right boones, but anything after that and she died instantly. She could almost understand why men threw controllers and broke TVs over losing a game.
Almost.
She would never do it because she wasn’t that emotionally immature, but after a few hours of dying in exactly the same place the temptation was definitely there.

When it got to the time that she would usually be getting ready to head to the music room, she got a message in the band group chat.

Eddie: Remember there’s no practise tonight because it’s bonfire night.

Eddie: You’re still welcome to come with us Rio!

She had indeed forgotten. The English tradition had slipped her mind but she remembered them talking about it on Sunday, saying that a local pub was having a huge fire in their car park and that it was open to the public.

Rio: Sounds good, I love fire. I’ll meet you guys there!

“What does someone wear to a bonfire?” She asked to her wardrobe as she was looking at her clothes. She’d sat around her fair share of campfires so this should be the same but slightly bigger, right? She pulled on an old pair of jeans and a slightly worse-for-wear shirt that she didn’t mind the smell of smoke becoming embedded in, grabbed her winter coat and a beanie to keep her ears safe from the cold and set off to the pub.

A crowd had already started to gather in the car park when she got there but her attention was drawn to the massive pile of wood in the centre. It was impressively arranged in a pyramid and had two barriers around the base to stop people from getting too close. She squinted slightly and swore that she could see some bar stools in the mix with the rest of the planks and branches. Maybe this would be a bit more than just a big campfire.

She spotted her friends easily and weaved her way through the people to get to them. They all greeted each other and Rio recognised one of the girls from Halloween.
“Oh hey. Lara Croft, right?” She asked, moving to stand next to her.
Lara Croft smiled and said, “My name is Taylor, but I’ll let you off. My memory would be fucked too if I had to drink the stein mixed by Satan.”
Rio scrunched up her face as the memory of the taste of that drink replayed on her tongue. “Ugh yeah. That was the worst thing I’ve ever tasted in my thirty years on this planet.”
Taylor laughed. “Hopefully this will taste better.” She handed Rio a plastic cup. “It’s warm cider, nice and sweet.”

Rio took the cup and gingerly had her first sip. She wasn’t a fan of cider usually but this was a pleasant surprise. The warmth seemed to dull the sugary aftertaste and she took a bigger drink from it. “That’s not bad actually.”
A voice rang out over the crowd through a megaphone announcing that the fire would be lit in two minutes and a cheer rippled through the throng.
Rio addressed the group. “So run me through this again. Some dude tries to kill your king and you celebrate it every year by drinking and setting shit on fire?”
“First of all, we celebrate everything by drinking.” Alice started. “But this isn’t a celebration of an attempted assassination. This is a celebration of the fact that the assassination was stopped.”
Eddie jumped in. “Sometimes people make an effigy of Guy Fawkes to put on the bonfire, but I’ve never actually seen one of those sadly.”
“Also, there’s fireworks.” Taylor finished.
Rio nodded, still confused but accepting of that fact. “Fire, booze, fun. Got it.” 
“Exactly!” Billy said and they all knocked their cups together and turned to watch the fire being lit.

Three people took positions at the base of the fire with barbeque lighters and lit a ring of rags at the bottom. The cloth went up instantly and the people hurriedly stepped away, back behind the protective barriers. A few seconds later the whole pyramid lit up and the crowd roared. Another announcement was made over the megaphone that food was ready inside and to form a queue on the left side of the entrance. There was an assortment of cakes and other sweet treats laid out and they were serving a hot pie that Taylor informed her was a pork pie and that they were delicious. So she took one and they all filtered back outside.

They ate their food and refilled their cups whilst chatting and got onto the topic of the band.
“Do you guys have a name?” Taylor asked, mostly to Rio.
“I’m letting these guys handle that, I’m just there to look hot and hit things.”
“Well, you manage one of the two.” Billy said with a smirk.
Rio patted him on the head. “Aww, thanks for saying I’m hot buddy. But I don’t swing that way.”
He rolled his eyes and pushed her hand away. “Taylor is right though, we should have a name.”
They all went back and forth for a few minutes suggesting and shooting down ideas, ultimately getting nowhere until Taylor spoke. “Why don’t I come to your next rehearsal to watch you guys play and see if I can come up with one from your vibe?”
They all agreed that having a third party make the choice was the best avenue.

Not long after, everyone migrated around to the back of the building to watch the fireworks display that the pub was also putting on. Being away from the direct heat of the fire made them all huddle closer together and Taylor laced her arm around Rio’s. “I’m using the penguin technique and stealing your body heat.” She said when Rio looked at her.
Rio knew where this was going, Taylor had been glued to her all night and now she was initiating touch. Sure it was through the many layers of clothing that both of them were wearing to keep warm, but it was a classic move nonetheless.
Taylor wasn’t Rio’s usual type – she was younger than her for a start – but one night couldn’t hurt.

They watched the fireworks and the first few made Taylor jump and bury herself further into Rio – another classic move – and Rio made a quip about loud bangs not bothering her since she was American which made Taylor laugh harder than it should have. This girl was really pulling out all the stops.

When the fireworks ended some people went back to the food and filled up their plates again or got more cider, planning on staying for a bit longer, but their group decided that they were going to head home. The campus housing was on the way to Rio’s building so she walked with them. Alice broke off and went in the direction of her and Billy’s block of flats but Billy carried on with Eddie towards a different block.

Rio had called it a while ago, she had noticed the way that they looked at each other.
Taylor, still with her arm linked around Rio’s, slowed their walking so that they fell behind Billy and Eddie a little bit until they eventually stopped, and Taylor turned to face her. She gestured in the direction that Billy and Eddie were still walking. “I live in the same block as Eddie. I’m assuming that you live off campus since I’ve never seen you.” 

Rio inclined her head in the direction of her building. “Yeah I live just up there. I’m too old for campus housing, I think.”

“Are you too old to spend one night in campus housing?” Taylor asked, her eyes flicking down to Rio’s lips and back up to her face as she spoke.
Rio smirked. She had no intention of sleeping over but Taylor didn’t need to know that yet. “I suppose I could handle that.”
“Well then, follow me.”

When the time came Rio made her excuses to leave, saying something about having an early PhD meeting in the morning. Taylor tried to get her to stay as predicted, but gave in and Rio walked home pushing down the same feeling that she always had when she left Wanda’s house. Something about it wasn’t quite right.

_________

Rio turned up to band practise on Sunday a little late and walked into the room while they were half way through Pink Pony Club. Taylor was sitting on the sofa at the far end of the room watching them, but waved at Rio when she saw her. Rio gave her a polite smile and a nod of acknowledgement before moving to sit at the drum kit to join the song. When the song was over Ash turned to her with a mischievous smile. “Well the first half of that was good, until Lars eventually showed up and threw us all out of time.”
Rio lightly threw a drum stick in their direction which landed at their feet. “Oops sorry, my hand slipped.”
“It’s okay.” Ash said, giving Rio the stick back. “Your aim is as bad as your drumming.”
Rio worked her tongue against her cheek and flipped them off.

Eddie spoke up to get their attention. “Now that we’re all here, I want to run it again. Rio, we were thinking about giving it more of a pop punk vibe, that cool with you?”
Rio nodded. “Let’s do it!”
They played through the song again, adding more distortion to the guitars and Eddie sang with a rougher tone to his voice. Pop punk was a genre where Rio felt comfortable, it was the type of music that her old band played, so she sent it. Who needs a double pedal when you can do heel-toe?

Taylor clapped when they were done and Billy looked at Rio in awe. “Where the fuck have you been hiding that?”
Maybe she had dumbed down her drumming ability a little bit when she had first joined them. It was safer than going into it being cocky and not being as good as she thought she was years ago. She had also lied a little bit when she told them that she hadn’t played properly since high school. She had continued her lessons through college and she had an electric kit at home that she played just to make sure that she didn’t lose the skill, she just hadn’t been in another band.
