Playing an instrument by yourself in your own house was different than playing with other musicians.
Rio shrugged. “Maybe you just underestimated me.”

They played through the setlist from start to finish at Taylor’s request so that she could come up with the perfect name for them. The set was quite a mish-mash of different genres, a combination of songs that they all liked and songs that they knew would be crowd pleasers.
Taylor told them all to give her a minute to think and Rio started a drumroll, hitting the crash when Taylor said, “Okay, I’ve got it! How do you feel about Twisted Symphony?”
They looked between themselves for a moment, nodding.
“Wait, why twisted?” Ash asked.
“Well, I’d say Straight Symphony but…” Taylor smirked.
“Yeah, not in this band.” Alice deadpanned and they all laughed. 

__________

The next couple of days passed without much happening.
On Monday afternoon Rio read over one of Eddie's essays and sat in the library with him to help him refine it since the deadline was that night.
In the evening she was at Wanda’s for a few hours and accepted a cigarette from her for the walk home. She breathed the smoke into her lungs, savouring the slight burn in the back of her throat. She much preferred a joint after sex, but since weed wasn’t legal here, she would take what she could get.

She spent Tuesday morning in her flat reading and enjoying some time to herself and in the afternoon she had a group call with her friends to catch up and get updated on the home gossip.
“You remember Natasha from homeroom, the one that bullied you for being gay?” Maddy, her high school best friend asked, and Rio rolled her eyes.
“Of course I remember her, she made my life hell.”
“Yeah well, she got married last week. To a fucking woman.”
Rio sat up from where she was laid on the sofa. “I fucking knew it! I said that she bullied me because she wanted me and you laughed at me. I was fucking right!”
“Yeah I know, your gaydar has always been impeccable. That one's on me.” Maddy said.
“Damn right, I knew you were bi before you did.” Rio grinned.

Chloe, a friend she had made in her final year of her undergrad piped up. “Speaking of being gay, have you found your hot, British, future wife yet?”
“C’mon Chloe, you know me, I don’t want to be tied down. Unless they’re into that.” Rio wagged her eyebrows and her friends made various noises of disapproval.
“Boooo!”
“You always have to bring the tone down.”
“That was such a cheap joke!”
Rio just laughed, fuelled by their criticism.

In the evening she was playing Assassin's Creed when her phone pinged with an email notification. She finished the fight she was in before pausing the game and checking her phone, and lifted her eyebrows in surprise at what she read.

Rio,

Given the nature of our last conversation I understand that this might not be something that you would want to do, but would you be able to come to my office at 9am tomorrow morning (Weds 12th)?

Apologies for the short notice.

Agatha

What the actual fuck? Agatha had made it very clear the last time they spoke that she didn’t want to see Rio again, so what was this about?
This was the first time that Agatha had purposefully used Rio’s name and referred to herself as Agatha.
Rio had no idea what Agatha could possibly be wanting, but she wasn’t going to entertain it.

Dear Professor Harkness,

Since you have already acknowledged that you are aware of my possible unwillingness to agree to this meeting, it should come as no surprise to you that I am disinclined to acquiesce to your request.

Sincerely,
Rio Vidal

P.S. The short notice is not the issue.

She debated whether she should keep the last sentence or not. She had already been petty enough by not using Agatha’s name and by using Agatha’s own words from their last conversation, leaving that on the end might cause more issues than it was worth. She loosed a frustrated sigh and deleted it before hitting send and throwing her phone on the coffee table in front of her and unpausing her game.

Rio began working her frustration out on some unsuspecting villagers, racking up a bounty that put her on the radar of some high level bounty hunters. About ten minutes, and a pile of dead villagers later, her phone pinged again. She rolled her eyes and paused the game once again.

Rio,

Understood.

I would like to have an actual conversation with you regarding the way things were left, so I will be in my office from 9-11am as usual should you change your mind.

Agatha

Rio just stared at the email, completely devoid of a response. Why was Agatha choosing now to treat her like a person? Was she only doing it because Rio had forced her to come to terms with the fact that she had previously spoken to her like shit, or was this a genuine attempt at an apology?
Rio couldn’t deny that her interest was piqued. Not at what Agatha could possibly have to say, but why she wanted to say it.
She thought for a couple of minutes about how to reply and ended up sending only one word.

Fine.

__________

Once again, Rio didn’t bother setting any alarms for the morning. She hadn’t committed to a time and if Agatha was kept waiting, then she was kept waiting. Rio simply did not care. However, just like the week prior, she woke up bang on eight o’clock – betrayed again by her fucking body clock.

She laid in bed, staring at the ceiling, scrolling on her phone, anything to make herself even the slightest bit late. She stayed there for about twenty minutes before she huffed out a groan, dramatically threw her quilt off of her body and swung her legs out of bed. She slowly got herself ready and unhurriedly began her walk to campus, choosing to take the long way to the building where the ancient history department was instead of cutting across the car park like she normally would.

She considered pressing every button between the ground floor and the floor she needed in the lift just to make it take longer, but two other people got in just as the doors were closing so she didn’t want to inconvenience them with her own need to be as petty as possible – though the temptation was definitely still there.
When she got to the door of Agatha’s office she checked the time, 9:17. Late enough.
She knocked on the door three times and waited for Agatha to tell her to go in.
“You may enter.”

Rio took a steady breath, pushing down the annoyance that was already beginning to rise in her chest, and opened the door.
Agatha was sitting at her desk typing on her laptop, her glasses hooked onto her shirt by one of the arms, a stack of papers to her right and a coffee cup to her left. It was childish but Rio allowed herself a moment of satisfaction at the knowledge that Agatha was having to get her own coffee again on a Wednesday morning again.
When Agatha lifted her head to look at her, Rio was expecting to see the usual look of indifference painted on her face, but instead she looked… happy?

Agatha smiled and said, “Rio! I’m glad you could make it,” like they were old friends who had recently reconnected and had agreed to meet for coffee and a catch up.
Rio stayed where she was standing by the door and shrugged. “I was awake.” She wasn’t going to give Agatha anything until she knew why she had been asked to come to her office. “Is this gonna take long? I have some things to do.”
Agatha stood from her seat, picked up her coffee, and walked around her desk to the armchair in the centre of the room. “It can take as long as you want it to.” She sat down and gestured to the chair that Rio usually sat in. “Please, take a seat.” Her voice sounded like the niceness was being forced into it as she spoke. Like she was trying to put on a jovial front in an attempt to make Rio feel more at ease. It wasn’t working.

Rio didn’t move for a moment, she just looked at Agatha sceptically until Agatha dropped the over-the-top smile to a smaller one and asked again, more sincerely this time. “Please?”
Rio shifted her eyes to the side and walked to her chair, dropping herself into it. She didn’t speak, instead she gestured towards Agatha. Agatha had asked her to come here, she could be the one to do the talking.

Agatha understood and cleared her throat before she started to speak. “I know that it won’t mean much at the moment but I would like to apologise. You were right, I was treating you… poorly and I had no reason to do so. So for that, I am sorry.”
It was a start but Rio was going to need more than a lukewarm apology. “You had me come here for that? You couldn’t have said that in your email?”
Agatha’s eyes dropped for a second before making their way back up to Rio’s face. “I could have, but that is only the start of what I want to say. If you’re willing to hear me out?”
Rio leaned back in the chair and folded her arms across her chest. “Go ahead.”

As Rio relaxed into her seat, Agatha seemed to do the opposite. She straightened her back and tucked one ankle behind the other. Her shoulders rose and fell with the breath that she took. “Due to some personal reasons that I’m not comfortable discussing right now, I like to keep certain parts of myself contained and when people try to reveal those parts, however innocent their intentions may be, I can become a bit…” She took a second to find the word, “prickly.” She took a drink from her cup. “I have since realised that you weren’t trying to pry into my life or be nosey, which I know you expressed multiple times, and that I may have overreacted-”
Rio couldn’t stop the scoff that happened in the back of her throat and it made Agatha reconsider her words. “Okay I definitely overreacted. I’m not trying to excuse my behaviour, I’m just trying to offer an explanation, and hopefully an apology that has some weight to it that you can accept.” Her words began to speed up, like she was rambling to fill the awkward silence that would inevitably drop once she finished speaking. “I’m aware that it isn’t that simple or easy but if you have any questions or things you want me to clear up then you can ask them, and I will answer without being defensive or talking down to you.”

A silence did begin to settle but Rio didn’t find it awkward, at least not fully. She uncrossed her arms and straightened herself in her chair slightly as she took in what Agatha had said.
She seemed genuine in her attempt to take accountability for her actions over the past couple of months and Rio could respect that, though it was a long way from accepting it. “Thank you for your apology, Professor.” Even though Agatha had signed her emails with her name instead of her title and surname, Rio still wasn’t sure about using her first name. She couldn’t help but see it as a way to lure her into a false sense of security somehow. She couldn’t trust that Agatha wouldn’t just do another one-eighty and flip out on her again. “As for questions, I do have some. But just to be clear, you are allowed to say that you don’t want to answer them. I’m not trying to make you uncomfortable or accidentally ask you to talk about something that you don’t want to talk about.”
Agatha smiled and relaxed her shoulders. “I know. And if one of your questions broaches a topic that I don’t want to get into, I will let you know. Also, you don’t have to call me Professor if you don’t want to. But that is entirely up to you.”

Rio couldn’t describe how she was feeling sitting in Agatha’s office with a new dynamic being presented to her. She was definitely confused, still a little agitated, but most of all she felt weird. That’s the only word that felt close to being accurate. Weird.
It was weird that Agatha had emailed her practically begging her to go back to her office. It was weird that Agatha had suddenly decided that not calling her Professor wasn’t a huge breach of the rules that she herself had been so adamant to set and maintain. Agatha’s motivations were unclear and it was weird.

Rio cleared her throat because the silence was now starting to take on an edge of awkwardness. “I guess my first question is: why?”
Agatha raised her eyebrows slightly. “You’re going to have to be more specific.” She took a  sip of her coffee.
“Why did you ask me here? Other than you having this epiphany that your behaviour was out of line, what changed?”
Agatha took a  breath. “I discussed our… situation with some close friends, and they pointed out to me that I had, rather harshly, misjudged you. When I had accepted that, I knew that I needed to try and smooth things out. Make it right.”

Rio pressed her tongue into her cheek. “We’ll circle back to me making it into your home life in a bit but first I want to know why you want to make it right with me. I’m just another student, I’m not the first person that you’ve spoken to or treated this way. So what’s special about me?”
Agatha’s gaze dipped again, her eyeline going over Rio’s right shoulder to the bookcase behind her. “Because…” She trailed off and closed her eyes for a second, opening them before speaking again. “Because you’re not just another student.” Agatha’s eyes moved back to Rio’s face, but not just to the centre like last time, she looked Rio in the eye. “You’re the first person in a long time who isn’t afraid to, umm, ‘call me out’ I think the phrase is? And I can admit that I didn’t know how to handle that since it very rarely happens.”

The explanation didn’t do much to ease Rio’s confusion, it only gave her more questions. The reason why Agatha had come grovelling was because Rio wouldn’t take any of her shit? No, there had to be more. Agatha wasn’t giving her the full story, she was talking around it. She was purposefully omitting bits and pieces, and for what? To save face? To save herself from the embarrassment of admitting the full truth? Why had Agatha needed to talk about Rio to her friends? How much of her brain did Rio take up and why?
There were so many questions, so many things that Rio needed clarification on but she couldn’t ask them all yet. She would have to bide her time and get her answers slowly because she predicted that the answers wouldn’t be straight forward. This was Agatha after all.

Rio shifted in her chair, sitting further back so that she could rest her back without slouching, and crossed her legs. “Well I’ve got plans to start a movement, give the student body more backbone. So you might have to get used to it.” She gave a half smile and Agatha laughed.
“I’ll keep that in mind.” The silence settled again, neither of them in a comfortable enough place to stop it just yet, until Agatha said, “Do you have anything else you want to ask me?”
‘So many fucking things!’ Rio thought but didn’t voice, instead she said, “I don’t know. Why don’t you tell me some things about you? You know a lot about me and if we’re to build a rapport, it should be equal on both sides.” This was the safest way Rio could think of to try and get information out of Agatha. She didn’t want Agatha to feel like she was being backed into a corner and forced to give explanations to all of the thoughts that were currently swimming around Rio’s head.

Agatha smiled and leaned back, crossing her legs. “Well, my name is Agatha, I’m forty two, I’m a professor at Cambridge Univ-”
“I obviously didn’t mean that.” Rio cut her off with a smile. “I mean like what was it about The Odyssey that made little Agatha want to explore Greek Mythology as a career? Why did you get so bent out of shape when I dog-eared the page instead of using a bookmark? You know, real things.”
“Okay first of all, there is no reason to turn the corner of a page when literally anything can be used as a bookmark. An old receipt, and out of date credit card, a blade of grass if you’re so inclined. If pages and spines get bent through general wear and tear then that’s fine, but to purposefully do it is psychopath behaviour.”
Rio couldn’t help but laugh at how easily Agatha got annoyed at such an insignificant thing. “I’ve been called a psychopath before, but that is by far the stupidest reason I’ve ever been given.”
“As for The Odyssey,” Agatha continued, ignoring Rio’s comment. “All you gave me when I asked you the same question was ‘I read Percy Jackson.’ So if you want tit-for-tat, you’re gonna have to elaborate as well.” A smug smile spread across her lips.

Rio pulled her bottom lip between her teeth and shook her head. Agatha had her with that one. “Touché. My parents got me The Lightning Thief as a late birthday present, because it was released after my birthday, and I became obsessed with the gods. I started researching them on my own time, checking out book after book from the library and when we started learning about it at school I was in my element. I scored top marks on all the tests about it, obviously.”
“Oh, obviously.” Agatha repeated in sarcastic seriousness.
Rio continued. “I’ve lost count of how many times I’ve read the books, but each time a new one was released, I’d get it and re-read them from the start before reading the new one. I did the same with Heroes of Olympus too. And from there it just spiraled really.”

Agatha was still looking directly into Rio’s eyes, smiling softly as she listened. Rio prompted her to tell her side by saying. “Your turn.”
Agatha adjusted the position of the watch on her wrist, breaking eye contact for the first time since it had been established. Her body language made Rio think that she might turn this one down, but she didn’t.
Agatha settled her hands in her lap. “I wasn’t entirely truthful before. My mother didn’t read The Odyssey to me. It was still my introduction to Greek mythology and I was ten when I read it, but I read it of my own accord. I snuck it from the bookshelf in her home office and read it under my covers at night when I was meant to be asleep.” She paused waiting for Rio to interject, but Rio just wanted to let her continue. “I liked the escape that world offered, so I kept hold of it.” She smiled, but it wasn’t full. It looked like it was tinged by the memories that clung to that part of her life.

Rio hadn’t expected that at all. She had figured that Agatha’s story would be similar to hers, and in some ways it was. But Rio’s was a happy one and Agatha’s didn’t seem to hold the same level of childhood joy. She was curious to know more, but now definitely wasn’t the time to ask. Despite what Agatha might have previously assumed, she did know when a question went beyond a simple want to know something and became an unwanted attempt to peek into someone's private life.

Instead of asking anything she just smirked and said, “So we’re both just massive nerds then? Good to know.”
“Oh come on Rio.” Agatha returned the smirk. “We already knew that.” She adjusted herself in the chair for a second and drained her coffee. “What’s next? Hit me.”
Rio thought for a moment, she wanted to keep the conversation light to avoid the risk of it turning sour like so many of their conversations had done in the past. She also wanted to know what the outcome of this meeting would be since it was out of the blue and she still wasn’t a hundred percent on board with Agatha’s reasoning for calling it. “Does asking me to come here today mean that the meetings are back on, or is this a one off?”
Agatha took a breath and ran her hand through her hair. The way that it caught the light coming in through the window made it look almost golden and Rio was nearly mesmerised by it. If Agatha hadn’t spoken, Rio could have happily kept staring at her hair. “We can go back to having regular meetings if you would like, though I wasn’t being dishonest when I said that you didn’t need them anymore. I do have something for us to do today if you’ve got the time. I know that you said you had plans, so it’s up to you.”
Rio had forgotten about the fake plans she had used as her get out of jail free card and made a show of checking her phone. “I hadn’t fully committed to them, so it’s cool.”
Agatha smiled. “Excellent.” She stood up and walked to her desk.

She returned with her laptop and the stack of papers that Rio had noticed when she walked in, and put them in the centre of the coffee table between them. “I thought you could help me mark some essays.”
Rio raised an eyebrow. “You want me to do your work for you?”
Agatha stuttered. “I- Uh- I can see how it would come across that way, but that wasn’t my intention. I thought you might want to try it since we both know that you can do your own work to a high standard, marking someone else's might be fun for- well, maybe not fun. It might be interesting for you. You don’t have to though if you don’t want to, I’m not going to force you.”
Rio tried to suppress the smile that was forming at watching Agatha flounder, but she couldn’t. God damnit, Agatha’s attempt at atoning for her past actions was unintentionally endearing.

Rio leaned forwards to get a closer look at the essay on the top of the pile. “You can stop panicking, I’m in.” She looked back up at Agatha. “Seems like it would be fun. Or would it be interesting?” She smiled and moved her tongue against her cheek.
Agatha rolled her eyes. “Just grab a chunk of them. The marking sheet is on my laptop so you can have that in front of you as you go. Do you want to do the first couple together so you can get a feel for it?”
“You don’t trust me?” Rio asked in mock offense, but she was already standing up to move her chair closer to Agatha. “If I was a weaker person, I’d be offended by that.” She finished as she sat back down. The angle the chair was placed at meant that their knees touched a little bit when Rio sat. It was a tiny thing, there was barely any contact at all, but Rio felt it and she assumed Agatha did too. Neither of them mentioned it, nor did they move their chairs or shuffle themselves away from each other.

They both reached for the top paper at the same time, Rio getting there a fraction of a second before Agatha, which meant that Agatha accidentally grabbed Rio’s hand. They lingered for one second, two seconds, before Agatha quickly pulled her hand away.
“I know I’ve never done this before, Agatha. But I don’t need you to literally hold my hand.” Rio said jokingly as she picked the paper up, testing her use of Agatha’s name rather than her title.
Agatha swallowed, looking slightly uncomfortable. “We’ll see how you feel after you’ve marked this first one.”

Agatha took time to explain the marking sheet to Rio, most of it was pretty self explanatory but she was still grateful that Agatha was covering it in detail. It was better to know exactly how to mark the work to the university’s standard than to wing it and hope that it was okay.
Agatha then went through the first paper with her, pointing everything out and indicating the corresponding guideline on the marking sheet. Of course there were things that they disagreed on, it wouldn’t be an interaction with Agatha if there wasn’t a debate of some sort.

Rio pointed to the marking sheet. “How are you saying that the use of sources is a three? It’s clearly a five!”
“Rio, you can’t be serious. They’ve only got six books and two journals in their bibliography.”
“Okay first of all, they’re in their first year so cut them some slack. Second, they’ve also got four websites which they’ve cross-referenced with the books. And they’ve done it really well.”
If this was how harsh Agatha was when marking the work of her first year students, Rio was having reservations about Agatha reading her full thesis. If she ever got the thing written.

Agatha sighed. “As a source, websites don’t hold the same weight as books. The English Heritage website had the wrong plans for Stonehenge out there for public consumption for so long.”
“It’s the twenty-first century, Agatha. People are going to be using websites now. Just because you had to chisel your college work into a stone tablet, doesn’t mean it’s the right way for everyone to do it.”
Agatha’s eyes went wide and her mouth hung slightly open. Fuck. Rio had spoken without thinking. She definitely, without a shadow of a doubt, should not have said that.
Agatha stared at her for a moment, the surprise at what Rio had said all over her face. Rio’s heart began to pound. Why did she say that? What had possessed her?

Agatha closed her mouth and pursed her lips. “I’ll have you know that I did not ‘chisel my essays into a stone tablet.’” She curled her fingers in air quotes as she repeated Rio’s words back to her. “We had progressed to reed pens and papyrus by then.” She held her stern look for a second longer before a grin started to spread across her face. 

Rio released the breath that she had been holding and turned it into a relieved, breathy laugh. “You’re right, my bad.”
“Shall we split the difference and mark it as a four?”
“I can agree with that.”
Agatha wrote it down on the paper. “If you keep going like this, I’m gonna lose my reputation as a harsh marker.”
“All I’m hearing is that your grade average will go up, which can only reflect well on you. No need to thank me.” Rio smirked.

Agatha calculated the overall percentage score for that essay. “Looks like this one gets fifty seven percent so it’s a 2:2. Do you agree with this, or would you like to dispute it?”
Rio made a show of scrutinising the score, checking the marking sheet a couple times for extra effect. “Nope, looks good to me.”
“I’m so glad. Do you want to do the next one alone?”
“I reckon I could give it a go.”
Agatha handed her the next essay and turned the laptop so that it was facing her, expressing that she had done this enough times by now to not need the marking sheet anymore.

They made their way through a fair few of the papers, significantly lessening the pile that was in front of them. They got into a rhythm with it, occasionally leaning over to check how the other was scoring certain things. Agatha usually tutting and saying, “You’re too nice.” And Rio pointing and saying, “That’s way too harsh.” But they worked at a good speed, making light work of the task.
Neither of them noticed the time passing, too involved in what they were doing. Their knees touched a few more times as one of them was leaning to get a new essay, or one of them shifted slightly to get more comfortable. It became more frequent, not enough that it was obviously a conscious thing but enough that Rio wondered if there was some part of Agatha that was doing it as a subconscious thing. By the time Agatha’s alarm went off, making them both jump, they had stopped bumping their knees and were just resting them against each other.

Agatha pulled out her phone and silenced the alarm. “We’re gonna have to wrap this up and go to the lecture.” She stood up, grabbing her laptop and her bag. “Are you coming?”
Rio nodded and followed Agatha out of her office.

Instead of turning left like she usually would, she turned right with Agatha.
Agatha gave her a confused look. “You don’t have to chaperone me, I know these halls like the back of my hand.”
Rio shrugged. “I noticed that you always walk this way instead of the short way. I wanted to see what was so great about it.”
“The café is what’s so great about it. I can’t teach without caffeine.”
“A perfectly valid reason.”

They walked together to the café, chatting a little bit but not about anything with substance. It was mostly Rio trying to convince Agatha to expand her horizons and order something other than a white coffee.
“What if I buy it for you, then you technically haven’t lost anything?” Rio tried.
“Nope. I’ll still have lost the caffeine hit that I desperately need.”
“Not if you stop being weird and just drink it.”
Agatha rolled her eyes as they approached the café. “If it’ll shut you up, fine.”
Rio moved to join the queue but Agatha stopped her. “We’ll be late if you wait for this.” She gestured to the queue that was only four people long, including Rio. “Just go straight to the front and say it’s for me. They’ll make it quicker.”
Rio’s brows shot up. “You’ve scared them into prioritising your order, haven’t you?”
Agatha lifted her shoulders in a shrug. “I like the efficiency.”

Rio snorted in incredulity but made her way to the collection counter all the same. She gave the barista the order and they looked scared. “Prof- Professor Harkness wants an iced caramel latte?” They stammered out.
Rio nodded. “Yep. With cream on top.”
The barista shuffled awkwardly. “She definitely doesn’t want her white coffee? It’s already done.”
“She’ll take both, but we’re kinda in a rush. Lectures to teach and all.”
The barista nodded and got to work, causing the other people in the queue to roll their eyes. One person mumbled, “We all have places to be, why is she so special?”
Rio would never abuse this kind of power, but she had to admit that it felt good.

Rio paid and the coffees were ready and placed into a cup holder in no time at all. She took them back over to Agatha and pointed to the white coffee. “This was already made and I think that barista would have cried if I told them that you didn’t want it, so you can have it in case your tastebuds are too delicate for a fun drink.” She smiled smugly and they set off to the lecture hall.

They split the coffees up and walked into the room, Agatha going left towards the desk to set up her laptop, and Rio turning right and climbing the seating bank to the spot Billy had saved for her. When she sat down he turned to her and whispered, “That’s not the kind of coffee I expected Agatha to drink.”
She looked towards Agatha who was unwrapping her straw and sliding it into the cup. “Turns out it is when she’s not the one paying.”
Agatha looked at Rio as she took her first sip and Rio had to stifle her laugh when she saw the surprise on Agatha’s face. She liked the drink. She actually liked the fucking drink. She was trying her best to hide it, but the speed that she went in for the second sip gave it all away.
Rio gave a cocky smile and tilted her head in a silent ‘told you so’ which made Agatha roll her eyes and set the coffee down on the desk.

Rio faintly heard Billy speak next to her, but she was too caught up in her silent exchange with Agatha to hear him. “Huh?” She asked.
“I said, why did you buy her a coffee? Are you moving on from second years to the staff now?”
She dipped her brows in confusion. “What are on about?”
He gave her a look that said, ‘you know exactly what I mean’ but continued out loud anyway. “Oh come on, don’t act coy. Me and Eddie heard you and Taylor after the bonfire. Sounded like she really enjoyed herself.”
“All women enjoy themselves with me Billy. It’s just a fact. Ask your mother.” She wiggled her eyebrows at him and he rolled his eyes.
Alice joined in. “You slept with Taylor? Nice.” She held up her hand for a hi-five, which Rio returned, reaching across Billy.
He moved both of their arms down as Agatha started clearing her throat to get the class's attention.

When everyone’s attention was on Agatha, she started talking. “I’m sure you’ll all be pleased to know that I have started marking your essays and you should get the results by the end of the month, so keep an eye on your emails. I know some of you might not be happy with the marking,” She passed her gaze over Rio, a smile tugging at the corner of her mouth. “So please utilise my office hours if you wish to discuss it at all.”
With that out of the way, she started the lecture. 

__________

During the lecture Rio started feeling an itch that needed to be scratched in a specific way. It came out of nowhere but she put it down to being due on her period. She always got randomly horny around her period.
After the lecture Rio messaged Wanda.

Rio: Are you free tonight?

The reply came quickly which meant Wanda was either on a break or was using her phone during a lecture.

Wanda: I’ll be home around 5:30 so come round any time after that

Rio didn’t reply, she didn’t need to. She just needed to last until band practise was over. And somehow, she managed. It was rough, she strongly considered not showing up to the music room and making her excuses later, but she stayed strong and saved herself for when she was at Wanda’s house.
She practically sprinted from the practise and got to Wanda's house just after seven and rapidly knocked on the door which Wanda opened within a few seconds. She’d been waiting for her.
Wanda grabbed Rio by the shirt and pulled her inside, shutting the door by pushing Rio against it and immediately kissing her. She undid Rio’s jeans without breaking the kiss and pushed her hand beneath the waistband but over her underwear, feeling the wetness that Rio knew was between her thighs. “Damn,” Wanda whispered against her lips. “How long have you been like this?”
Rio gave Wanda’s bottom lip a gentle tug between her teeth. “Since I messaged you.”
Wanda pulled back enough to look in Rio’s eyes. “You’ve been this wet all that time? And during school too?” She tutted. “Naughty.”
Rio didn’t hate teasing by any means, but right now she needed a release. She wove her hand into Wanda’s hair and pulled it back sharply, making Wanda gasp at the movement. She dropped her voice low, her lust adding a husk to it. “Stop talking and do something about it then.” Rio let go of her hair.
Wanda smiled, the look in her eyes showing exactly what Rio wanted to see. She twisted her hand, grabbed the waistband of Rio’s jeans and began leading her up the stairs. When they got over the threshold of the bedroom, Wanda turned, pushed Rio’s jacket off of her shoulders and lifted her shirt over her head before walking her backwards towards the wall. She told Rio to take her jeans off and sank to her knees, following with Rio’s underwear kissing down her legs as she went. When the fabric was out of the way, she picked Rio’s leg up and put it over her shoulder giving a final kiss to Rio’s inner thigh before she put her tongue where Rio needed it.

It didn’t take long before Rio was close. The leg that was over Wanda’s shoulder was shaking and her other leg was threatening to give out under the weight of her orgasm. Neither of them heard the front door open, but Wanda heard the voice that carried up the stairs. She pulled away from between Rio’s thighs. “Oh fuck.”
Rio whimpered at the loss of contact. “No no no, please don’t stop.” She tried to push Wanda’s head back down but Wanda resisted, hurriedly standing up. “Wha-” Rio started but Wanda cut her off.
“Rio, it's my son!” She said in a harsh whisper, and then Rio heard it.

“Mum, are you home?” A voice that sounded eerily familiar came from downstairs. “I just needed to bring some washing because my bonfire clothes were starting to make my room smell really bad.”
Shit. Rio started to quickly scramble around, grabbing her clothes and putting them back on as quickly as she could. Wanda started to leave the room but Rio grabbed her arm. “Wait!” She whispered. “What should I do? Should I hide?”
“I don’t know how long he’s gonna be here for. Just make up an excuse for being here and leave. I'll let you know when he’s gone and you can come back.” Wanda replied and headed downstairs. Rio heard both of them speaking and stood dumbfounded for a minute.

Why had Wanda phrased it that way? ‘Just make up an excuse and leave.’ Was her son someone that Rio knew? She did recognise the voice, but he could have been in any of the lectures that Rio had attended. Or she could have even heard his voice in the library, at the bar, he could have been one of the guys from Halloween.
She threw her top on and slowly started down the stairs. Maybe his back would be to the hall and she could sneak past them.

She continued to creep down the stairs, avoiding the step that she had come to learn creaked if stood on, catching the end of the conversation.
“... firework display was so good! I don’t think I’ve seen rockets that big before.” The boy finished telling Wanda.
“I’m glad you had a good time sweetheart. Did your friends enjoy it too?” She heard Wanda say from the kitchen.
“Yeah they did. Though I think a couple of them enjoyed each other's company more than the bonfire.”
“Oh? The fireworks worked their magic on someone then?”
He laughed. “They sure did. It was Taylor and… Rio?”

Rio stopped in her tracks and turned in the direction of his voice. No. There's no way.
He was looking directly at her, and she him. “Billy?”
Wanda was standing behind him looking apologetic. She had known this whole time that Rio was one of her son’s friends.
How many times had he spoken to Wanda about her and Wanda had just nodded along?
He was about to fucking tell her that she slept with Taylor – not that it was an issue since she and Wanda were not in a relationship. But still, it felt wrong coming from her son.

Billy looked thoroughly confused and Rio no doubt looked like a deer in the headlights. “What are you doing here?” He asked.
It was a perfectly reasonable question for him to ask but Rio’s brain was struggling to process it. She looked over his shoulder to Wanda who just mouthed, “Say something.”
Big fucking help. “I was just borrowing a book that Wand- uh- your mom has. For my thesis.” She choked out as her brain was still lagging behind.
It was lagging very far behind since she didn’t have a fucking book in her hands. Wanda jumped to her rescue. “Turns out that I don’t have it. It must be at your dad’s.” She said to Billy. A beat passed before she cleared her throat. “I’ll let you know when I have it and bring it in for you. It’ll either be tomorrow or Friday.”
Rio nodded. “Uh yeah, that’s cool with me. See you later Billy.” She gave them both an awkward wave and left as quickly as she could. Choosing to sit on the wall outside to put her shoes on rather than doing it in the house.

She sat there and sighed heavily, hanging her head. That could not have gone any worse. She rubbed the back of her neck and noticed something about her shirt. It was on inside out.
That wasn’t noticeable, right? Sure the back of the embroidered logo was obviously facing outwards and looked like a tangled mess instead of the neat pattern that it should have been, and the label was at the front. But he didn’t notice that, right?
She ran her hands down her face and rested them on her chest where she could feel her heart beating so fast that it would definitely concern a doctor.

FUCK. 

Chapter End Notes

Am I using songs from setlists that I've played in the past?
Am I also using my own trauma from Ring of Fire as inspiration for Rio's?
You cannot prove either of those things!

Also, I wrote my dissertation on Stonehenge so Agatha's annoyance at English Heritage for publishing incorrect plans is actually very valid

Chapter 17: Agatha

Chapter Notes

Take a shot every time I say coffee
You'd die

Edit just to say 10,000 hits is insane
Thank you all so much for reading!

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Agatha was on her way to her Thursday morning lecture via the café, as usual. She skipped the line and went straight to the front, as usual. The barista looked terrified, as usual. Everything was normal.
Until the barista brought out two coffees.
“Good morning, Professor Harkness.” They nervously started. “We, umm, we weren't sure if, uh-”
Agatha rolled her eyes. “Hurry up, I don’t have all day.” She snapped.
The barista swallowed. “Since you changed your order yesterday we weren’t sure which we should prepare for you, so we made both.” 

They put two coffees in front of her. One was her usual white coffee with two sugars already stirred in, and the other was the iced coffee that Rio had bought for her the day before.
She looked at both of the drinks considering her options.
She could just take both and have both, there were no downsides to that.
She could take both and give the iced one to Rio as repayment for yesterday, but that would mean that she didn’t also get to have the iced one – and she really wanted the iced one.
She could get them to make a second iced coffee so that she could give one to Rio whilst also keeping one for herself. Everyone was a winner in that scenario.
But there was one problem with that. She had no guarantee that she would see Rio today.

It was a Thursday and they had no meetings scheduled – they hadn’t even arrived at a conclusion as to whether they would go back to having weekly meetings. Just because they’d had one meeting that didn’t mean that Rio would turn up to her lecture today and accept a coffee from her. This was a complicated, delicate thing that needed to be handled correctly.

“Professor Harkness?” The barista’s voice brought her out of her thoughts.
She checked her watch. There was enough time to get a second coffee made and still make it to her lecture on time.
Fuck it.
“The iced thing. Make a second one, and do it quickly.”
The barista nodded and got to work. Agatha would just have to hope that Rio would attend the lecture.

As she waited she tried desperately to not think about the fact that this was the first time in a long time that she had factored another person into a decision that she had made. If she had just been given her white coffee, she wouldn’t have given it a second thought. The drink that Rio had begged her to try wouldn’t have even entered her mind. She could have gone about her day the same as she did every day but that fucking barista had to ruin it by putting both drinks in front of her and forcing her to think about it.

She paid for the drinks and set off to the lecture hall, coming up with a contingency plan. If Rio wasn’t there then she could give the second coffee to Billy and that would sort out the three-coffees-problem that she was currently having.
She got to the lecture hall as students were still filtering in, walking straight to her table and starting to set up. She scanned the seating bank finding Billy and Alice in the middle where they usually sat, but Rio wasn’t there. There wasn’t a spare seat next to Billy either. That had to  mean that Rio wasn’t coming since he always saved a space for her. She felt a pang of disappointment at knowing that Rio wasn’t going to be there but pulled out her phone to text Billy to come to the front. She had to think of a subtle way to give him the drink so that it didn’t look like he was getting special treatment and cause a rumour to spark. The last thing she or Billy needed were more rumours flying around the department.

She was about to press send when, out of the corner of her eye, she saw the familiar dark waves and leather jacket. Rio had walked in.
But wait, if Rio was here then why had Billy not saved her a seat like he usually did? Had Rio told him that she wasn’t coming and then changed her mind at the last minute?
Fuck, none of that mattered right now. She put her phone down and called Rio’s name. 

Rio turned to her, briefly looking confused before walking over and holding up her hands. “Whatever it is, I swear I didn’t do it.” 

Agatha couldn’t stop the smile that played on her lips. God damnit. “Well, that remains to be seen. Are you sure?”
Rio nodded. “Totally. It was, uhh, that guy.” She motioned over her shoulder to a random person and gave an innocent smile.
Agatha looked in the direction that she was pointing at a now confused and slightly worried looking first year who had just taken his seat, and laughed softly. “I appreciate your honesty. And as a token of my appreciation, I want to give you this.” She held up the iced caramel latte and its accompanying straw.

Rio’s eyebrows raised. “You bought me a coffee?”
“Repayment for yesterday.” Agatha tried her best to sound nonchalant.
“I don’t need repaying, that was a gift.”
Agatha started to put the drink down. “Oh. Well if you don’t want it…”
Rio quickly reached out and took the coffee from her. “Let’s not be hasty now. I said I didn’t need repaying. Not that I didn’t want the coffee.” She took the lid off and dipped her finger into the cream.
Agatha tried to look away, she really did, but her eyes couldn’t stop following the motion of Rio putting her finger into her mouth and sucking the cream off of it again.

Rio smiled smugly. “Hmm. Tastes even better when it’s free.” She put the lid back on and picked up the straw.
Agatha started to speak but her throat had suddenly gone dry so it came out as a squeak at first, which made Rio chuckle. She cleared her throat and tried again. “I’m glad. Go find a seat please. I have work to do.”
Rio saluted her and said, “Aye aye captain.” Before walking up the seating bank and dropping herself into a free seat in the back.

The start of the lecture was a little shaky because it took Agatha a hot minute to get her head back to where it needed to be, but she soon found her stride again and delivered her lecture without any issues.

When the lecture was over Agatha noticed Alice and Billy leave without sparing a look in Rio’s direction which she thought was strange. They seemed to be rather close until today so something must have happened. She’d have to ask him at some point.
When Rio was on her way out she stopped by Agatha’s desk. Agatha, trying to appear indifferent, didn’t look up. “If you’re here for another coffee I’m afraid you’ll be disappointed. I only bought us one each.”
“It hurts me that you think I only stick around because you buy me expensive presents.” Rio said in feigned offence. “Though if you were to bring me a diamond necklace tomorrow, I wouldn’t turn it down.”
Agatha finally looked up because she had to roll her eyes at that. She was sure that if there was a category in the Guinness Book Of World Records for the strongest eye muscles, she would win it in a landslide with how often she rolled her eyes at the silly things that Rio said.

When she looked at Rio’s face, Rio was wearing the smirk that Agatha had come to have a love-hate relationship with. “You’ve a long way to go before you’re at diamond necklace level. You’ll be lucky to get a second coffee.”
Rio breathed out a laugh. “I can wait, don’t worry. I actually came to ask you if the meetings are back on. We never decided yesterday.”
“Like I said, that’s up to you. In terms of talking about your PhD, we don’t need to do it as often. You’re very self-sufficient in that regard.”
Rio quirked an eyebrow. “I’m sensing a but.”
“But,” Agatha continued. “If you wanted to continue helping me mark my essays, that would be greatly appreciated.”
Rio chewed on her bottom lip as she thought. “I suppose I could do that. Wednesday then?”
“I have a couple of hours free now if you wanted?” Agatha said, probably too quickly. Was that too desperate? Was Rio going to be put off by it? Shit save it! “Or you can just check my schedule and pick a day and time. If I have an hour or more between lectures, those are the best times.” Crushed it.

Rio looked at the clock on the wall behind Agatha and then towards the door before looking back at Agatha. “I have something to do right now, I’m not sure how long it will take. If I can be at your office with enough time left then I will, but I can’t make any promises today.”
Agatha swallowed down the disappointment she felt beginning to rise. “That’s fine, there’s no pressure.” She returned her attention to gathering her things. “I’ll see you at some point.”
“For sure.” Rio replied before making her way to the door and leaving the room.

As soon as the door was closed Agatha let herself drop into the chair behind her. She rubbed her eyes then sighed and stared at the ceiling, not moving until the lights started to make her vision swim. Talking to Rio was harder now that she was acutely aware of the fact that she liked her. She was able to live in blissful ignorance before Jen and Lilia had forced to reckon with her feelings, but now it was torture.
She wished that she still had the confidence that her younger self had once possessed. Twenty year old Agatha would have had Rio by now, in every sense. But forty two year old Agatha was struggling to talk to her for fear of going too far and scaring her off.
When did talking to women become this hard?

Agatha eventually managed to pick herself up out of the chair, pack her things away and leave the lecture hall. She had no idea how long she had been sitting there for, nor did she want to know. She had spent too much time lately staring into space and thinking about Rio. She needed to get her shit together.
Since she didn’t know how much time she had left, she decided to take the lift up to her office instead of the stairs.

The reason that she usually gave people for taking the stairs was that the stairs were healthier. It was a good way to get her steps in and make sure she was still getting some exercise in her day. The truth, however, was that taking the lift meant that she had to walk past Wanda’s office and she had a very good reason to avoid going that way. But today she decided to brave it.
She regretted it almost instantly when the door to Wanda’s office started to open.
Agatha practically threw herself around the corner diagonally across from it, hiding from view. She did not, under any circumstances, want an accidental run in with her ex. She had managed to avoid it for the better part of two and a half years and she wasn't going to add a blemish to that spotless record now. She waited for Wanda to leave but was surprised when it wasn’t Wanda that she saw.

Rio stepped out from the office and closed the door gently behind her, walking in the direction of the lift. Agatha watched her go, her mind swimming with questions.
Why was Rio in Wanda’s office?
How had Rio and Wanda met?
Was this the first time Rio had been to Wanda’s office?
What had they been talking about?
Had Wanda spun Rio a tall tale about Agatha?
Was Rio's head now filled with all of Wanda’s lies?
Did Rio know that Wanda was Billy’s mother?
Was this just another one of Wanda’s games?
There were so many things she wanted, no, needed to know.

Agatha got back into her office and her head was spinning, that seemed to be the theme of her day so far. It had been a long time since a woman had caused this many spirals in such a short amount of time. She hadn’t even felt like this with Wanda. Sure there were times when she was overthinking things whilst she was getting to know Wanda in the early stages of their relationship, but nothing on this level. Rio Vidal had knocked her for six and it had left her floundering.

Her phone pinged with an email notification.

Agatha,

My thing went longer than expected so I won’t be able to make it today, sorry.
I’ll be there tomorrow though!

Sorry again
Rio

Agatha had expected as much since Rio had immediately gone towards the lifts after leaving Wanda’s office, but she still didn’t know how to feel about Wanda being Rio’s aforementioned ‘thing’.
What did Rio even mean by ‘thing’? What were they doing? Did this have something to do with Billy not saving her a seat today?
She knew she should probably reply to Rio’s email but she didn’t know what to say. She spent a few minutes thinking about her response before she just gave up and typed the first thing that came to her head.

Rio,

No worries, see you tomorrow!

Agatha

She pressed send before she thought about it too much and found something to keep her busy until her alarm went off, prompting her to go to her next lecture.

__________

Agatha was sitting in her office with the pile of essays in the middle of the coffee table and the marking sheet already open on her laptop. If Rio had looked up her schedule then she would know that Agatha had two hours of free time starting now, which meant that Rio could show up at any minute.
Agatha had thought about buying them both a drink on her way back from her morning lecture but decided against it. Buying Rio a coffee two days in a row would be strange. Rio bought her one on Wednesday and she bought one for Rio on Thursday. They were even now, no need to turn this into a who-owes-who situation.

After a few minutes there was a knock at her door and she waited a second before saying, “You may enter.” 
 The door opened and Rio breezed in with an easy smile on her face.
“Good afternoon.” Rio greeted her. “I hear that you need someone to show you how to properly mark essays.”
Rio casually sat in her usual chair, pleased with her joke.
Agatha played along. “Oh yes please. I’m so glad you’re here, Professor Vidal.”
Rio’s smile widened, showing her teeth a little bit. “Professor Vidal? I like the sound of that.” She leaned back resting her elbows on the arm rests. “I’m definitely gonna come for your job now.”
Agatha smiled and pressed her tongue against her cheek. “If you think you’re good enough then by all means.” She leaned back, mimicking Rio’s current posture. “I’ll happily take an early retirement.”
Rio scoffed. “You professors are so lazy.” She said sarcastically.
“Exactly. Why do you think I’ve got you marking my coursework for me?”
Rio’s eyes went comically wide and she pointed her finger in Agatha’s direction. “I knew it! You’re just using me!”
Agatha smirked. “I’m glad we’re finally on the same page.”

Rio shook her head and reached forwards, grabbing a section of the papers in front of her and one of the red biro pens that Agatha had put next to them.
Agatha liked all of her markings to be in red ink, it looked more professional to her. More final. She had expected Rio to make a quip about it on Wednesday, but she had just let it go.
Rio leant back in her chair again, getting comfortable, but she sat back up again. “Oh I almost forgot.” She said as she reached into her bag and pulled out a medium sized brown paper bag and put it on the coffee table.
Agatha furrowed her brows. “What’s this?”
“Pastries.” Rio casually replied as she took four different pastries out of the bag and put them on top of it.
Agatha’s confusion deepened. “You bought us pastries?”
“Yeah.” Rio said as she was wiping the crumbs from her fingers. “It’s lunch time. It’s also why I was a little bit late. Without you there to glare at them their sense of urgency is lacking.” She picked up what looked like a cinnamon swirl and settled back into her seat.

Agatha looked at the pastries sceptically, trying to process exactly why Rio had bought them. It was lunch time but why had she bought four? She could have just got them one each, but she bought four different ones.
First coffee, now pastries. What did this mean?
“They’re not poisoned, Agatha.” Rio’s voice snapped her out of her thoughts and she held up her hand with her thumb and little finger tucked in. “Scouts honour.”
Agatha managed a smile and said, “Well my food tester isn’t here so I’m gonna have to take your word for it.” She picked up a pain au chocolat and took a small bite.
Rio watched her. “Well?”
 Agatha held up her finger. “Give it a minute.” She waited for a bit before saying, “Nope, I think we’re good.”
Rio rolled her eyes and went back to her stack of essays, mumbling. “See? Dionysus.”
Agatha laughed softly and picked up her own section of the papers.

The two of them worked in comfortable silence. They occasionally read sentences out to each other that impressed them in both negative and positive ways, and Rio sometimes asked Agatha to double check the score she’d given the essay. They made light work of the pastries, polishing them off within the first hour and Rio made a comment about needing to buy more next time – which of course made Agatha’s thoughts run a mile a minute.

Next time implied that Rio wanted to do this again. Next time implied that Rio enjoyed spending time with Agatha. Is there a possibility that Rio would want to spend time with her off campus? Would she agree to a date-type scenario?
Agatha was nowhere near asking her, but the fact that there was the smallest chance that Rio would want to do it made her chest warm slightly.

“Agatha!” She was brought out of her reverie by Rio loudly saying her name.
“Hmm?” She hummed as she looked up at Rio.
“Damn, you’re really into that one. I’ve been saying your name for like a full minute.”
Agatha cleared her throat. “Uh yeah, sorry. These sentences are really poorly written, I was trying to make sense of it.”
“Well now that I’ve got you, will you give this a look over for me? The score seems too high for how I’ve marked it.” Rio handed her the essay that she had just marked and she started adding it together to calculate the percentage mark.

“Rio, you’ve given two of these sections a six. The highest it can go is five, and these are definitely not fives. And I can’t tell if this is a two or a three.”
“What? No I haven’t.” Rio stood up out of her chair and walked round to Agatha. “Show me.”
Agatha pointed at the obvious 6 that was written in the margin. “It’s right there.”
Rio leaned down over Agatha’s shoulder to get a closer look. As she did, some of her hair fell forward and brushed Agatha’s neck. It was light, a featherweight thing, but Agatha felt the tingle that it shot down her spine. This was the closest they had ever been in each other’s proximity and Agatha was very aware of it. She breathed in deep through her nose to steady herself and the once scentless air had notes of the earth that tickled her senses. She could faintly smell pine leaves and a slightly woody undertone. Was it cedarwood or sandalwood?
Before she could stop herself, she took another breath through her nose. Definitely sandalwood.

She was about to take another breath, suddenly needing to breathe as much of this scent in as she could when she realised what she was doing. She was sniffing Rio. She was literally sniffing Rio. What the fuck was wrong with her?
Thankfully Rio didn’t seem to notice. “Oh I see what I’ve done.” She reached out and pointed at the numbers. “These are fives but I’ve written them weirdly and when I was adding it up, I thought they were sixes.” She flipped to the next page while the essay was still in Agatha’s hand. “Yep those are twos but I read them as threes.” She straightened up and took the paper from Agatha, sitting back down in her chair and recalculating the score. “Ahh yeah. This makes more sense.”

Agatha was still in her pine and sandalwood infused daze, barely registering a word that Rio was saying. Her body was on autopilot, picking up the paper that was in her lap. Her eyes scanning the page but not taking in any of the words that were written on it.
What was it about the woman sitting across from her that made her lose any and all sense of herself when she was around her?
She really needed to get her shit together.

__________ 

Agatha’s kitchen was a mess. There was sauce on the kitchen counter, a piece of spaghetti stuck to the wall, and the skins of the many cloves of garlic that she had added to the dish were littering the floor.
She wiped her hands on her already stained apron and went to open the door to let Lilia and Jen in.
Jen was covering her eyes with her hand saying, “If I can’t see it, I can pretend that the mess doesn’t exist.”
Lilia patted Agatha on the shoulder. “Ignore her, she’s being dramatic. I’ll help you clean up.”
“I always ignore her, don’t worry.” Agatha stepped to the side to let them both in.

All three of them filed into the kitchen and Jen spread her fingers slightly to survey the damage. “Oh, it’s not as bad as I ex-” She was cut off by the garlic skins crunching under her feet and scrunched her face in disgust. “I stand corrected.”
Lilia handed her a dustpan and brush. “Oh stop complaining Jennifer and make yourself useful.”
The two of them were well aware of the fact that when it was Agatha’s turn to cook, they would have to come round slightly early to help with the clean up before they ate. It was part of the routine they had all established when these weekly dinners started. It didn’t stop Jen from making a comment about it every single time though, but Agatha liked the consistency.

Agatha tried to subtly take the spaghetti off the wall and throw it in the bin without either of them noticing but Lilia clocked her. She didn’t say anything, she just smiled and shook her head. Lilia had told her, quite a few times now, that she didn’t have to throw the spaghetti at the wall to test if it was cooked, she could simply try a piece. Agatha was a creature of habit though, so she would continue to do it.

Within ten minutes the kitchen was cleaned, the food was plated and they were sitting around the dining room table enjoying the carbonara that Agatha had prepared.
“Your process might be sending me into an early grave, but I can’t deny that the results are always immaculate.” Jen said around her mouthful of food.
“Thanks. My mother might have messed me up beyond repair, but at least she taught me how to cook.” Agatha said after taking a sip of her wine. Out of the corner of her eye she saw Lilia make a face. The face she makes when she has something to say but is trying to hide it. The woman might be a whizz at reading people and not giving anything away herself, but after all these years Agatha had managed to spot a few tells. Well, the tells that Lilia allowed her to spot anyway. Agatha sighed. “Go on Lilia. Share with the class.”

Lilia took a drink of her wine and put the glass down again. “I just don’t believe that anybody is beyond repair, that’s all.”
“Well I am and I like it that way. So don’t even think about it.” Agatha said in mock seriousness, a smile playing at the corners of her mouth.
 Lilia pretended to be offended. “Think about what? Doing a deep dive into your childhood and finally getting answers for…” She made a sweeping gesture over Agatha’s form. “This.”
Agatha lifted an eyebrow. “You just gestured to all of me.”
“Did I? Hmm, how strange.” Lilia said, smiling into her wine glass as she took another sip.

The conversation stayed light as they ate their meal and the accompanying dessert that Agatha had bought. She was a little on edge, waiting for one of them to bring up Rio. A topic she both did and didn’t want to cover.
She didn’t want to cover it because nothing had happened. Aside from calling each other by their first names and Agatha basically giving Rio permission to show up to her office as and when she wanted, she had made no progress. There was nothing to report.
But she did want to cover it because talking things out with Lilia before had actually helped a bit. Not that she would tell her that. She needed to maintain some of her pride.

The trio moved into the living room with a fresh bottle of wine and settled into their usual seating arrangement. They continued talking, though not about anything in particular, and Agatha began to feel comfortable in the fact that neither of her friends was bringing up Rio.
The comfort didn’t last long because Jen just had to ask. “Oh what’s going on with Rio? Any developments there?”
Agatha looked down, suddenly very interested in the deep red liquid in her wine glass. 
 Jen snorted softly. “If you don’t answer, Lilia will do it for you.”

Maybe that would be easier. Having someone else voice her thoughts for her was preferable at this point, but she was an adult who could do it herself.
“There’s nothing to report really.” Agatha said after taking a sip of her wine and looking back up at Lilia and Jen.
She saw the corners of Lilia’s mouth twitch, but Lilia didn’t say anything. If Agatha didn’t know any better she would think that Lilia could actually hear people’s thoughts. 
 Instead it was Jen that pressed for more information. “Explain ‘really’.”
Agatha sighed, though not out of annoyance. It was more out of the lack of information that she had to give them. “We’ve only spoken a handful of times. She’s helped me mark some essays. She bought me a coffee, I bought her a coffee. She bought us some pastries to share because we were working through lunch. Nothing of note.” She listed the mundane things that she had shared with Rio over the last few days. “I wish that I had more to bring to the council but alas, I do not.” She had another drink of her wine. The progress really had been slow, but Rio was talking to her so she would take what she could get.

Lilia finally spoke up. “Despite what you might think, that is something to report.”
Agatha furrowed her brows. “How?”
“Because you’ve re-established contact. You’ve found something that the two of you can do together that still gives you time to talk and get to know each other. You’ve bought each other things. It might only be coffee and pastries but it’s still something. These small acts will add up, you just need to be consistent.”
“You could casually drop into conversation that you have access to the Harkness fortune. I bet that would speed things along.” Jen mumbled around her glass.
Agatha rolled her eyes. “Yes, because buying Rio’s affection would be a stellar thing to do.” She said, the words dripping in sarcasm.
“It couldn’t hurt is all I’m saying.”

Agatha kept her financial situation very close to her chest. She had only told Lilia and Jen when she knew that she could trust them. She hadn’t even told Wanda. Whenever Wanda questioned how she could afford the things that she bought her and Billy, Agatha brushed it off with a comment about being good at saving and budgeting. She had been planning on telling Wanda after they were married, but she never got the chance.
It wasn’t something that she flaunted, the money had come from her mother so she never really saw it as something that she had. It was just a product of her mother dying, and some expensive lawyers to make sure that her mother didn’t screw her over in her will. Her half-sister had gotten a small portion of it but Agatha got the bulk.
As soon as she’d received the money she had put it straight into a savings account, vowing to only use it on things that would make her mother spin in her grave – like gifts for her long-term girlfriend, an engagement ring for the woman she was planning to marry, or donating to LGBTQ+ charities.
She didn’t like to use it on things like cars or houses because it felt like her mother was the one buying those things for her and, even though the woman had been dead for twenty two years, she never wanted to feel like she was indebted to her mother. If she dipped into it for any of those things, it was out of necessity.

Lilia gave Jen a vexed look. “Once again, Agatha, I’m going to tell you to ignore our dear Jennifer.”
Agatha smiled. “Always.”
Jen rolled her eyes. “Well what would you suggest is the next step for our loveable but useless lesbian?” She asked Lilia.
“I resent that!” Agatha jumped in. “I’m very good at being a lesbian thank you very much.”
“Not currently.” Jen smirked.
 Lilia laughed. “Actually, from what I know about how lesbians operate in the dating scene, pining after a woman and doing nothing about it is akin to asking her to marry and start a family with you.”
“Very true.” Jen raised her glass to Lilia who mimicked the movement, but they were too far away to actually knock them together so they just took a sip in unison.

Agatha huffed out disgruntled noise. “Neither of you are any help.”
 Lilia put her now empty glass down on the end table that was next to her chair. “Jen does have a point though. It’s great that you’ve got to a place where you can talk to Rio in a more casual way, but you can’t stay there forever. Other than when you’re face to face, how do you communicate?”
“We email.” Agatha stated matter-of-factly. How else did Lilia expect them to talk? Did she think Agatha sent a telegram to wherever Rio was at the moment she wanted to contact her?
“So do you think you could segue into texting maybe? Remove some more of the formality?”
Oh. That made more sense than a telegram. God, she was bad at this.
The surprise at the simple suggestion must have been evident on Agatha’s face because Jen piped up again. “I swear you weren’t this useless with Wanda.”
Agatha turned to face Jen. “That’s because Wanda made all of these moves. She was the one who asked for my number and then asked me on a date.”
Jen started refilling her glass. “You were the one who got on one knee though. You can make these leaps.”
Lilia held her glass out for Jen to fill and Agatha knocked the rest of hers back before following suit. “And we all know how well that ended.”

Glass freshly filled, Lilia settled back into her chair, fixing her eyes on Agatha. “You can’t keep using your past experiences as an excuse to run from future ones. Think of a way to give Rio your number and then work on a way to meet her somewhere that isn’t your office or a lecture hall.”
Agatha wished that it was that simple. She wished that could just ask Rio out without any fear of potential repercussions. If Rio wasn’t a student, if Rio wasn’t her student, then it would be easier. She had already had one office romance go bad and was still dealing with the fallout, she couldn’t stomach another. If she, or moreover Lilia, had read the situation wrong and these were unwanted advances on Rio's side, then Rio could report her and end her career. There were more things to consider than just ‘will she say yes to a date?’

“You’re gonna give yourself a headache if you keep spiralling like that.” Jen said softly.
Agatha sighed quietly. “I know. It’s just hard not to get bogged down by the negatives.”
Jen gave a gentle nod and Lilia said, “We can work this out together, but you will need to move forward at some point.”
Agatha nodded and smiled, though it didn't reach her eyes.
A moment passed before Jen broke the silence. “Oh!” She said loudly, making both Agatha and Lilia jump. She smiled sheepishly before continuing. “Sorry, I didn’t realise I’d be that loud. You have that end of year thing right? In December?”
“Yeah?” Agatha questioned her sceptically.
“Ask Rio to go with you!”
Lilia’s expression morphed from the shock of Jen’s loud exclamation to one of excitement at the idea. “That’s a good idea actually. It’s still affiliated with the university so it’s not too far removed to be an out-of-left-field suggestion, but it’s also off campus so you won’t have the hang-ups that come with that.” She looked at Jen. “Well done, Jennifer.”
Jen gave a smug smile at the praise.

Agatha pointed in Jen’s direction but kept looking at Lilia. “What happened to ignoring her?”
“That’s only when she’s commenting on the state of your kitchen or suggesting that you should become a sugar daddy. She’s right about this and you can’t deny it.”
Agatha took a healthy gulp of her wine. “You both know that I don’t attend those events and the reasons why.”
“Maybe it’s time to move on.” Lilia said gently.
Agatha narrowed her eyes and carefully put her wine glass down, centring it perfectly on the coaster. She was putting a great amount of effort into not snapping her response at Lilia. “I have told you the hell that my life was turned into when Wanda manipulated every member of staff in our department, including the cleaners.” She spoke slowly, making sure to keep her voice steady, controlled. “I was cast out. Removed from text chains and group chats without a second thought. I was purposefully left out of department events, birthday dinners, bottomless brunches, and you want me to just move on ?”
The suggestion made Agatha’s blood boil.

Jen cleared her throat and looked scared when Agatha’s gaze whipped her way. She took a moment to choose her words. “You can’t take steps forward if you’re always looking behind you, Agatha. What Wanda did was horrible and the fact that she turned everyone against you makes me so angry on your behalf, but you can’t let it rule your life. It’s time that you reclaim some of the things she took from you. There are no written rules that say you can’t attend the end of year ball. Go with Rio and have some fun.” She said in earnest, her voice and eyes soft.
“You can’t have a future if you’re stuck living in the past.” Lilia added on.

Agatha knew that they were right. She knew that this was something they’d been wanting to say for a long time, and she couldn’t deny that they had a point . She could hold a grudge for as long as she wanted but it wouldn’t achieve anything. It wouldn’t erase anything that had happened and it wouldn’t aid her in moving past it – which she did want to do. She could wait a lifetime for people to come to her and apologise for the way that they treated her. She could live in fear of what people would say if she went to the ball, or she could face it head on like an adult.
She looked down at her hands momentarily before taking a long breath in through her nose and exhaling through her mouth. “Okay.”

Jen raised an eyebrow. “Okay?”
“Okay.” Agatha repeated. “I’ll think of a way to give Rio my number, and I’ll ask her to go to the end of year thing with me. I’m not sure how though. I don’t think ‘sorry I was weird, I wanted you’ would be the best course of action.” She gave a light chuckle.
Lilia tilted her head. “You never know.”
All three of them laughed and finished the bottle of wine, moving the conversation to a different topic to close out the evening.

__________

Agatha strode into the lecture hall on Monday morning and cast an eye over the students waiting for her to begin the lecture. Billy, Alice and Rio were all sitting together in the centre, the anomaly of Thursday morning seeming to be sorted. Agatha unwrapped her straw and slid it into her iced coffee, her regular order now having changed to a new one courtesy of Rio Vidal. She noticed that Rio had one of her own sitting on the folding table that was attached to her chair and when Rio caught her looking, she raised it with a small smile. Agatha raised hers in return and Billy leaned over to say something to Rio, but she was too far away to catch any of it.

She gave her lecture on the weapons of Greek Mythology and had to stifle a smile when she saw both Billy and Rio’s reaction to the inclusion of Percy Jackson’s sword ‘Riptide’ in one of the slides. She wasn’t originally going to put it in, but she knew that it would make them both happy so she amended the slide on Sunday night.

When the lecture was over, all of the students filed out of the room, Billy smiled at her as he walked past her but Rio hung back.
“You know that you’re a PhD student right?” Agatha asked, walking round her desk to lean against it. “You don’t need to beg for extra credit.” She crossed her arms and smiled.
Rio gave a low laugh. “Oh believe me, if I wanted extra credit from you I’d get it.”
“I’m sorry to inform you that it’ll take more than a coffee and a couple of sweet treats to win me over.”
“Don’t worry, I have my ways.” Rio said, stepping closer.

They were in the same position they had been in when Rio had confronted Agatha after her lecture a couple of weeks ago. Except the situation was different. This wasn’t Rio demanding that Agatha explain her decision of cancelling their meetings. This was a conversation between two acquaintances with the lightest amount of flirting mixed in. Agatha’s hands were restless again, but unlike the last time she knew why. She wanted to reach out, to touch Rio. She wanted to pull Rio closer and-

“So why are you hanging around after a lecture if it isn’t to boost your mark?” Agatha asked before her thoughts could get out of hand.
Rio pulled out her phone and showed it to Agatha. It was her schedule. “I checked your schedule, you have a couple of hours before your next lecture and, I’m assuming, the essays aren’t going to mark themselves.”
Agatha pushed herself off of the desk and started to pack up her things. “You know, if you keep spending this much time with me, people are gonna start to talk.” She turned back around to face Rio. “They might think you're my favourite student.” She punctuated the sentence with a wink and walked ahead to go to her office.
She had no idea where the wink came from, but she wasn’t going to dwell on it. 

Rio fell into step beside her. “Do you want me to grab us some snacks again?” She asked as the café came into view. “Or would that kickstart the horrific rumours that you don’t hate all of your students?” She smirked.
Agatha pretended to think for a moment. “Hmm. I’m sure that my reputation could survive . Also, I’m not gonna turn down free snacks.”
Rio bought them another selection of pastries, and a coffee each, and they carried on to Agatha’s office. Agatha took them via the lift instead of the stairs, not because she was in a great rush, but because Jen and Lilia were right. She needed to reclaim things, and one of those things was the short way to her office. However she told Rio it was because she didn’t trust her to carry the coffees up the stairs and not drop them.

When they stepped out of the lift, Agatha didn’t hesitate when it came to passing Wanda’s office.
“You can’t take steps forward if you’re always looking behind you, Agatha.”
“You can’t have a future if you’re stuck living in the past.”
She recalled Jen and Lilia’s words as she walked, keeping her head held high until they arrived at her own office. She unlocked the door and let them both in, holding the door open for Rio to walk through, and they got to work on the essays. Between them they’d managed to get through all of the first year essays – Rio had marked both Billy and Alice's work and Agatha had double checked them to make sure Rio hadn’t padded their marks out because they were her friends, but she had marked them fairly – and were now on to the second and final years.
Rio was still a little more forgiving in her marking than Agatha would have liked, but it wasn’t going to do any damage so she let her keep doing it. There was no use starting an argument.

__________

Tuesday was the day that Agatha held her office hours. A few of her better final years had taken the time to bring the research designs for their dissertations for her to look over before they submitted them. She had high hopes for these students, they actually put the work in and didn’t leave everything until the night before the deadline. Which was more than could be said for the rest of them.
She had sat through so many presentations on the tomb of Tutankhamun and how the ancient Romans did wonders for modern plumbing in the last couple of weeks that she was starting to regret specialising in ancient Egypt and ancient Rome as well as ancient Greece.
It was refreshing when she was given a proposal by one student on how Hippocrates had greatly influenced modern medicine, and she was genuinely excited to read the full dissertation when it was written.

She had just finished giving advice to a student who could not have cared any less when her laptop let her know that she had a new email. She dismissed the student and opened it.

Agatha,

I know you have office hours today, so I won’t take time away from your other students. Gotta make sure those rumours don’t fly!

Rio

Oh how she wished she was marking essays with Rio instead of dealing with the riff raff that kept trailing its way in and out of her office. Maybe she could rope Rio into helping with this too.
No, she couldn’t subject her to this, that would be cruel. Also Rio wasn’t her teaching assistant, so there would be no need for her to do it.

Rio,

Oh please come save me from this hell. I swear there’s barely a brain cell between my final years.

She paused in writing her response. Would now be a good time to suggest that they move from emailing to texting? The worst that could happen is that Rio rejects the idea, right? There’s no need to overthink this.
She continued typing.

Also we don’t have to keep using the formality of emails if you don’t want to. 

My number is: 07879871102
There’s no pressure though, it’s completely up to you.

Agatha

She pressed send, the whoosh noise letting her know that she couldn't take it back now. A minute passed, then another, then another. No response from Rio. Maybe it had been too forward. Maybe she felt awkward and didn’t know how to respond saying that she didn’t want to move on from emailing. Maybe she was emailing the Dean and letting him know that Professor Harkness had tried to give her her number. If that was the case then she was screwed. She could say goodbye to her career.

Her phone buzzed on her desk next to her, freeing her from her thoughts. It was two messages from an unknown number.
