Agatha figured that discussing a topic like this made Rio feel restless, unsure of how to hold herself, what to do with her hands, where to direct her gaze. Those would be the things that Agatha was feeling if it was her giving this lecture. Rio was doing a fantastic job and Agatha was proud of her.

“Having been exiled to an island, the only contact Medusa had with any other living being was the men that were sent to kill her. At first, Medusa was angry with the gods for cursing her and she was scared of her ability to turn people to stone – who wouldn’t be? But soon enough anybody who took one step on her island was now marked for death at the hands of the Gorgon Medusa. The more research that I’ve done into Medusa, the more Athena’s reaction to her being sexually assaulted troubled me.”
Rio changed the slide to show pictures of the earliest books to depict the stories of Greek mythology, and the names of the authors with the years the works were published written below them. “My personal belief for why Athena didn’t side with Medusa, help her and punish Poseidon, is simply because she was written by men.” There was an awkward murmur that rippled through the students, unsure if they should laugh or not. “If these myths and stories were written today, by women, then Medusa’s story might have been told differently and Poseidon might not have gotten away with it.”

Rio glanced up at the wall behind the seating bank and Agatha followed her gaze to the clock that hung there. There were only five minutes left of the lecture. ‘Has it really been two hours already?’ Agatha thought to herself. She was shocked at how the time had flown, not that she thought Rio’s lecture would be boring, it had just been a while since she’d sat through a lecture that someone else had given.

Rio made her way back around the desk and she changed to the last slide which was just a reminder about essay marks being sent out. “On a lighter note, Professor Harkness has finished marking your essays and you should get your marks by the end of the week, so keep an eye on your emails. As the professor mentioned a couple of weeks ago, should you want to contest your mark at all you can email her or make use of her office hours, which are on Tuesdays. I would like to thank you all for sticking with me and giving me your full attention, I really appreciate it.” She brought the lights back up and the students started packing up and making their way out of the room.

Agatha remained in her seat, watching Billy and Alice approach Rio. “You better be bringing me an apple or a ‘worlds best teacher’ mug.” Rio said with a smirk.
“Well we would have if we knew that this was happening!” Alice said.
“Why didn’t you tell us about this yesterday?” Billy added.
Rio folded her arms across her chest and leaned her hip against the desk. “I have to keep some mystery.”
Billy got a cheeky look on his face as he spoke. “Actually yeah, some mystery from you would be nice. I know way too much about you.”
Rio rolled her eyes. “Okay, scram you two. You’ve got more lectures to attend.” 
 Billy saluted her saying, “Yes Miss Vidal, sir,” and Alice pushed him towards the door, throwing a “bye Rio!” over her shoulder.

When the door was closed again Agatha stood up and brought the chair back over to the desk and pushed it under. “Well I can’t speak for anyone else, but that was definitely the best lecture I’ve ever sat through.”
Rio was in the process of unplugging and shutting down her laptop and snorted, saying, “If this is part of your attempt to see Spyro you’re gonna have to work harder than that.”
Agatha picked up her bag and slipped her notebook and pen back into it. “Do you just assume that everyone is flirting with you?” She folded her arms across her chest and leaned her hip against the desk, raising an eyebrow.
“I can’t help that I’m blessed with this level of charm and good looks.” Rio replied, putting her laptop in her bag and a cocky smile spreading across her face.

Agatha rolled her eyes and shook her head. She had been charmed by Rio but she couldn’t let Rio know that, not without knowing if Rio felt the same way. She had to continue playing it off. “Have you ever felt the sting of rejection?” She asked jokingly.
Rio breathed out a short laugh and looked up at her. “I have actually. But I don’t dwell on it, I just move on.” She shrugged and threw her bag over her shoulder, Agatha followed suit and shouldered her own bag.
Rio started to turn so that she could leave the room but Agatha reached out and put her hand on Rio’s upper arm, stopping her. “I meant it, by the way. You did a really good job this morning and you should be proud of yourself.”
Rio glanced down at Agatha’s hand but it was fleeting and she looked back up at Agatha’s face just as quickly. “Careful, you’re in danger of being nice to me.” She said softly.
“Oh don’t worry, this is a one-time event.” Agatha gently squeezed Rio’s arm before letting go.

They stayed there for a moment, just looking at each other. Rio’s expression was unreadable and there was a look in her eyes that Agatha couldn’t figure out. Time seemed to stretch and what was, in reality only a few seconds, felt like hours. It would be so easy for Agatha to reach out again. To grab Rio’s arm and pull her in. What would happen after, Agatha wasn’t sure. But if she made that first move then she would get an answer to the question that had been on her mind for the past month.

She wasn’t ready to do that, however, and when Rio took a small step towards her, she panicked. “There’s gonna be another lecture that needs to take place here soon, so we should go.” She quickly said, walking past Rio to the door. She didn’t stop to check if Rio was following her, she just let the door swing shut behind her and continued to her office. She didn’t even think about the fact that she hadn’t offered to give Rio proper feedback on the lecture, or that the two hours of downtime that she had right now would be the perfect time to do it. She just marched to her office, focussing only on putting one foot in front of the other.

When she got into her office she threw herself down into her desk chair and leaned her elbows on the desk, letting her face drop into her hands.
Jen was right, she was useless at this.
There was a time where she wouldn’t have hesitated. A time where she would have kissed Rio, repercussions be damned, and she wouldn’t have thought twice about it. But that time had long since passed and she was now in her forties, desperately pining after a woman who was twelve years younger than she was and trying to figure out how to navigate that.

Her phone pinged with an email notification, pulling her out of her thoughts. She opened the app and scowled at the latest unread email when she saw who it was from. It was the Dean summoning her to his office the following morning.
What the fuck had she done now? She hadn’t made anybody cry, she hadn't insulted any students or staff members, so what did he want?
This meeting would be cutting into her office hours so it better be fucking worth it.

She sent off a quick email to all of her students informing them that she was having to cancel her office hours due to an urgent meeting, and sat thinking about what the Dean could possibly be telling her off for now.

__________

Agatha went to her office first to drop her bag off and then went to the café to get a drink before making her way back up to the Dean’s office. She was muttering to herself the whole time about how much of an inconvenience this was and how he better not just be on a power trip or finding some nonsense to pull her up on because he was bored.

She rounded the corner into the waiting room that came before his office at exactly nine o’clock and rolled her eyes when her vision was unfortunately filled by the Dean’s secretary.
She greeted Agatha with a bright smile and said, in her nasally voice, “Oh there you are dear! They’re both waiting for you inside.”
Agatha was so desperate to get away from her that she just said, “Whatever,” and went straight to the door.
She didn’t bother knocking, she gave up on that a long time ago, and just pushed the door open, walking into the office.
It was only then that the secretary’s words sunk in. “They’re both waiting for you.” 
Both?
The Dean was sitting behind his desk, eyes trained on her as she entered, but sitting in front of him was another person. A person with dark hair wearing a dark green leather jacket who turned around to look at her when they heard the door open.
Why the fuck was Rio here?

Rio gave her a confused look which she returned as she walked towards the vacant chair on Rio’s right.
“Nice of you to join us, Agatha.” The Dean said as she sat down.
“Cut to the chase, Herb. Why am I here?” The corner of her mouth twitched when she saw him tense his jaw at the way she addressed him. He hated being addressed as anything other than Dean Collins, and he especially hated it when Agatha used his middle name.
She cast a sideways glance towards Rio who was looking at her with raised eyebrows and an expression that she couldn’t read.

Herb cleared his throat to get their attention back on him. “It has been brought to my attention, by some faculty members, that the two of you may have engaged in a relationship that goes beyond the standard teacher-student relationship that the university expects you to uphold.”
Agatha jumped straight in. “Excuse me? Who-”
“You know that I cannot disclose names, Agatha.” Herb cut her off. “While Miss Vidal may be a PhD student, and there is technically nothing illegal about the two of you being in a relationship, it is frowned upon and advised against in the university code of conduct.”
Agatha clenched her jaw. “What information have you been given, exactly?” She asked through her teeth. She didn’t look at Rio, she kept her eyes forwards, only on the Dean.
Herb inhaled sharply through his nose. “I have been told that, on Wednesday last week, yourself and Miss Vidal were seen walking through the building with your arms around each other, and there have been some reports of you walking arm in arm with Miss Vidal and getting into your car together.”

Agatha’s eyes went wide and she heard Rio scoff in disbelief next to her. That's what this was about? Did people really have nothing better to do than make up rumours about her and escalate it to the Dean? Were they really that dissatisfied with their own lives that they have to make every attempt to ruin hers?
Before she could respond, Rio spoke up. “With respect Dean Collins, that is just rumour and speculation. The reason that Professor Harkness and I had our arms around each other, as you put it, is because of a knee injury that flared up when I was in the Professor’s office. She was helping me get to the lecture.”
Herb narrowed his eyes, but not at Rio. He was still looking at Agatha. “I’m sure that there is a perfectly reasonable explanation for the two of you getting into your car after said lecture as well?” He asked, clearly trying to goad her into misspeaking.

Agatha relaxed her jaw slightly and schooled her features into a more neutral expression. “I offered to take Miss Vidal home after the lecture so that she didn’t have to walk on her injured knee, or stand and wait for a taxi to get her. As for being arm in arm as we walked to my car, Miss Vidal had taken some painkillers that lessened the pain in her knee but she was still unstable as she walked, so I helped her stay upright. Would you rather I just left her stranded with no way of getting home?” Her voice was even but there was an underlying challenge. A challenge for Herb to deny that she was doing anything other than being a good person.

Herb looked between the two of them for a moment before asking, “Can you provide any evidence of this?” He asked, smugness and disbelief covered his voice and expression.
Was he being serious? Asking for evidence of an injury that Rio sustained god knows how many years go that randomly comes back without warning? If she wasn’t already certain at this point that he was looking for literally any excuse to fire her, that just cinched it.
Agatha was still making an effort to not look at Rio too much during this but she saw out of the corner of her eye Rio silently bending down and rolling up the right leg of her sweatpants.
Agatha turned her head then because she was shocked at the fact that Rio wasn’t wearing jeans.

Once the leg had been rolled up past her knee, Rio stood up and walked around Herb’s desk slightly so that he could see her better, and pointed at the brace that was on her leg. “I’m not sure what kind of evidence one could present in this scenario, Dean Collins, but hopefully this brace that I got from the hospital when I originally sustained the injury will suffice.”
Agatha knew that Rio was well spoken, her writing reflected that, but hearing her speak in this way and using it to take the Dean down a peg sent a tingle down her spine.
She watched Herb look down at Rio’s knee, the brace wiping the smug look from his face.
“I can show you the painkillers that I was prescribed to take as well, should you require further proof of the unfortunate accident that befell me when I was sixteen.”
He cleared his throat once more before saying, “No that won’t be necessary, Miss Vidal. You may take your seat again.”
Rio walked back to her chair and her eyes locked onto Agatha’s, though her expression gave nothing away.

Herb looked between them again. “I can see that the things I was told were in fact rumour and speculation, as Miss Vidal previously stated.”
Agatha quirked an eyebrow. “Is that it?”
Herb clenched his jaw. “I would like to apologise to both of you for any inconvenience this may have caused and I shall endeavour to ensure that such gossip will not result in this outcome in the future.” He didn’t look at Agatha though, he spoke to Rio.
Agatha couldn’t hold back the scoff that happened in the back of her throat. She had heard that one before and yet here she was again, sitting in Herb’s office, being reprimanded for something that wasn’t even true, and he couldn’t look at her as he offered his fake apologies.

Agatha plastered a fake smile on her face and said, “Well this has been a pleasure as always Herb, but I actually have some work to be getting on with. And I’m sure Miss Vidal has better things to be doing right now than sitting in your office.” She stood up and started towards the door. “Let’s not do this again any time soon.” She held the door open for Rio before letting it slam shut behind her.
She ignored the secretary’s attempt at conversation and silently stalked out of the waiting room. Once she had turned the corner into the corridor she turned to Rio whilst still walking. “That man has vendetta against me. I’m sorry you got dragged into it.”
“It’s fine Agatha, don’t worry about it. Hey…”
Agatha felt a hand wrap around her wrist and she stopped dead, turning round to see Rio’s outstretched arm as she caught up. “I’m still not up to full speed, I can’t keep up with you if you walk that fast.” Rio finished with a light chuckle.

Agatha felt a heat blooming on her cheeks from the feeling of Rio’s skin on her own. “Sorry,” she said quietly as she looked down at their hands. “You probably shouldn’t try to hold my hand in the corridors though. Being summoned back into his office five seconds after leaving wouldn’t be a good look.”
Rio laughed and dropped Agatha’s arm. “Very good point. You really weren’t kidding when you said that people would talk if we were seen together, huh?”
“It’s not often that I dislike being right, but in this case I’m annoyed that I was.” Agatha dipped her head slightly and caught sight of Rio’s trousers again. She pointed at them and said, “I was beginning to think that you didn’t own anything other than skinny jeans. How are your legs doing now that the blood is able to flow properly?”
Rio crossed her arms and lifted an eyebrow. “What is your issue with my jeans? These are easier to fit the brace under if you must know.” She grabbed some of the fabric and wiggled it to demonstrate the baggyness. “And before you ask why I didn’t wear them yesterday, I didn’t think sweatpants would be the correct attire to be giving a lecture in. Now come on before someone reports us for talking in the corridors.” She walked past Agatha and gave her a smirk. Agatha waited for a few seconds before falling into step beside her.

They walked to Agatha’s office in comfortable silence, careful to not walk too closely. Agatha unlocked the door and let them into the room, closing it gently once Rio had walked in, and then sat in her usual chair with a sigh. “Every interaction with that man makes me need a drink, I swear.”
Rio lowered herself into her chair, her knee wasn’t causing her as much discomfort as before. “If you want to whip out a flask, I won’t tell anyone.”
“Oh I know you wouldn’t, but the last thing I need right now is for someone to report me for drinking on campus. It would be like Christmas for Herb.”
Rio looked at her for a second, face neutral apart from a slight furrow in her brows. “Why does he have it out for you so badly?”
Agatha sighed and straightened her posture a little bit. She definitely wasn’t going to tell Rio the whole story, or mention any names, but if she was now being involved in the pedestrian drama that the situation created, then it’s only right that she knows the basics.

“Some years ago I dated a faculty member and to keep a much longer story short, it ended badly. The other faculty members took her side which led to me being reported for many stupid things, like today, and it made Herb’s life more difficult than it needed to be. There came a point where he decided that it would be easier to fire me, but since he can’t do it without a plausible reason, he takes every one that he’s given until he can find one that works. It’s a rare occurrence when someone defends me with him, so thank you for doing it today.” Agatha kept her eyes on Rio’s, watching for her reaction.
Rio licked her lips. “Men like that just enjoy swinging their dicks around, and I enjoy shutting them down.” She said with a sly smile.
“You enjoy proving that yours is bigger.” Agatha said, a statement not a question.
Rio gave a nonchalant shrug. “It usually is.” She said and pushed her tongue against her cheek.

Agatha cleared her throat, not sure how to move on from the current topic of conversation. “I believe I owe you some feedback for your lecture.” She stood up and retrieved her notebook from her bag before sitting back down again.
Rio leaned back in her chair and crossed her arms. “Ahh yes, tell me how brilliant I was.”
“Your cockiness will be your downfall one day.” Agatha said as she found the right page and slipped her glasses on. “Your introduction was good, I liked that you had them engaging right away by asking what they knew about Medusa and you handled it well. The information that was on the slides was concise and you elaborated on it well without being glued to your notes the whole time.” She looked up at Rio. “Actually, I don’t think you looked at your notes once.”
Rio tapped her temple a couple of times. “Steel trap.”

Agatha smiled. “Of course, how could I have assumed anything else?” She went back to her notebook. “You filled the time well and kept their attention which is a difficult thing to do, especially when you get to the final years, and there was a good balance of humour mixed in with the facts to keep it flowing.” She shut the notebook and took her glasses off, focussing on Rio’s eyes. She changed the tone of her voice from the matter-of-fact one to a softer one. “I was really impressed with how you approached the final section of the lecture. Giving the disclaimer before you started it showed good forethought and compassion. There’s not a lot of experienced lecturers who would have thought to do that.
The way you worded everything was probably the best it could have been done and it was a strong decision leaving that part until the end so that, if anyone did need to leave, they wouldn't miss the rest of the lecture.” She set her notebook down on the coffee table. “Overall? Yes, you were brilliant.” She gave a full smile and sat back again.

Rio sat forwards again with a lazy half smile on her lips. “What was that you said yesterday? Being nice to me was a one time event?”
Agatha rolled her eyes. “Okay fine, you were absolutely terrible and you have no future in the world of teaching. Is that better?”
“No, no. I’m fine with you being nice to me, I just don’t want you to spontaneously combust because of it.”
Agatha sighed. “Have I told you that you’re infuriating?”
Rio smirked. “You might have mentioned it. Does this glowing review mean that I’ll be allowed to do it again?”
Agatha leaned back and crossed her legs. “I don’t see why not. It gives me less work to do, and since it’s nearly the end of the semester, we just need to focus on giving the students as much information they can use on the January exams as possible.” Before Rio could respond, Agatha continued. “Speaking of the end of the semester.” Now was her chance to bring up the ball and gauge Rio’s interest. “You’ve probably already heard about it, but every December the department throws an end of year ball. It’s usually a good night, and it’s an open bar for the first two hours. You should go. It’ll be a good way to get to know people off campus.” She chose her words carefully so as not to outright ask Rio to go with her. It was safer that way.

“You know, you’re the fifth person to mention the ball to me. I might have to turn up and see what all the fuss is about.” Rio said.
Fifth person? Fifth? Had four other people asked Rio to go with them? Agatha should have expected as much. There was no way that Rio hadn’t gotten the attention of multiple other women at the university. Had she left it too late? Shit.

Agatha’s alarm went off to let her know that she needed to go to her first lecture of the day. Saved by the bell, as it were. She stood up and moved to her desk to get her bag. “Well I’ll hopefully see you there then. Fifth in line apparently.” She kept her voice light and humorous to hide the hurt that was lying just underneath.
Rio gave a short chuckle. “I don’t think you’ll have any trouble making it to the front of that line."
Agatha didn’t pause her movements but her mind got stuck on that sentence.
What did she mean? Had she rejected the other offers? Or was she now deciding to reject them in favour of her?
Was Rio saying that she specifically wanted to go to the ball with her?

Agatha moved on autopilot as she headed for the door, saying words that she didn’t realise her brain had formed. “Do you want to come sit in on the third year lecture, or do you need to go home and rest your leg?”
Rio walked through the door and turned back around to face Agatha. “My leg’s mostly fine now, I’m just keeping the brace on for a week to make extra sure really. And it’s a good job I did, otherwise you might have spent the last hour packing up your office.”
Agatha locked the door and they walked towards the lift together.
They rounded the corner that took them past Wanda’s office and just as they were passing the door, something that Agatha had been wishing would never happen, happened.
The door opened.

Wanda stepped out and collided with Rio, knocking her into Agatha. Agatha put her arms out and caught Rio as Rio put her own arms out and stopped Wanda from falling over.
“Oh my god I am so sorry!” Wanda started immediately apologising and Agatha helped Rio stand upright properly, trying to process what was happening.
Wanda looked up at Rio’s face and recognised her. “I thought we were done meeting like this, Rio.” She said with a laugh, not yet noticing Agatha standing behind Rio.
“Well I’m just lucky that Agatha was here to stop me from hitting the deck.” Rio replied, stepping to the side so that Wanda could see Agatha.

Wanda’s smile fell and her face started to pale as she looked at Agatha. “I didn’t realise that you were- you don’t usually-” She cleared her throat as Agatha gave her an unamused look. “Where are you going?”
Agatha gave a tight smile. “I’m going to give a lecture, Wanda. That is our job after all.”
Wanda looked down and smoothed out her shirt that was wrinkled where Rio had grabbed her. “Right, of course. Stupid question.” She looked back up at Agatha. “You usually take the stairs.”
Agatha’s gaze flicked towards Rio who was watching this interaction with a look that Agatha couldn’t read, and then back to Wanda. She didn’t owe Wanda any explanations and technically, Wanda hadn’t asked a question, so there was no need to even respond. She could just walk away and leave this unfortunate moment behind her. Instead she simply stated, “Rio has a bad leg, stairs aren’t an option.”

Wanda immediately turned to Rio, concern on her face. “What happened to your leg? Are you okay?” Agatha’s eyes narrowed as she watched Wanda instinctively start to reach out towards Rio but stopped herself before she touched her.
How well did they know each other for that to be Wanda’s reaction? Those weren’t the actions of someone who had only met a person once or twice. They knew each other on more than a base level. What were they to each other?
Agatha had hoped that every time Rio had threatened to go to Wanda that it was empty, just words with no meaning, but this made her think differently. They knew each other. They’d spent time together.

“An old injury got aggravated again, but I’m fine. Just taking it easy.”
Agatha barely heard Rio’s response through the noise in her head. Her thoughts had gotten so loud in the last thirty seconds that she could feel a headache coming on. She needed to get out of this hallway, she needed to get out of this building. But she couldn’t just run, she had a job to do.
She checked her watch, ignoring the slight tremor in her hands, and cleared her throat. “Well, I hate to leave so suddenly, but I do have a job to do.” She had to force her voice to stay even as it threatened to shake like her hands. “Let’s not do this again.” She said for the second time that day.
She started towards the lift again, her body on autopilot as her head was still swimming.

She stepped into the lift and slumped in the right corner, letting out a breath and letting her body deflate with it. She dipped her head and closed her eyes, waiting for the doors to close and the lift to start moving, but the sound of the doors opening again made her open her eyes.
She saw the shoes first, black converse with small lightning bolts that were in the colours of the pride flag. Then her eyes moved up and she saw the grey sweatpants. They moved up some more and she saw the black t-shirt and dark green leather jacket, an arm outstretched to stop the doors from closing fully. Then finally, she saw Rio’s face. Her eyes were fixed on Agatha, soft and full of worry.

Rio silently walked into the lift and pressed the button to close the doors once more.
Agatha sighed and said, “I’m not answering any questions.” She definitely wasn’t in the right headspace to be having this conversation right now. She didn’t even know what she would say. How does one begin to talk about what that was?
Rio settled herself into the left corner of the lift. “I’m not gonna ask any. Except one.”
Agatha leaned her head back against the wall of the lift, bracing herself for whatever Rio was going to say next.
“Are you okay?”
Agatha whipped her head in Rio’s direction. That hadn’t been what she was expecting. “What?” Was all she could say, probably more sharply than she should have, but she was too surprised.

Rio gestured towards the now closed doors of the lift. “I don’t need details, but that didn’t look like a normal conversation between co-workers. So, are you okay?”
It was a simple question, one that should be easy to answer. But when it came to Wanda Maximoff, things were never easy. “It’s nothing I can’t handle.”
“That’s not an answer.”
“Well it’s the one you’re getting so you’ll have to live with it.”
The remaining minute of the lift ride was spent in silence, as was the walk towards the lecture hall. The silence was only broken when Rio started to veer off and Agatha asked, “Where are you going?”
Rio turned so that she was walking backwards. “You go on ahead, I’ll catch up.” She turned back around and continued on her way.

Agatha got to the lecture hall just as the last few students were walking in. She quickly got her laptop set up and dimmed the lights to start the lecture, forcing herself to focus on the task at hand instead of the thoughts that were bombing around her skull.
About ten minutes into the lecture, the doors opened again and in walked Rio. Agatha watched her but didn’t stop speaking. There was a slight murmur that ran through the students, but no real disruption caused by the latecomer.
Rio quietly walked up to the desk in the centre of the room and softly placed a drink and a brown paper bag on it before walking up the seating bank and taking her seat next to Billy.
Agatha, still not breaking from her lecture, watched Billy raise his eyebrows at Rio but she just smiled, shook her head and sat down.

The lecture passed by in a blur, muscle memory guiding Agatha through it. She had a few sips of the coffee that Rio had bought for her as she was changing slides but ignored the bag until the lecture was over.
All of the students, including Rio, left the room when the two hours was up, and the next wave of students came in to take their seats.
Agatha took the few minutes that the changeover gave her to see what was in the bag. She pulled out a cinnamon swirl and a pain au chocolat. A napkin fell out with them, but she paid it no mind as she took a bite of the cinnamon swirl. It was only after she had swallowed that bite that she noticed there was something written on the napkin. She picked it up to see what it said.

I know you have back to back lectures until the end of the day, so I hope the coffee and pastries make it a little easier for you - R

Agatha’s breath caught in her throat as she read it. She looked towards the door like she expected Rio to be standing there watching her, but all she saw were her final year students still filing into the room. She put the cinnamon swirl down next to the pain au chocolat on the bag and loaded up the relevant PowerPoint. She dimmed the lights and tapped out a quick message on her phone before starting the lecture.

Agatha: Thank you

__________

The rest of the day didn’t exactly pass quickly, but it wasn’t as excruciating as Agatha had expected it to be. She savoured the food and drink that Rio had bought her, making them last as long as she could. The beauty of the iced coffee, as Rio had once pointed out, was that she didn’t have to worry about it going cold, so she was able to make it last a good couple of hours before she finished it.

When she got home at the end of the day she got straight in the shower. She did her normal shower routine and then sat on the floor, just letting the water pour over her. She rested her back against the cool tile wall and pulled her knees up to her chest, finally allowing the events of the morning to flood her mind. She thought about phoning Lilia to help her work through them but she couldn’t move. She was frozen.

The meeting with Herb really wasn’t anything that she would dwell on, she was used to that by now. But everything that happened after? That wasn’t anything that she knew how to process right now. Seeing Wanda outside of a pre-arranged meeting wasn’t something that she ever wanted to do, and then she literally bumped into her. That in itself would have been enough, but there was the fact that Rio and Wanda recognised each other. From that limited interaction Agatha could tell that they had some kind of bond that they had built up. A friendship of some kind.

Agatha knew that it was silly to get wound up about it. Rio and Wanda were free people who could meet and talk to whoever they wanted, and Rio was friends with Billy so it’s entirely probable that they met through him. But the concern on Wanda’s face and the way she reached out towards Rio when she found out about Rio’s leg went beyond just being her friend's mum. There was something there, something between them that Agatha didn’t want to think about. Was Wanda one of the four other people that had asked Rio to go to the ball? Had Rio said yes? Did Billy know? She could ask him about it, but that would be tough to bring up organically.
‘Hey kid, how’s your first semester going? Also what’s going on with your mum and Rio?’
That definitely wouldn’t work. Also she didn’t want to use him just to get information, the thought made her feel sick.

Then there was the fact that Rio chased after her into the lift, stopping the doors just in time to get in with her. She hadn’t asked any questions about the very tense and awkward interaction that she had just witnessed, she had only asked if Agatha was okay.
Agatha thought about the way she had responded to it and winced when she remembered how short and sharp her voice had been. But it hadn’t seemed to deter Rio. Rio had understood that she didn’t want to talk about anything and had just let her have her silence. Then Rio had bought her a drink and some food and left a note with it. She had actually thought about the fact that Agatha clearly wasn’t okay with seeing Wanda, and instead of pressing for information she had just bought something that she thought would comfort her.
Agatha truly didn’t know what to make of it.

She had no idea how long she’d been sitting in the shower for, but the ache in her back and hips when she tried to stand let her know that it had been too long. She dried herself off and put her pyjamas on before going back downstairs to order some food. She would usually cook something, but she was too exhausted to fathom standing in the kitchen for half an hour physically making food, and then having to wash up afterwards. So ordering pizza it was.
After some deliberation, she also bought her ticket to the ball, scoffing at the limited menu choices. It might have been a few years since she attended one of these events but she swore the options used to be better.

When she had eaten, she went upstairs and started her nightly skin care routine – all products that Jen had picked out for her over the years.
When she was done she crawled into bed and picked up the book that was on her nightstand, The Night Circus by Erin Morgenstern.
She had bought it a few days after Rio told her about it and was thoroughly enjoying it. She hoped that reading it tonight would quiet her mind, and it did to some extent. The fact that the book jumped around both in place and time meant that she had to concentrate on it more than she usually would if she wanted to follow it, and that gave her something else to focus her mind on.

Rio hadn’t responded to her text from earlier but she wasn’t reading into it, Rio was probably just giving her space – and she was actually thankful for it.
After reading a few chapters, she set the book back down and laid on her side to attempt sleep.
She tossed and turned for a while before her brain finally slowed down and she drifted off.

__________

The next month passed pretty easily. Rio gave another lecture, this time about the Underworld and the different layers it had. She used her PhD research to highlight a few different depictions of it, pulling information from books, TV shows, films and even games. She was good at keeping the attention of the first year students and continued to impress Agatha with how well she delivered the lecture.

Rio continued to go to Agatha’s office whenever she had downtime and they traded who would be buying the food and drinks each time. Since there were no essays to mark, they just talked. Getting to know each other and deepening their friendship.
Rio had started referring to these meetings as dates which absolutely did not make Agatha panic whatsoever. She had a completely normal reaction the first time Rio had said it and definitely didn’t nearly choke on her pastry.
“Damn, you really know how to bruise my ego.” Rio had joked.
“Well I can’t in good conscience let your head get too big. You’re insufferable enough as it is.” Agatha had replied once she could breathe again.
They still walked to and from lectures together, but they maintained a distance so as not to invoke more rumours and visits to Herb’s office.

Rio didn’t bring up their run-in with Wanda, and Agatha started to push it to the back of her mind. She did avoid the lifts for a week before remembering what Lilia and Jen had said about not living in the past. If she was to truly move on from it, then she needed to accept that these things would happen and she couldn’t hide from them forever.

Agatha invited Billy and Alice over for dinner another couple of times, she was tempted to ask about Rio’s involvement with Wanda but decided against it. She could ask Rio herself, it wasn’t fair to use Billy like that. If she did then she would be no better than Wanda, and if there's one thing that kept Agatha going, it was knowing that she was better than Wanda.

Her weekly dinners with Lilia and Jen were spent fielding questions about Rio, and telling them that she did not need a ‘game plan’ for the ball. She did mention the fact that she and Rio had bumped into Wanda on their way to a lecture and that Rio and Wanda seemed to know each other, but Lilia and Jen just confirmed what the rational part of her brain already knew. Rio and Wanda were both adults who frequented the same areas of the university, they were allowed to meet and even become friends. And should anything start with Agatha and Rio, then she should tell her about her relationship with Wanda and why it ended. But until that point, she would just have to deal with it and continue as normal.

Throughout December decorations went up around the department and the university as a whole, and Agatha added the obligatory singular rope of tinsel around her television that Jen and Lilia insisted that she put up.
Her Christmases as a child after her dad had died had never been happy ones. Her mother always went on a religious tirade, blaming Agatha for all of the bad things that had happened to her that year, saying that her evil nature had made god angry and he was punishing her for not killing Agatha when she was born.
When her step-father came on the scene he only strengthened the tirades, joining in with them and supporting Evanora’s delusions.

When she had been with Wanda she began to find ways to enjoy Christmas. Decorating the tree with Billy, baking mince pies with Wanda even though she couldn’t stand them, and getting to see and experience the joy that both Wanda and Billy felt at the season as a whole.
But since all of that had been taken from her, she had no reason to feel the Christmas spirit anymore, and this December came with a new memory. The 3rd marked one year since the car accident that nearly killed Billy. One full year since Agatha got that call from Wanda and she raced to the hospital. One full year since she was reminded that through all of the heartbreak, sadness and rage she had felt at Wanda cheating on her, the worst, hardest to face part of it was losing Billy.

December was Agatha’s least favourite month of the year, and she had plenty of reasons for it, but as the night of the end of year ball approached, she hoped that that would no longer be the case.

Chapter End Notes

Peep the time jump... WE'RE GETTING THESE BITCHES TO THE BALL!

Chapter 20: Rio

Chapter Notes

Sorry this one is so short, it's just to give Rio's POV on some things

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Getting called into the Dean’s office was not on Rio’s bingo card for the year. Yet there she was sitting across from him with Agatha beside her, listening to him tell them that rumours were spreading about their involvement with each other.
The amusing thing was that she was, in fact, sleeping with a member of staff. Just not the member of staff that everyone apparently assumed she was sleeping with.
The less amusing part was the Dean’s tone when he spoke to Agatha, the way that he spoke down to her and clearly had no respect for her.

Agatha was clearly used to this, clearly used to being pulled into his office for stupid things that had no weight to them, but Rio wasn’t.
Rio had never been in a Dean’s office in any capacity, good or bad. This was entirely new to her but she would be damned if she let him sit there with a smug grin on his face while he tried to frame them for having an inappropriate relationship and asked for evidence of an injury.
Thank god Rio was cautious and kept her brace on even after her knee was fine again, because the satisfaction she got from watching his face drop when he saw it was a high she would be riding for some time.

He was obviously unhappy that he had to dismiss them and couldn’t take any action in favour of the baseless chatter that had made its way to him, but dismiss them he did.
Again, it was clear that Agatha was used to this. But the way that she stalked out of his office and into the hall showed Rio that it affected her more than she would ever let on.
Rio knew that Agatha wouldn’t be open to questions, especially not mere seconds after the fact, so she followed Agatha’s lead in terms of conversation. It stayed light and small – mostly about her jeans, which she was happy to comply with – until they got to Agatha’s office.

Watching the way Agatha deflated and dropped some of the ‘Professor Harkness’ persona that she upheld where people could see her let Rio know that Agatha viewed her office as a safe space. A place on campus where she could go after meetings like that to decompress and just take a few minutes to herself where she didn’t have to be switched on. And the fact that she was letting Rio witness it meant that she trusted Rio to some degree. Trusted that she wouldn’t judge or make fun of her in this small moment of vulnerability that she was experiencing.

Once again Rio let Agatha lead the conversation, only asking a question when Agatha mentioned the Dean.
Hearing Agatha say that the Dean is just looking for any excuse to fire her and that her fellow staff members aid in this, made Rio feel equal parts sad and angry. Did Agatha have any friends among her colleagues? Did she have anyone that she could go to when something like this happened?
Suddenly Agatha’s need for control, her demand for respect, started to make sense. Her peers had written her off and treated her as less than – all because of a relationship that went wrong. She had lost their respect so she took it back from her students. She wasn’t in control of how her colleagues saw her so she took control of how her students saw her. The Dean looked at her as someone who was beneath him and treated her as nothing other than an inconvenience, so she took that feeling and projected it onto the people that were beneath her .
It was a vicious cycle.

Rio wasn’t expecting Agatha to mention the ball, it didn’t seem like her thing – especially after realising that pretty much the whole department had something against her – but she spoke about it like she regularly attended the event. And she seemed almost sad when Rio told her that she was the fifth person to mention it. Was Agatha trying to ask her to go with her? As her date? No, that couldn’t be right.
Agatha had asked her the other day if she assumed everyone was flirting with her and maybe there was some truth to it because there was no way that Professor Agatha Harkness was asking her on a date. Either way, Rio felt the need to point out that the other people weren’t a threat.

They talked about the upcoming lecture whilst they walked the familiar path to the lifts, when Rio suddenly felt the wind being knocked out of her.
A body crashed into hers and sent her sideways, but she didn’t fall. She reached out and grabbed the other person to try and steady herself, and also keep them upright as she felt Agatha’s arm wrap around her waist, squeezing gently to stop her from tumbling to the floor.
Once her brain caught up, she registered the red hair and green eyes that belonged to Wanda and felt Agatha pushing her fully back onto her feet.

“Oh my god I am so sorry!” Wanda said before she realised that it was Rio that she had just very nearly knocked to the floor. She laughed lightly. “I thought we were done meeting like this, Rio.”
Rio smiled, recalling the two times that this had happened previously. It felt so long ago now. “Well I’m just lucky that Agatha was here to stop me from hitting the deck.” She said as she stepped to the side.
The smile Wanda was wearing was immediately erased when she saw Agatha and Rio watched as Wanda floundered, trying to find something to say. “I didn’t realise that you were- you don’t usually- Where are you going?”
Rio immediately felt the tension settle between the three of them. The panic on Wanda’s face, the tightness of Agatha’s smile. It all furthered Rio’s suspicion that they were each the ex that the other had referenced – and if that was true then that meant that Wanda was the reason that Agatha was a target for the Dean.

Rio cast her mind all the way back to the time she and Wanda had eaten Chinese food in her apartment, and tried to recall what Wanda had said about the ex that wasn’t her husband. She couldn’t remember the conversation fully as it was months ago, but she swore Wanda had mentioned something about being scared and that it made her do something she regretted.

Rio had zoned out and only came back to the corridor when Agatha mentioned her name.
“Rio has a bad leg, stairs aren’t an option.”
Wanda turned to her, looking worried, and started to reach towards her. Rio took a small step back, not enough to be out of Wanda’s reach – not even enough that it was noticeable – but enough that it had been an involuntary reaction to seeing Wanda trying to touch her.
“What happened to your leg? Are you okay?” Wanda asked, stopping her hands before they made contact.
“An old injury got aggravated again, but I’m fine. Just taking it easy.” Rio briefly flicked her eyes towards Agatha and noticed the subtle shake of her hand as she checked her watch.

As if having to face the Dean this morning wasn’t bad enough, Agatha had now been forced into an interaction with the person who was potentially responsible for it – albeit indirectly responsible, but if what Agatha said about everyone taking Wanda’s side was true, then she was still implicated.
Rio truly didn’t know how to feel as she watched Agatha walk away. She had no real hard evidence that supported her theory and therefore couldn’t react properly. There was a high likelihood that she would never know the full story, at the end of the day it wasn’t any of her business. She had no loyalties to either of these women, she had known them both for the same amount of time.
Sure she knew them in different ways – very different ways – but still, she knew each of them minimally.

Wanda’s voice pulled her from her thoughts. “Are you sure your leg is okay?”
Rio blinked a couple of times, her mind still not fully back. “Yeah it’s nothing, really." She started walking towards the lifts again, following Agatha. “See you later,” she threw over her shoulder, picking up her pace as much as the slight limp she still had would allow.
She got to the lift just in time to throw her arm out and stop the doors from closing. When the doors opened again, she settled herself into the corner across from Agatha.
Agatha huffed out a tired sigh and said, “I’m not answering any questions.”
Rio expected as much. She hadn’t planned on asking any questions, she didn’t even know what she would ask. She didn’t know how to begin to broach this subject right now, so instead she said, “I’m not gonna ask any. Except one.”

She watched Agatha lean back into the corner of the lift and take a deep breath.
“Are you okay?”
Judging by the speed that Agatha turned to look at her and her tone when she asked, “What?” she hadn’t been expecting Rio to ask that. She had definitely been expecting something more invasive.
“I don’t need details, but that didn’t look like a normal conversation between co-workers. So, are you okay?” Rio wasn’t lying, she really didn’t care for the details right now. All she cared about in that moment was making sure Agatha was alright.
“It’s nothing I can’t handle.”
Rio blew a breath out of her nose. “That’s not an answer.”
“Well it’s the one you’re getting so you’ll have to live with it.”
That was fair enough, Rio supposed. She said that she wasn’t going to ask questions and she stuck to her word.

On the way to the lecture hall, Rio made a decision and told Agatha that she would catch up. She made her way to the café and picked up the two pastries that she noticed Agatha favoured along with the iced coffee. Whilst she was waiting for the coffee to be made she scribbled ‘I know you have back to back lectures until the end of the day, so I hope the coffee and pastries make it a little easier for you - R’ on a napkin and tucked it into the bag with the food. When she received the coffee she carried on to the lecture hall, arriving ten minutes late thanks to the queue. She had hoped that it would only take a few minutes, but once again she was without Agatha’s privileges so she had to wait with the commoners.

To her credit Agatha didn’t let Rio’s late arrival interrupt her flow, she kept on teaching whilst Rio placed the food and drink on the table and then took her seat next to Billy.
Billy looked at her with raised eyebrows, his question evident on his face, but she shook her head. He could ask later.

When the lecture was over Rio left with Billy and Alice, she didn’t want to add anything on top of what Agatha was already feeling about the morning. As soon as they rounded the first corner away from the lecture hall Billy asked, “Please tell me that you didn’t make yourself late just so you could butter Agatha up with food.”
Rio smiled and shrugged. “I didn’t intentionally arrive late. The queue was just long.”
“I’m hearing no denial of an attempt to become the teacher's pet.” Alice joined in.
Rio stepped in front of them and turned so that she was walking backwards. “I don’t need to try to be the teacher’s pet, it just naturally happens.” She turned back around and fell back into step with them. “Besides with the marks you two got on your essays, you might want to try giving gifts to your lecturers once in a while.”
“What?” Billy and Alice asked in unison.
Billy grabbed Rio’s arm. “Did we really do that badly?”
Rio looked at him and shrugged.
“Dude!” Alice moved in front of her, making her stop walking. “Don’t fuck with us.”
“You’ll just have to wait for your grades to see if I was lying or not.” Rio said nonchalantly as she moved around Alice.
“Dick.” She heard Billy mutter behind her. 

__________

The next month passed with more of the same.
Rio still went to Agatha’s office and she enjoyed watching Agatha panic when she started to call the meetings dates, but since there was no real work to do they just talked. Sometimes they would just keep each other company whilst they read in comfortable silence, trading books and opinions.

At the start of December, Rio gave her second lecture to the first years.
“Okay so as I’m sure you’re all aware, religions tend to have their own version of the afterlife. For Greek mythology it was the underworld – a kingdom that Hades and Persephone ruled over. The earliest idea of the afterlife in Greek myth is that, when a person dies, that person's essence – or psyche –  is separated from the corpse and transported to the underworld.” She changed the slide so that the bullet points matched what she was going to say next. “In the earliest works like Homer's The Iliad and The Odyssey, the dead were kinda just lumped together to live a post-existence as shadowy figures. However in later versions of the mythology, the forms of judgement started to make an appearance. It was then believed that there were sections within the underworld where someone's psyche would be sent depending on how they lived their life on top.” She changed the slides again to one that had pictures of the three sections with their names underneath.

“The most unpleasant one is Tartarus. This is where the wicked received divine punishment. Most famously, it’s where the Titans went after they were defeated by Zeus. It also happens to be the easiest part of the game Hades, which seems backwards to me.” That last part got the laugh that she was hoping it would.
“Next is Asphodel, the meadows where the vast majority of the dead go. It’s believed to be the place where the normal people went. The people who hadn’t committed any atrocious crimes, but also hadn’t done any outstanding good deeds. And then we have Elysium, the good place. Elysium is a utopian afterlife reserved for specially distinguished individuals where life is easiest, a paradise that heroes could go to as a reward for all the good work they did on earth. So why it’s also the hardest level on Hades, I have no idea.” Once again, the reference to the game got a laugh from the students.

After giving an overview of the different sections she spoke about the rivers that were contained within the underworld, giving their names and functions. She also touched on the story of Orpheus and Eurydice, which was just an excuse to talk about Hadestown for a few minutes – something Agatha mentioned when giving feedback.
She ended the lecture by talking about the different notable residents of the underworld. Namely Hecate, Charon, Thanatos, and finally, Cerberus.
“The ultimate guard dog and overall goodest boy. He’s depicted as having three heads and is often shown as a Rottweiler, Doberman and sometimes a Molossian hound. But if you ask me, a three-headed Chihuahua would be the most terrifying dog to have chasing you down.”
The students laughed as she brought the lights back up, signalling the end of the lecture.

Band practise was focussed on running the setlist until they could all play and sing it in their sleep. There were a few last minute changes in terms of the order of the songs, and one song was swapped out for a different one that they thought would be more of a crowd pleaser, but they were all confident that they were going to absolutely smash the gig.
 Taylor joined them in the pub a couple of times, and Rio went home with her. Always leaving instead of staying the night.

Billy made a joke about not wanting to see her when he went home for dinner one weekend and she laughed it off. Rio saw Wanda a handful of times throughout the month and only because getting herself off wasn’t satisfying enough. Wanda was good at it, so why wouldn’t she use what she had at her disposal?

Rio was a big fan of Christmas and found herself getting more and more homesick as the holiday approached. She bought herself a small tabletop tree and strung some Christmas lights around her apartment to celebrate the season as much as she could by herself. Her friends and family had sent their Christmas cards to her so she put them on her bookcase and windowsills to add to the decorations.

Her flight home was the morning after the ball so she made sure that she had her bags packed and ready to go to avoid rushing around too much. She had a few calls with her family and friends to make arrangements for her being picked up from the airport and to make sure that her time at home was filled with seeing as many of the people that she missed as possible.

As the night of the ball drew closer she started to feel more nervous. She hadn’t played an actual gig since high school, and playing in a practise room was vastly different to playing in front of an audience. If the other guys fucked up they could catch back on pretty quickly, but if she fucked up then it was a lot more noticeable and that’s what she was worried about the most.

The night before the ball she struggled to sleep. She hadn’t had any more issues with her knee, but it was in the back of her mind. What if she hurt it again before or during? She had no idea how she would recover. She made sure to put her painkillers in the bag she was taking just in case and eventually drifted off to sleep.

Chapter End Notes

Next chapter will be the ball so it might take a bit longer to write.
Thank you all for sticking with me thus far!

Chapter 21: Agatha &amp; Rio

Chapter Notes

This chapter is nearly 16k words so grab a drink and a lil snackie and settle in.
Its ball time BOI

*** = a change in perspective
*~* = both perspectives at once

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Agatha was pacing around her house, she had already picked out the dress that she was going to wear and knew what she was doing with her hair, so she was just trying to fill the time until she had to get ready. She still had a few hours so she did various bits of cleaning that she had been putting off and got a head start on some of the admin needed for the new semester that started in January.

Jen and Lilia had offered to come over and help her get ready but she turned them down – something she regretted as she was trying to pin her hair up in her bathroom mirror. After some time of fighting with the unruly mane that lived on her head, she was finally happy with it and moved on to her makeup. She wasn’t really one for getting glammed up, nor did she really know what she was doing, so she kept it light. She chose an eyeshadow colour that matched her dress and went with a light lip, finishing with a small amount of blush and highlighter.

The dress that she chose was one that she hadn’t worn in years. It was once a favourite of hers but it had been tainted by bad memories that she was hoping to erase tonight. She slipped it on over her head and tied the halter style neck into a bow at the back, admiring herself in her full length mirror.
The dress stopped just above her ankles and had a slit that went up to the middle of her right thigh. It still clung to her hips the way that it did four years ago and the plunge in the front was modest.
She was happy with her choices and ordered an Uber to take her to the hotel that the ball was being held in. She slipped on a pair of black heels and went outside to wait for the car.

***

Rio, Ash, Billy, Alice and Eddie, all arrived at the hotel to set their instruments up and run through a sound check, around three hours before the event was due to start. They were all half dressed in the clothes they would be wearing later on, and half dressed in comfy clothes so that they wouldn’t have to rush around so much to get ready after the sound check.

Since they had the time, they ran through the setlist in full so they could hear how each song sounded in the room and adjust the levels accordingly.
When they had finished the final song, Ash said, “I don’t want to jinx us, but that might be the best we’ve ever played.”
“Well Ash has now guaranteed that we’ll suck tonight.” Eddie joked.
Rio snorted. “Don’t worry, we can just drown our sorrows afterwards. We’ll still have half an hour of free bar time.”
“What about the free bar time before we play?” Billy asked, only to be immediately followed by the four remaining people saying, “Not for you!” in perfect unison.
With Billy’s incredibly low tolerance, there was no way they were letting him drink before they went on stage. The rest of them though, they would definitely take advantage of the free bar.

They had agreed that they’d all get ready together in the flat that Billy and Alice lived in to make sure that none of them lost track of time and so that they could all arrive together.
The boys and Ash had gone for suits with matching ties, the three of them looked very dapper. Alice had gone for a shirt and skirt combo, keeping it simple whilst still putting in some effort.
When Rio walked into the living room the others were all waiting for her.
“You’re cutting it close, Vidal. The Uber is a minute away.” Eddie said, holding up his phone for her to see.
“Well what are we all standing round for? We have a gig to play.” Rio replied with a smirk and they all headed for the door. 

***

As the taxi pulled up outside the building, Agatha began to feel nervous. She hadn’t attended a university event in nearly three years, she hadn’t spoken to any of the staff members here in nearly three years. And on top of that, there were also students in attendance. The whole evening was set to be a clusterfuck of awkward interactions, but she had committed to it and she wasn’t one to back down.

She thanked the driver and stepped out of the car, taking a deep breath before going up the steps and into the building.
She followed the signs leading to the function room that the university had hired and as she got closer people started to do double takes when they saw her. She heard a few of them whispering to each other as she walked past.
“Is that Agatha?”
“What’s she doing here?”
She ignored them and headed past the bar that was just outside the room. It was swarmed with students that were trying to make the most of the fact that it was free so she decided to find her seat first and let the crowd die down before she got a drink.

There was a board just inside the entrance that showed the seating plan. The tables that were reserved for students were in the front half and the tables for faculty were in the back half. She scanned the board and found her name on table twelve – a table in the back corner of the room – but paused when she saw who she was supposed to be sitting next to.
Was this some kind of sick joke? Had the person that made this seating plan had a stroke half way through? That had to be the explanation. There was no other way that someone could have thought sitting her next to Wanda would be a good fucking idea.

She quickly looked around the room checking to see if Wanda had arrived yet but she saw no sign of her.
Good, there was still time to fix this.
She headed towards her table and found her name card checking her options to see who she could swap with. Her choices were thin, she didn’t want to sit with any of these people, but any of them would be better than sitting next to her ex-fiancée.

She picked up her card and was about to slyly swap it when she heard someone behind her.
“Agatha, is that you?”
She cursed under her breath before placing the card back down, putting on a fake smile and turning towards the voice. It was Dottie Jones, the head of the department.
“It is you! Oh my, it’s wonderful to see you!”
Before she could stop it, she was pulled into a hug. She awkwardly wrapped one arm around Dottie and waited for her to pull back again.
“I can’t believe you came this year, it’s been so long.” Dottie said once she released Agatha.

Agatha made sure to maintain her smile while she spoke. “I figured it had been long enough, it’s about time I reintegrated myself.”
“I couldn’t agree more! And look, we’re sat next to each other.” Dottie pointed to her own name card that was sitting in the place next to Agatha’s.
Agatha did her best to convey happiness in her features. “That’s great, that’ll be one friendly face at least.”
Dottie placed a hand gently on her arm. “Oh you don’t have to worry about that, everyone will be glad to see you.”
Agatha knew that Dottie was just trying to keep the peace but it was a lie, and she was not looking forward to having her every move scrutinised by the people who still carried their vendettas.
Dottie lightly squeezed her arm. “I’m going to say hi to some more people, but we’ll catch up properly later.”
“You bet.” Agatha said as Dottie walked away.

She blew out a breath and dropped her smile. Well she couldn’t swap the name cards now that Dottie had pointed out that they were sitting together could she? She would just have to suck it up, she could do that. With enough alcohol she could definitely give it a good go.
She looked towards the door and saw a group of students walk in, a lot of them already tipsy, and decided to take her chances at the bar.

The crowd had thinned and the remainder parted once they saw her. The corners of her mouth ticked upwards. Her reputation worked off campus it seemed and she still made it to the front of the queue.
She ordered two large glasses of wine and took them back to her table as people continued to filter in.

***

The five band mates arrived at the venue and made a beeline for the bar. As they were waiting in the queue, Rio addressed them. “Okay kids, remember we still have to play so don’t go too hard right now.”
They all looked at Billy who rolled his eyes. “You’re all bullies.”
Four of them ordered two pints each and when Billy’s turn to get served came, he also ordered a pint for himself, much to the displeasure of his friends.
They all groaned.
“This is gonna ruin the tour.” Alice said, pinching the bridge of her nose.
“I can handle one pint you dramatic fucks.” Billy said in an exasperated voice as they walked into the room.

They checked the board to find their table, they were on table one, and went to find their seats.
“Are you sure you can play in those heels?” Ash asked Rio.
Rio pointed at the stage. “I’ve put a pair of Converse next to the kit to change into.”
“And the corset?” Eddie asked with a raised eyebrow.
Rio gestured to her torso. “The corset makes me better actually. I could fight a war in this corset.”
Her phone played the message tone.
Alice looked at her, confused. “Where the fuck did that come from?”
Rio reached below the top edge of the corset and pulled her phone out. “It’s multifunctional.” She said with a smile as she checked her phone.

Wanda: You have no idea what that outfit is doing to me

Rio looked up and craned her neck to sweep her eyes around the room. It took a few seconds but she spotted Wanda at the back of the room, talking to a woman that she didn’t recognise. Wanda wasn’t looking at her, she was just engaged in the conversation.

Rio: You shouldn’t message me things like that when I’m sat next to your son

Rio put her phone face down on the table and tuned back into the conversation her friends were having.
“... remember, the bridge is E minor and B minor twice, then it goes to F and then C.” Eddie was telling Billy.
“Then D minor, B flat, G minor, then A, I know.” He took a swig of his lager. “As long as Rio doesn’t start us off too fast, we’ll be fine.”
“Learn to keep up with me.” Rio said with a smirk.

Out of the corner of her eye, Rio saw a woman walk into the room holding two glasses of red wine. She’s got the right idea she thought and it took her brain a moment to register who she had just seen.
She turned her head in the direction that Agatha was walking and got a strange sense of déjà vu as she watched Agatha make her way to her table, though she couldn’t place what it was in that moment.
Her eyes travelled down Agatha’s back taking in the mark that was on her left shoulder blade. Was that one of her tattoos? Rio had now seen two out of three, but where was the other one?
“A place that you will never see” was what Agatha had said and Rio was sure that she could collect them all if she tried.

Her eyes continued their route downwards to where the dress that Agatha was wearing moulded to her hips before becoming more free-moving thanks to the slit that went up the right side.
“So she’s hot but you're not sleeping with her?” Chloe’s question from over a month ago replayed in Rio’s head. Agatha was definitely hot, so why wasn’t she sleeping with her?
“Earth to Rio.” Alice’s voice brought her out of her thoughts, along with a balled up napkin to her chin. “You’re acting like the distracted boyfriend meme.”
Rio realised that she had been staring at Agatha for longer than could be considered normal. She blinked a couple of times and cleared her throat. “Sorry, what were we talking about?”
Alice laughed and shook her head. “I swear you’re no better than a man. We were talking about the after-party.”
“Rude and I’m not going to the after-party, my flight home is tomorrow morning and I want some sleep before I have to be trapped on a plane for twelve hours.” She took a drink of her pint and cringed at the length of her flight.

Her friends continued to make plans for after the ball and Rio couldn’t resist looking over her shoulder towards Agatha again. Would it be weird if she went to talk to her?
Wait, since when did Rio Vidal overthink talking to an attractive woman?
She pushed her chair back and stood up. “I’ll be back.” She said to the group before setting off in Agatha’s direction.
She heard Eddie say, “Hey Arnold Schwarzenegger, we go on in half an hour, don’t get distracted!” behind her and she waved her hand dismissively.

*~*

Agatha was sitting alone at her table sipping one of her glasses of wine. She had seen Wanda talking to Dottie when she walked back through, but neither of them had approached her yet thank god. She was beginning to regret her decision to come when out of the corner of her eye she saw someone walking towards her. She closed her eyes for a second and took a deep breath, trying to prepare for whatever was about to happen.

“You got me a glass of wine? You shouldn’t have.”
Agatha immediately opened her eyes again as she recognised the voice. The low tone and accent that she had come to enjoy hearing. The constant underlying sarcasm that had once been a source of annoyance but had since started to have the opposite effect. The voice that could only belong to one person.

Rio was casually standing next to her, hands in the pockets of her trousers and a lazy smile on her face. The trousers were loose fitting, the bottoms kept off the floor by a simple pair of black heels. But what caught Agatha’s eye was the top part of Rio’s outfit. A black, over bust corset, with gold vines woven into the brocade. The vines snaked around the corset and disappeared beneath the waist-length black jacket that was sitting on Rio’s shoulders. The top and bottom edges of the corset had a dark green lace that extended just beyond them and the gold studs on the busk glinted as Rio breathed, catching the light. Her hair was in soft waves, falling gently down her back and over her chest.

Agatha’s breath caught in her throat as she took in the person standing before her. This was another dream, it had to be. She would wake up in her bed and it would still be the night before the ball. Of course that would mean that she dreamt about a conversation with Dottie – which would never happen – so maybe this wasn’t a dream. This was really happening. Rio was really standing in front of her, wearing that and making a sarcastic comment about the amount of glasses of wine she had.

Agatha cleared her throat to make her voice work. “It wasn’t my intention, but they’re free so go ahead.” She picked up the full glass and held it out to Rio, doing her best to match Rio’s smile.
Rio wordlessly took the glass. She briefly looked at the liquid and gently swirled it around the glass, smelling it before finally taking a sip. She held the wine in her mouth for a few seconds before swallowing it. “Is that Crianza Rioja?” She asked as she pulled out the chair next to Agatha and sat down.
Agatha lifted her eyebrows in surprise. “It is. How did you know that?”
Rio shrugged. “My parents like their wine. We used to test each other when I was younger, though I’m better with reds than I am whites.” When Agatha’s surprise didn’t falter, she added,  “I told you that Dionysus was too on the nose.” The wine tasting game had started when she was sixteen. That’s when her parents deemed her old enough to start drinking, the legal age limit be damned.

Rio took a proper sip of the wine and put the glass back down on the table. “I expected you to have more expensive taste.” She smirked.
Agatha laughed. “And I expected you to be a lot more inebriated. Are you not taking advantage of the open bar?”
“We’re pacing ourselves. Not every student is solely interested in getting wasted, you know.” She had another drink of the wine.

Agatha rolled her eyes. Of course Rio would have a sarcastic reply to that question, she shouldn’t have expected anything else. She took a sip out of her own glass. Now that Rio was sitting down, Agatha noticed the shimmer around her eyes. A subtle amount of eyeshadow to match the gold pattern on her corset.
She hadn’t thought about what Rio would wear tonight, in fact she’d made a pointed effort to not think about it. Rio had never fully confirmed that she would be here so Agatha didn’t want to get her hopes up. She didn’t want to pin her experience of the night entirely on Rio’s attendance, but now that Rio was here – and it definitely wasn’t a dream – Agatha felt herself relaxing a bit.

Rio shifted slightly in her seat, nudging the chair closer to Agatha by an inch at most. It was subtle, but it was enough that their knees touched and Rio let her leg rest against Agatha’s. “That dress is gorgeous by the way. The colour suits you.”
The compliment, though true, wasn’t intended for any purpose other than being a compliment. She had a feeling that Agatha hadn’t received the warmest reception, and the fact that Agatha was sitting at her table alone whilst everyone else milled about, chatting and mingling, solidified the thought.

Agatha blinked, her brain struggling to register what Rio had said.
Had she just given her a compliment? Why had she just given her a compliment? She should say something back. That’s how normal people behaved.
“You don’t look too bad yourself. I’d ask how you’re functioning in that corset, but I already know that you like tight clothes.”
Rio looked down at herself and then back up to Agatha, giving a light chuckle. “I’m not doing too bad at the moment. Ask me in a bit and I’m sure I’ll be regretting my choices.” She moved the leg that was resting against Agatha’s so that she could point at her shoes. “It’s the heels that might cause the most issues. I don’t know how you do it every day.”
“Oh it takes years of practice and a rigorous training schedule. I can teach you if you like?”
“Nah, I’m good. I’m not insecure about my height.” Rio smiled and pushed her tongue against her cheek, enjoying the way Agatha reacted to her teasing.

Agatha huffed and drank her wine, finishing the glass. “No, you run your mouth enough to make up for what you’re missing height wise.” The corner of her mouth curved upwards slightly, a hint of a smirk.
Rio put her hand on her chest and gasped in feigned offense. “Professor Harkness insulting a student? And in front of all these witnesses as well?” She leaned forwards and dropped her voice, keeping it low and quiet. “You’re quite the rebel.”
Agatha leaned in, dropping her voice as well. “Oh Rio, you have no idea.”

They were now mere inches apart, the noise of chatter around the room seemed to disappear, and Rio’s eyes flicked down to Agatha’s lips. They lingered for a brief moment before flicking back up to Agatha’s eyes. The colour of the dress she was wearing somehow made them brighter, more captivating. The temptation to lean in the remainder of the way was almost too much. For months they had been getting closer. An accidental hand touch here, a flirty comment there. It somehow all felt like it had been leading up to this night.

Agatha felt her pulse spike when she realised just how close she and Rio were and her breathing started to quicken when Rio looked at her lips. It would be so easy to close the gap. It would be so easy to just lean into the remaining space and do what she’d wanted to do for months now. She thought about how Rio’s hair would feel when she wove her fingers into it, how soft Rio’s skin would feel as she cupped her cheek.
They were close enough that Agatha could smell Rio’s perfume. It was the same intoxicating scent that had taken over her senses that day in her office. She wanted to bury her face in Rio’s neck and breathe it in.

Neither of them got a chance to act on their impulses because they were interrupted by Billy appearing at Rio’s shoulder, making both of them jump with his sudden presence. “Rio, we need you dude.”
Rio practically sprang out of the chair. “Right! Just give me one more minute.” Upon seeing the exasperated look Billy gave her, Rio added on, “I’ll be quick, I swear.”
Billy started walking away. “Sixty seconds. I’m counting Vidal.”
Agatha was now standing too, looking thoroughly confused. “What was that about?”
Rio started shrugging off her jacket. “Don’t go anywhere and you’ll see.” She handed her jacket to Agatha. “Can you keep hold of this for me?”
“Sure, but-” Agatha stopped talking as she watched Rio pick up her glass of wine and down the remainder.
“We’ll talk more when I’m back.” Rio spun around and walked with a brisk pace towards the stage where Billy, Alice and some other students that Agatha didn’t really recognise were picking up instruments.

As Rio was walking away, Agatha saw the tattoo that Rio had mentioned was on her back. Extending past the corset, and curling so that it stopped on her shoulder blades, were the lines of a vine with some leaves sprouting off of it. Did it go down the full length of her spine?
Agatha sat back down in her seat, laying Rio’s jacket over her lap. She subconsciously reached for her glass only to be disappointed when she remembered that she had finished it. She wanted to go get another but Rio had asked her to stay so stay she would.

She barely registered the person who sat on her left, eyes still on Rio as she sat behind the drum kit. Since when did Rio play drums? Since when was Rio in a band with Alice and Billy?
A realisation dawned on her. Rio had said that four other people had mentioned the ball to her, there were four other people in the band. Agatha wouldn’t have any trouble being at the front of the line because the line consisted of her friends.
Agatha had been jealous of undergraduate students, one of which had basically been her son for four years. Oh she was stupid.

“I’ve been looking forward to this.” The person sitting next to her said, snapping her from her thoughts.
Agatha turned her head towards the person and rolled her eyes when she saw who it was. “What do you want, Wanda?”
“I want to watch my son play the songs that he’s been rehearsing for months.” She slid a glass of wine across the table towards Agatha. “The son that thinks we’ve reached a point of civility, so please afford me the next half an hour of pretending that you don’t still hate me.”
Agatha considered it for a moment before picking up the glass and taking a sip. She could survive thirty minutes for Billy.

Rio had changed into her sneakers, feeling the familiar grip that her converse gave her on the pedals, and was waiting for Eddie’s signal to start the drum fill that began Call Me.
She spared a glance in Agatha’s direction and was surprised to see Wanda sitting next to her, giving her a glass of wine.
Eddie addressed the room. “Good evening Cambridge University Ancient History department!” There was a cheer from the students and some of the staff. “I hope you’ve all been making use of the free bar, it’ll make us sound better than we actually are.” Laughter rippled through the crowd. “You’ve got us for the next half an hour and our first song is our drummer’s anthem so make sure you take her up on it.” He looked over his shoulder and winked at Rio.
He’d promised that he wouldn’t actually say that, dickhead.
Rio mouthed ‘fuck you’ before playing the triplet fill that opened the song.

***

Agatha gave a small laugh at the joke Eddie made once she recognised the song. It was very Rio to ask him to say that. Maybe she would have to make sure she was first in line after all.
When the song reached the bridge, Wanda said, “I have to admit, they’re better than I thought they would be.”
