“I didn’t think, I-”
“No you fucking didn’t. It’s illegal here, Eddie. These guys aren’t going to risk being caught out. You put Billy in real danger, do you understand that? If I hadn’t been there, who the fuck knows what might have happened. He could have been killed!” She scowled at Eddie, his idiocy was astounding.

Eddie dropped his gaze, now looking at the carpet. “I know.” He said quietly. “I told Billy to use my name, I thought that would be enough. I didn’t know they’d do that.”
Rio breathed out heavily through her nose. “You should have told them.” She went to run her hands down her face, but stopped herself just in time before she basically slapped her wound.
She crunched her hands into fists and said, “Get some rest and be fucking smarter in future.”

She didn’t wait for a reply before she left the room and headed for the lift.
Feeling her phone buzz in her pocket, she pulled it out.

Agatha: Did you get lost?

Shit.
She was supposed to be on her way to Agatha’s nearly an hour ago.
She knew that she should go home, she knew that she needed to go to bed and rest.
But there was a part of her that wanted Agatha.
She didn’t know exactly what she wanted from Agatha, she just knew that she wanted to be with her.
And that part of her won out.

She booked her Uber as she was walking towards the main road and met the driver there.
As she was sitting in the back of the car she pulled out some of the toilet paper that she’d shoved into her pocket and dabbed at her face again. Fresh blood stained the white and she leaned her head back until the driver pulled up outside of Agatha’s house.

She thanked him and stood at Agatha’s front door, dabbing her face one last time for good measure before she stuffed the tissue back into her pocket and rapped her knuckles against the door.
It only took a moment before Agatha opened it.
“About fucking time- Rio, what happened?”
The annoyance that was initially on Agatha’s face morphed into something far worse.
Worry.

Rio did her best to smirk, to mask the way her head was pounding, to hide the way Agatha’s reaction made her chest ache. “You should see the other guy.” She said, forcing smugness into her voice.
Agatha stepped aside to let her in and shut the door behind them. “No, don’t do that. Tell me what happened.”
She moved so that she was in front of Rio again, facing her. She reached out towards Rio’s face but Rio held her hand to stop her.
“I’m fine.” The words were starting to lose meaning now.

Agatha pulled her hand from Rio’s. “You’re not fine. You need to go to the hospital.”
Rio sighed. Why was everyone being so damn dramatic? “I don’t need to go to the hospital, it’s just a cut.”
“Rio you could have concussion, the bone could be broken, you might permanently lose your vision in that eye!”
Rio took a step towards Agatha, reaching for her hand again. “Look, it’s sweet that you care this much, but I’m okay, I promise.” Agatha let her link their fingers.

“If you won’t go to the hospital then at least let me clean it.” Agatha changed the grip Rio had on her hand so that she could lead her to the living room. She pointed to the sofa. “Sit. Wait.”
Rio rolled her eyes and immediately grimaced at how much that simple movement hurt.
Agatha’s eyes flashed with something that Rio couldn’t place as she sat on the couch.

Agatha hurried off somewhere else in the house and left Rio for a few minutes before she returned with a glass of water, some painkillers and a medium sized, square tin and sat next to Rio.
Rio looked at it and raised an eyebrow. “You’ve brought me shortbread?”
Agatha didn’t react, she just handed Rio the water and drugs, took the lid off the tin and put it on Rio’s knee.

Rio took the painkillers, put the glass on the coffee table and looked down at the contents of the tin as Agatha started to rifle through it.
There were gauze bandages, plasters of various shapes and sizes, antiseptic wipes, steristips and a myriad of other first aid items.
“Damn, were you an army medic in a past life?”
“I got my fair share of cuts and scrapes as a child, I learned to keep these things handy.”

Agatha gently held Rio’s chin and tilted her head so that she could see her eye better. “Tell me properly, what happened?”
Rio drew in a breath through her teeth as Agatha gently pressed around the cut. “Drug deal gone bad.” She gritted out as Agatha continued feeling around the wound.
“Rio.” Agatha sighed and Rio could hear the warning in her voice. This wasn’t a laughing matter, she was genuinely concerned.

The traitor that lived in Rio’s chest constricted and she swallowed thickly. “Billy was buying weed and-”
“Billy was buying drugs?”
Agatha’s eyes were no longer focussed around Rio’s eyes, they were looking directly into them. “What happened?” She asked again, firmer this time.

Rio saw the way Agatha’s eyes were shining, she was panicked now and Rio could tell that she was trying to hide it. Afterall, Rio was only supposed to know that Billy was Agatha’s student and nothing more.

“Billy was buying weed and he was a little worried about it because he’d never picked up before. So he texted me, letting me know where he was. I went to meet him and when I got there, three guys were crowding him.” She saw Agatha’s eyes widen, but nothing else on her face moved. “There was a scuffle, I got a few good hits in before they managed to land one on me. Billy managed to trip one of the guys and we got out.”

Agatha took a shaky breath. “And Billy, is he…”
Rio took one of Agatha’s hands and squeezed it, offering comfort. “He’s a little shaken, but he’s totally fine. He’s with Eddie.”
Agatha exhaled slowly and closed her eyes. She squeezed Rio’s hand back briefly before pulling it out of Rio’s grasp to rifle through the makeshift first aid kit again.

Rio watched her pick out a couple of the antiseptic wipes and a pack of steristrips, her hands were shaking. It was subtle but Rio noticed.
“Hey.” She said softly, holding both of Agatha’s hands this time. She could feel them trembling. “Who is Billy to you?”
Rio knew now, but she wanted to give Agatha the chance to tell her. And she figured that Agatha’s reaction was a good enough excuse to ask.

Agatha looked up at her and swallowed. “He- He was-” She let out a breath and looked back down at their hands. “He’s Wanda’s son.” She said softly, quietly. Almost like she regretted it being the truth.
Rio nodded. This wasn’t information that she didn’t already know and she knew that Agatha knew that too.
“I know. Who is he to you?” She asked the question again as gently as she could, acting as if Agatha were an animal that might spook if she spoke too loudly.

Agatha pulled her hands free and picked up one of the antiseptic wipes, ripping open the paper packaging. “This is gonna sting.” She said as she raised the wipe to Rio’s cut.
She was avoiding the question, but Rio wasn’t going to push right now.
Agatha pressed the wipe to Rio’s skin and the damp coolness of it felt comforting against the angry warmth of the area, until she moved it directly over the abrasion.

Agatha wasn’t kidding, the sting was instant and Rio ground her teeth to stop herself from crying out at it.
She noticed the small smile that Agatha was now wearing. “I’m glad you’re enjoying this.”
The smile grew wider. “It’s nice to know that you can feel.”
That hit her in the gut. The implications and deeper meanings behind the words buried their way under her skin and settled behind her rib cage.

But she didn’t want to unpack that right now. So instead she narrowed her eyes. “If I wasn’t mortally wounded right now, I’d be offended.”
Agatha chuckled softly and continued to carefully clean the cut. “It doesn’t look like it’s too deep, I don’t think you’ll need stitches.”
“Thank you for your expertise, Doctor Harkness.” Rio said and it was immediately followed by a hiss of pain as Agatha pressed a little harder against her eye. That was definitely on purpose.

Agatha opened the second wipe and began cleaning the area around the cut. “This bruise is gonna be fantastic, it’s already starting to come through.”
“Oh yeah? Do you like a woman who can take a punch?” Rio tried to wiggle her eyebrows and instantly knew it was a bad decision.
Agatha smiled. “I like a woman who’s smart enough to not have to take a punch.”
Rio smiled too and they stayed silent for a little while.

It was only as Agatha was laying the third steristrip did she break the silence.
“We lived together, Wanda, Billy and I.” Her voice was soft and Rio stayed perfectly still as if moving would alert Agatha to the fact that she’d spoken out loud.
“I was engaged to Wanda and we were a family.” She gently placed the fourth steristip on Rio’s skin. “Billy was never truly mine, but he felt as good as. That’s who he is to me.”
Rio nodded. “Okay.”

They fell back into silence as Agatha laid the final few steristrips over the cut and she leant back to survey her work. “You’ll live.”
The corners of Rio’s mouth twitched with a smile that wasn't quite ready to make itself known, not until she said the thing that was begging to be said out loud.
“There’s nothing going on between me and Wanda.” The words came out a little rushed, but there were no regrets about them.

Agatha looked taken aback by the sudden confession, her lips parted by the small gasp she took. She closed her mouth again and her eyes moved about the room before landing back on Rio. “What about before?”
Rio swallowed. This was a conversation they needed to have, it was a conversation that she had started, but it didn’t make her any less nervous.
She took a breath to steady herself. “Yes. Last year before we… before the ball. We had a casual arrangement. She tried to come onto me at the ball but I turned her down. I didn’t want her.”

Agatha’s eyes were shining, there was something like apprehension mixed with relief on her face. “What about after the ball?”
Rio shook her head, she was trying to work out if she should mention Kate. Was it even relevant when Wanda was the one that Agatha was clearly hurt by?
Rio ultimately decided that full honesty was the best course of action.
“Not Wanda, but there was one person back home that I slept with. But it didn’t- she wasn’t-” Rio sighed knowing no excuse would be good enough. “She was just there.”

Agatha’s head dipped, looking at her knees. “Was I just there?” Her voice was impossibly small. It was like she was hoping she could say it so quietly, so timidly, that Rio wouldn’t notice.
But she did, and the sadness in Agatha’s voice made Rio's stomach twist.
She cast her mind back to the first night that she’d left Agatha’s house. The feeling that something wasn’t quite right hadn’t hit her like it usually did, she had already come to that realisation.
She knew that the way she felt when she left Agatha now was different. It still felt wrong, but that’s because it was wrong.
The fact that she was leaving was wrong, not the person she was leaving.

Rio pulled her bottom lip between her teeth and chewed it for a moment. “No.” She breathed out, barely a whisper. “I think you were inevitable.”
She watched Agatha’s lips part and close again a few times, until she reached out and cradled her left cheek, the one that wasn’t hurt. She still didn’t say anything, instead she leant in and pressed their lips together.

Rio’s chest felt tight.
Agatha’s tenderness and worry.
The closeness.
The confessions.
It all felt too much.

It felt like it was pressing down on her, making it hard to breathe.
She needed to leave, she needed to clear her head so that she could think about this clearly and calmly.
She needed her head to not be clouded by the pain and everything else that had happened tonight.

She curled her fingers around Agatha’s wrist. She could feel her pulse, steady, grounding.
A reminder that this was real.
And that made it worse.

Rio pulled away. “I should go. I’ve taken enough of your time.”
She moved to stand and got half way up before Agatha tugged her back down again. “Wait, no. Stay. You shouldn’t be alone tonight. Someone needs to keep an eye on you.”
Rio looked at the hand that was now resting on her bicep and covered it with her own. “I don’t want to burden you with that.”
Agatha shook her head. “You won’t be a burden. Just let me look after you. Please?”

Rio chewed on the corner of her lip. “I don’t have anything to sleep in.” It was a weak excuse. A feeble thing that held no weight. And, judging by the small smile that was on Agatha’s face, she knew that too.
“I can find you some pyjamas.”
Rio was out of reasons not to stay, so she nodded.

They both stood from the couch and Agatha went to the kitchen to refill the glass of water before taking it and the painkillers upstairs.
“You can take some steristrips and wipes with you in the morning so that you can keep it clean and re-dress it.”
Rio agreed and Agatha handed her an old t-shirt and some pyjama bottoms to change into.
“There’s a spare toothbrush and toothpaste in the bathroom down the hall.”

Rio went to the bathroom and got changed.
She looked in the mirror and inspected her face. Her eye had started to swell and there was a deep purple now colouring the skin.
She touched the edge of it and winced.
Why did she keep doing that?

She looked at the cut itself.
It was no longer bleeding and the seven steristrips that Agatha had placed with such care were all perfectly spaced, holding the cut closed so that it could heal.

She brushed her teeth and folded her clothes to take them to Agatha’s bedroom with her. But that gave her pause.
Was it presumptuous to think she would be sleeping in Agatha’s bed?
Should she ask if she was to take the spare room, or go back down to the settee?

She knocked on Agatha’s bedroom door and walked in when Agatha gave her okay.
Agatha was already in bed, a lamp casting a warm, yellow glow over the room.
Rio shuffled her feet awkwardly. “I, uh, am I in the spare room? Or on the couch?”

Agatha’s brows furrowed in confusion as she pulled back the quilt to reveal the other side of the bed. “I can’t keep an eye on you if you’re in a different part of the house.” She smiled briefly before it dropped and she looked worried again. “Unless you’d prefer to sleep in the spare room. I’m not going to force you to sleep next to me if you’re not comfortable with that.”

“No, no, it’s fine. I just didn’t want to overstep.” Rio said as she put her clothes on the chair at Agatha’s dresser.
“You’re not, don’t worry.”
Rio crawled into the bed.
The bed that she had been face down on, and had Agatha face down on, many times.
The bed that had supported them through various positions, both rough and gentle.
The bed that now felt strangely foreign as Agatha brought the quilt back to cover Rio’s body.

Rio turned her head towards Agatha, careful to not let that side of her face touch the pillow too much to avoid the inevitable pain it would cause.
“Thank you, Agatha. Goodnight.”
Agatha smiled. “Goodnight, Rio. Please don’t hesitate to wake me if you need anything.”
Rio nodded and turned over so that she was laying on her left side.
Her shoulder felt a little sore from where she was thrown into the wall, but it was better than her face currently was.

Seventeen days of just sex and now one where they just slept, side by side.

__________

Rio woke in the morning to a warm feeling against her neck and a soft weight around her middle. It took her a second to register what each thing was.
Agatha must have shuffled closer to her in the night because her face was pressed against the back of her neck and her arm was slung over her waist.

She laid there, frozen in her realisation.
The intimacy in it made her blood run cold.
The last time she woke up next to someone it had been Wanda, and that had been after a night of heavy drinking and steamy sex.
Not after a night that had felt so charged and so full.

The pain started to press into her head again, heavy and sharp. She screwed her eyes shut, trying to block it out, but that only made it worse.
She gently lifted Agatha’s arm and slipped out of the covers, careful not to wake the sleeping woman beside her.
Agatha made a soft noise and Rio froze again. But Agatha remained asleep so Rio quietly took the pills that Agatha had left out for her, chasing them with the water that had gone lukewarm in the night.

She padded over to the chair where she had left her clothes the night before and picked them up to take them to the spare bathroom so that she could change.
The bright light of the bathroom made the pounding in her head worse, so she brushed her teeth and got dressed as quickly as she could.

She folded the pyjamas that Agatha had let her borrow and put them on the landing outside of the bedroom door.
She stood looking at them for a few minutes before she sighed and picked them back up, taking them into the room and putting them on the foot of the bed instead.

Agatha was still fast asleep, having rolled more onto her front now that Rio’s body wasn’t there to keep her propped up, her arm slightly outstretched as if she were searching for her.
Rio watched her for a moment, watched the steady rise and fall of her shoulders in time with her breaths.
The alarm clock on Agatha’s bedside table showed 8:37AM.
It would be going off soon to wake Agatha so that she could get into work in time for her first lecture.

Rio thought about staying. She thought about going downstairs and making them both some coffee, maybe throwing something together for a quick breakfast. But those thoughts made her breathing become shallow and difficult.
She dug her teeth into her bottom lip, trying to steady herself.

The admissions that had been exchanged between them the previous night still hung in the air. They were waiting to settle, to turn into something, to change them. But Rio couldn’t fathom that right now.
She needed to think.
She needed to go over everything and figure it all out.

She left the room and closed the door softly before heading downstairs.
She thought about leaving a note, but what would she even say?
Also a note seemed too outdated, she could just send a text that Agatha would see when she woke up.

She noticed the tin with the first aid supplies in it still open and on the couch. Agatha had mentioned letting her take some stuff so that she could keep her wound clean, so she took a few wipes and one of the boxes of steristrips and shoved them into the pocket of her jeans.

She pulled her phone out of her pocket where it had been all night.
There were some messages from Billy, but she only had ten percent battery so she prioritised ordering a cab over reading them.
She closed the door behind her as quietly as she could, not wanting to make any noise that could wake Agatha before her alarm did its job.
As her car pulled up, she typed out a message to Agatha.

Rio: Thank you for last night. Didn’t want you to feel like you had to stay home today to look after me so I’ve gone home
Thank you again

She hit send before she could overthink it and slipped into the back of her Uber.

Once the car had pulled away, she opened Billy’s messages.

Billy: Are you okay? I’m so so sorry!
Billy: Did you make it home okay?
Billy: Rio please let me know you’re alive
Billy: Did you go to the hospital?
Billy: Rio please! Any sign of life at all

She sighed and tapped out her reply.

Rio: Yes I’m alive, sorry. I’ve just woken up but don’t think I’ll stay this way for long. Gonna give today a miss for obvious reasons, and you should too. I’ll hopefully see you on Sunday!

Billy: Oh thank god! Yeah Eddie and Alice are staying home with me see you on Sunday!

She gave a small smile, glad that Billy had people around him to support him.
She briefly wondered if she should tell Wanda but figured that it wasn’t her place and Billy should tell her himself.

She thanked the driver when he pulled up outside her building and took herself up to her apartment.
She put her phone on charge and messaged Maddy, asking her to call her when she was on her lunch break and then made a beeline for her bathroom, peeling off her clothes and gently removing the steristrips around her eye.
She got straight into the shower, carefully making sure the water wasn’t too hot and washed the previous night from her body.

She patted the area around her eye dry with her towel and replaced the steristrips.
She wasn’t as precise as Agatha had been but it would do the job.
She pulled her pyjamas on and crawled into bed, sleep overtaking her almost instantly.

She only woke when there was an insistent buzzing sound that broke through her dream of soft, blue eyes and wild brown hair.
She cracked one eye open and turned to the source of the noise.
It was her phone letting her know that there was an incoming facetime call.

She squinted at the bright screen. Surely she hadn’t slept long enough for Maddy to be on her lunch break already.
She checked the time and did the maths in her head. It was only eight o’clock in Virginia, why was Maddy ringing her now?

She accepted the call and saw her best friend's face appear before her.

“Jesus what the fuck happened to you?” Maddy asked immediately.
Rio looked at herself in the window in the top corner of the screen. The bruise was somehow darker and bigger, the skin puffier than it was a few hours ago. “I got into a fight.” She groaned, her voice raspy from sleep.
“Ah, did you jump to a fair maiden's defense?”
Rio snorted. “More like a lanky twink who was trying to buy weed.” She said with a wince as the pain in her head started to surface again.

Maddy grimaced. “Shit. Got into it with some drug dealers, huh? That’s stupid, even for you.”
Rio forced herself to get out of bed so that she could take some painkillers. “Your concern for my wellbeing astounds me.”
“Well are you dying? Is this the last conversation we’ll ever have?”
Rio shuffled back into bed and leaned back against the headboard. “Unfortunately for you, I’m not dying any time soon.”
“Well there you go then. No need for concern.”

Rio shook her head and laughed softly. “Why are you calling me now? Shouldn’t you be going into work?”
Maddy smirked. “When I saw your message, I rang in sick. Figured if you were actually asking me to call you then it must be important.”
Rio smiled. “You just take any excuse to not go to work.”
“Hey, don’t diminish my love for you.” Maddy said with a frown as she pointed at Rio through the screen.

“You’re right, I’m sorry. Thank you for risking your employment to help little old me.”
“Better. Now what is it exactly that you need my help with?”
Rio sighed. How did she even begin to explain this?

She shuffled again, arranging her pillows behind her so that she wasn’t at such an odd angle.“I might be… in trouble.”
Maddy raised a single eyebrow. “In trouble with the drug dealers?”
“What? Oh, no. In trouble with, uh, a woman.”
Maddy leaned closer to the camera. “Elaborate.”

“Do you remember I told you about my supervisor?”
“The one you banged?”
Rio rolled her eyes. “Yes. The one I banged.”
“Uh huh, I’m familiar. Go on.”
Rio took a breath. “When I came back from Christmas break, I slept with her again. And I kept sleeping with her. Every day. For almost three weeks. Last night was the first time since I got back that we didn’t have sex.” The distinction was important because last night was the first time that they had actually slept together.

“Because you got your ass handed to you.” Maddy said. A statement, not a question.
“I did not get my ass handed to me.”
“Sure looks like you did.”
“This was the only hit they landed on me actually.”
There was no need to mention the second bruise on her leg from where she got kicked, or the twinge in her shoulder from where he was thrown into the wall.

Maddy put her hand up. “Okay, okay, we’re getting off track.”
Rio scoffed. “You’re the one that took us off track.”
“So I’m putting us back. It’s not like you’ve never slept with the same person more than once before. I mean sure, every day for three weeks is excessive, but if you both know what the deal is, then what’s the problem?”

Rio closed her eyes for a second, preparing her next words. “The problem is that I’m not sure I know what the deal is anymore.”
Maddy’s brows shot up. “Is Rio Vidal developing feelings for a woman? Hang on a sec, I gotta see if there's pigs flying past my window.”
“Asshole.” Rio muttered when Maddy actually went to look out of a window.

Maddy shook her head. “Nope. No pigs.” She flopped back down onto her couch. “So what is it about this particular woman that’s bringing some colour back to the blackened heart of yours?”
“I have no fucking idea, dude.” Rio leaned her head back against the headboard. “All I know is that it got harder and harder to walk away from her, or watch her walk away from me, at the end of each night. And last night, after getting Billy home safely, I still went round to hers. But not for sex, not at that point. I just wanted to be near her, be in the same room as her.” She groaned.

Maddy’s face softened, the teasing eyebrow raises and smirks vanishing. “Okay. Start from the beginning. Tell me about her.”

Rio started from the day she met Agatha. 

That very first lecture when she spoke out and got Agatha's attention.
Then when she sent in her new proposal whilst half torn and Agatha had let her get away with it with barely a slap on the wrist.

She remembered the time that they had an argument – their first, she told Maddy – and how she'd managed to get Agatha to open up just the smallest amount that day.

She mentioned Wanda and told Maddy all the ins and outs of that whole situation, assuring her that it was relevant when Maddy accused her of trying to avoid the subject.
She did enjoy the shocked look Maddy gave her when she tied it back into Agatha.

“Wait, hang on. Just let me get my head round this.” Maddy put her hand up to stop Rio. “You became friends with Billy whose mom is a lecturer at your university, you didn't know she was his mom and started sleeping with her. Then you found out that she was his mom when he caught the two of you in her house, slept with her a few more times then decided you couldn't deal. You then started sleeping with your supervisor who just so happens to be the ex-fiancée of the lecturer you were sleeping with and a sort of step-mom to Billy?”

“That would be correct, but I’m actually getting ahead of myself.”
“Well what the fuck are you doing that for? Chronological order, please!”
Rio flipped Maddy the bird before picking back up.

She recounted with precision the times that she’d caught Agatha staring at her – a precision that she surprised herself with.
Her memory was good, there was no denying that, but she didn’t think it was good enough to remember things like that. Not that long ago anyway.
But remember she did, and her smile grew a little at each one.

She told Maddy about reading The Odyssey for the first time in front of Agatha and how she noticed Agatha barely holding back from asking her what she thought of the book every time she turned the page.
And then she spoke about the dog-ear incident; that made Maddy jump in again.

“No, I'm gonna have to stop you. Rio Vidal, you cannot be with a woman who sees her ass about folding the corner of a page to keep your place. You’re too carefree for that.”
Rio laughed at the memory. “Look, I will admit that it pissed me off at the time. But now I think it’s kinda… cute?”
“Cute?” Maddy echoed in disbelief. Her eyebrows were somehow scrunched and raised at the same time, like her face couldn’t pick an emotion.
“She’s passionate.” Rio said with a shrug, wincing slightly at the ache in her shoulder.

Maddy grunted but she didn’t say anything else so Rio continued.
She talked about Agatha’s random choice to cut off their weekly meetings and the conversation that Rio had forced on her about it, which ultimately led nowhere, and how they had reconvened after a while, how they had gotten closer.
The Agatha she knew now was totally different to the Agatha she knew back then, and it had only been a handful of months.

She wasn’t rough and abrasive, she was softer – at least with her.
She still didn’t suffer fools, but that wasn’t a trait that Rio would ever change.
Rio liked that Agatha was opinionated and wasn’t afraid to voice them. She liked the fact that Agatha could command a room and have them hanging on her every word. She liked that Agatha didn’t let the Dean talk down to her, but she didn’t like the reasons that he did.

She didn’t like that Agatha was a social outcast in her own workplace. She didn’t like how Agatha was made to feel like her every move was scrutinised by Wanda’s army of minions, just waiting for something to be enough that the Dean could fire her and ruin her career… her life.
She didn’t like that Agatha had no one in her corner, no one to fight for her, no one to fight with her.
Rio wanted to be that.

“Hey.” Maddy’s soft voice brought Rio out of her thoughts. “As nice as it is to watch you stare into space, I can’t read your thoughts. Out loud please.”
Rio breathed out a laugh, she hadn't even realised she’d gotten lost in her own head. “My apologies. That basically takes us up to the ball which is the night we first slept together.”
“That’s it? That’s all you’re giving me on that? Where’s the lead up, the suspense, the ‘will they won’t they’?”
“Jesus Christ.” Rio sighed. “We talked, we flirted, she bought the most expensive bottle of wine that the venue had. We almost kissed but were interrupted and then I walked her home. I’m sure you can figure out the rest.” She rubbed her eyes and hurled out a string of profanities when she pressed onto her right eye.

Maddy was smirking when she opened her eyes again. “So your response to this months long flirtationship and eventual sex was to go home and sleep with Kate?”
Rio’s eyes went wide, pain forgotten as her blood started to cool in her veins. “How did you-?”
“She told me.” Maddy said smoothly. “After you left. And you can relax, I’m not mad. I just didn’t want Kate to get hurt, but she was fine actually so you’ve escaped my wrath.”

“Oh thank god.” Rio said with a breath of relief.
Maddy smiled. “Okay, so you left her and went home for Christmas, slept with someone else, and then came back to England and slept with no one except her?”
Rio nodded. “That about covers it, yeah.”
“Does Agatha know about your many exploits?”
“She knows about Wanda and Kate, but that’s it. They’re the only two that are relevant really.”

Maddy hummed and thought for a moment before saying, “And what about now?”
Rio dipped her brows. “What do you mean?”
“Do you want to sleep with someone who isn’t her?”
Rio’s head began to swim at that question.

Did she want to sleep with anyone who wasn’t Agatha?
The simple answer was no, but this wasn’t simple.
Should she sleep with someone who wasn’t Agatha? Yes, absolutely.
If she did that then maybe her brain would reset itself and these feelings – whatever they were – would go away.
It was more than likely that the only reason she felt this way right now was because she hadn’t slept with anyone else.
Maybe she should just do it and see what happened.

“Out loud, please.” Maddy prompted after a minute of Rio being silent.
She sighed, long and drawn out. “It’s not that simple, Maddy.”
“It couldn’t be any simpler. Do you want to have sex with anyone else?” Maddy repeated the question like Rio was being dumb. And maybe she was.

Rio leaned her head back against the headboard and closed her eyes. “No, I don't want to sleep with anyone else. But I know that I should.”
“No seas un maldito idiota.” Don't be a fucking idiot.
Rio cracked one eye open and looked back down at her phone. “Hey, your Spanish is improving."
“Don’t change the subject. How are you so academically proficient but this fucking stupid?”

Rio opened both eyes now. “I have a head injury.”
“You are a head injury.” Maddy shot back. “You like this woman and it sounds like she likes you, why the fuck would you mess that up by convincing yourself that you need to have sex with someone else? Look, I know you’ve been hurt in the past, I’m not diminishing that, but you need to think about this. Really think about it, before you ruin it.”

Maddy let Rio sit with that for a minute before continuing. “You said you still went to Agatha’s house after being beaten up – and don’t try to tell me they only got one hit in, I’ve seen you wincing every time you move your shoulder. What did you go to her for if it wasn’t sex? Why would she be the person you choose to go to instead of going home? What happened while you were there?”

Rio moved her pillows around so that she could sit up straighter, but also so that she had a moment to gather her thoughts and answer Maddy’s questions.
She knew deep down that sleeping with someone else wouldn’t help. It wouldn’t fix her. It wouldn’t change the fact that Agatha was always on her mind.
But that didn’t stop the thought from nagging at her.

She responded when she was settled again. “I told you earlier that I went to her because I wanted to be near her. I don’t know, I just felt like that’s where I wanted to be. Where I needed to be. It felt… It felt safe.” She groaned. “Fucking hell, when did I become like this?”
“Like someone who feels human emotions? No idea dude, but you’re one of us now. So what happened while you were there?”

“When I got there she was immediately worried and tried to take me to the hospital but I refused. I didn’t want to waste time and resources when I knew I didn’t need it. So instead we went to the couch, she gave me some painkillers and she cleaned the cut. Turns out she has an entire hospital's worth of first aid supplies, so I didn’t even need to go anyway. She put some of these fancy band-aids on,” Rio pointed to the steristrips, “and we talked a little bit.”
Maddy didn’t say anything, she just gestured for Rio to continue.

“We talked about Billy and who he is to Agatha. She told me that she and Wanda were engaged at one point and that the three of them lived together. I’d already figured that out but I wanted her to feel like she could tell me, I wanted her to know that she can trust me.
Then I told her that I’d been sleeping with Wanda but hadn’t since before the ball, and no longer wanted to. She asked me if I’d slept with anyone else since the ball, which is when I told her about Kate.”

Maddy hummed in the silence that Rio left. “What did she say to that?”
“Not much actually. She just kissed me and asked me to stay so that she could make sure I was okay through the night.” Rio was absolutely omitting the fact that she’d told Agatha she was inevitable. Maddy would never let her hear the end of it.

“She gave me some clothes to sleep in and we slept in her bed. That’s the first time I’ve actually spent the night. The first time we had clothes on.
We weren’t touching when we went to sleep, but when I woke up she was pressed into my back and her arm was around me, still asleep.”

Maddy leaned closer to the camera. “And then?”
Rio dropped her eyes, not wanting to see Maddy’s reaction to what she said next. “And then I left before she woke up.”
“¡Eres un completo imbécil!” You absolute fucking moron!
Rio didn’t need to see Maddy’s face to know that she was furious with her.

“After all that, you fucking left her? While she was still asleep? Not even a thank you and a goodbye? Don’t piss me off!” Maddy was shouting now.
“I texted her.” Rio said quietly, guilt now sitting heavily on top of her.
“Oh, you texted her? You texted her thinking that would make up for her waking up expecting you to be there? You’re so fucking stupid oh my god!”

Rio heard a thud and gingerly looked up. Maddy had thrown her phone down, no doubt pacing around her living room.
Rio deserved this. She deserved her best friend calling her stupid, a moron, an idiot. Because she was. And she knew she was.

She knew the second Agatha’s front door had closed behind her that she’d fucked up.
“Waking up like that, with her so close, with her holding me, it scared me. I didn’t want to leave. I nearly started making us some breakfast, but then I panicked. I needed to get out and clear my head so that I could think clearly about it. I needed to talk it out with you.”

Maddy picked her phone back up. “Okay. What do you need to talk about? Because it’s pretty clear to me that you like this woman but you’re scared of getting hurt. And again, I totally get that, but you can’t run from it your entire life.”
Rio sighed and ran her hand through her hair. “How do I stop being so scared? How do I make this work? How do I not fuck this up. I mean, more than I already have.”

Maddy’s face softened, the sharp edges of her frustration dulling. “You want the truth?”
Rio nodded.
“I don’t think you’ll ever stop being scared. And that’s okay because it means you care. It means that you want it to work, but in order to do that you have to put the effort in. You have to work through the difficult patches, hold each other through the harder parts so that you can enjoy the good. So that the good can become great.
There will be times when you fuck up, when both of you do, but that’s all part of it. As long as you’re still there afterwards, that’s all that matters. I know that you know all of this, but I hope that hearing it out loud helps.”

Rio smiled. It was small but it was real.
Maddy’s words landed exactly where she needed them to, they warmed the parts of her that had been left without attention for too long.
“Okay.” She said quietly. “You’re right. I can’t let some failed relationships and bad break ups haunt me forever.”
“Halle-fucking-lujah! Now go to her!”

Rio laughed. “I can’t she’s at work.”
Maddy pointed at her. “Rio Isabella Vidal, if you don’t go to this woman and grovel at her feet so help me god!”
“Can I at least wait until my head doesn’t feel like it’s being split open from the inside?” Rio basically whined.
Maddy narrowed her eyes. “I suppose I can allow that.”

They spoke for a few more hours and Rio eventually left her bed, carefully cleaning her face while Maddy bullied her for being in love with her lecturer – Rio’s explanation of not technically being one of Agatha’s students falling on deaf ears.

They fired up their playstations and played a game whilst they talked and Rio gave Maddy the run down of the Gabriela and Jason break up.
Maddy was just as shocked as everybody else had been and wasn’t at all surprised when Rio told her that her abuela had called her to shout at her about it.

They hung up in the early evening and Rio’s stomach grumbled, reminding her that she hadn’t eaten all day.
She couldn’t face cooking right now so she picked her phone back up to order food and noticed a WhatsApp notification.
The message must have come through while she was still asleep because she didn’t notice it whilst she was on facetime to Maddy.

She opened the app and saw that it was from Agatha, then checked the time it had been sent: 9:12 am.
Shit.
She’d been so focused on the call with Maddy that she hadn’t checked anything else.
Agatha was probably panicking thinking that Rio was ignoring her after they’d shared a bed for the first time.
She opened the message.

Agatha: I wish you’d woken me up, I panicked when you weren’t there and searched the house in case you’d collapsed somewhere! I wouldn’t have been able to stay home with that little notice, but we could have worked something out. Let me know if you need anything today, I mean it. Anything at all. Even if it’s just someone being there. Get some rest and let me know when you’re awake

Rio read the message. Then she read it again, and again.
Agatha had panicked when she’d woken up alone.
Agatha had been scared that Rio had collapsed somewhere in her house and she wasn’t there to help her.
And Rio had let the message go unanswered for over eight hours.

Rio: Sorry I’ve only just seen this. I woke up around 1 and then was on the phone to my friend until now! I didn’t mean to scare you, I’m sorry. I didn’t think about how you would feel when you woke up and I should have.
I’ve rested, cleaned my eye again and put more band-aids on it and now I’m gonna order food so I’m all good

She thought about how she would have felt if it was the other way around. If she had been the one to wake up expecting Agatha to be there laying next to her, but instead it was just empty space.
A fresh layer of guilt wrapped around her, crawling up her legs, wrapping around her arms, constricting her chest.

Her entire body felt heavy and even the thought of moving her limbs was too much.
Her head hurt again, but not from her black eye, it was something else. A gnawing sensation at the base of her skull that made the shorter hairs there stand on end.
It only began to subside when another message from Agatha made her phone light up.

Agatha: It’s okay, I’m just glad you’re alright. Billy stayed home too and I assume Alice was with him since she was MIA as well
I can bring you some food if you want? Or more plasters at least? Do you have enough painkillers? Let me know what I can do to help

The squeezing on her chest eased as she read the words.
Part of her wanted Agatha to be there with her, but part of her knew that she needed some space. Just for a little while until her head was better.
She definitely wasn’t thinking about having sex with someone else anymore, but they had spent so much time together for the better part of three weeks and, now that Rio was no longer running from her feelings, she just needed some time to sit with them. To get used to them. To understand them.

Rio: You don’t have to do that, I wouldn’t be good company right now anyway. I’m just gonna eat, zone out for a bit and then go back to bed
Thank you again, I really appreciate you looking after me last night

Agatha: You don’t need to keep thanking me, I was happy to do it
Let me know if you change your mind about wanting company

Rio: I will

Rio smiled happily.
Her limbs felt like they belonged to her again and she could breathe properly. The pain in her head had been reduced to a dull ache and the growling of her stomach had gotten louder.
She ordered her food and popped another couple of pills to take the final edge off of her headache, content in the knowledge that she would talk to Agatha properly. And soon.

Chapter End Notes

Things are looking up, what could possibly go wrong?

Chapter 29: Agatha

Chapter Notes

Happy Valentine's Day gays!!!

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Agatha hadn’t seen Rio for a few days now.
It was to be expected since Rio really shouldn’t be doing anything until she was better.
Agatha still wanted to take her to the hospital to have her checked over, but she knew that was a losing battle. So she would settle for checking in a couple of times a day and reminding Rio that she could let her know if she needed anything.

Rio never did, of course, which was fine.
It definitely didn’t make Agatha feel like Rio was pushing her away.
It absolutely didn’t send her into a spiral, worrying that it was because they’d shared a bed.
And it certainly didn’t mean that she was replaying that night over and over in her mind trying to figure out what she did wrong.

Was it because she told Rio about Wanda and Billy and the family they could have been? Did Rio hear that and realise that it was too complicated for her?
Was it because Rio felt like she had been forced to spend the night?
Had Agatha pushed the boundaries of what they had too far?
Had she broken one of the unspoken rules of casual sex?

She knew, rationally, that she could just ask Rio, but the idea of it made her palms clammy. And Rio was still recovering so she couldn’t ask now anyway. She should wait until Rio shows signs of getting better.
She could do that. It wouldn’t be too long, just another couple of days and then they could talk.

“What do you think, Agatha?”
The sound of her name started to bring her out of her head and back to the dining table where she sat with Lilia and Jen, eating their Saturday night dinner.

Not being fully sure which of them had spoken, she looked between them as she asked, “What?”

Jen spoke up. “About dragons being the primary mode of delivering messages during the first world war.”
“That’s- I don’t- dragons weren’t- What?” Agatha stumbled over her reply as her brain was trying to catch up with whatever the fuck Jen was talking about. “They used pigeons.” She eventually managed to say, thoroughly confused.

Jen lifted her brows a fraction. “How do you know they used pigeons?”
“Rio told me.” The reply was quick, natural, like mentioning Rio in conversation was a normal thing for her to do.
Jen’s brows rose higher now. “You and Rio talk about pigeons?”
Lilia snorted softly. “I don’t think that's how they spend their time together.”

Agatha’s eyes shot to Lilia who was now wearing a smug smile as she sipped her wine.
Jen, looking between them, asked Agatha, “Wait, what? What does she mean?” Then to Lilia, “What do you mean?”
“She doesn’t mean anything.” Agatha said cooly, not taking her eyes off of Lilia who was still smiling at her. “She’s had too much wine.”

Lilia held the glass up. “This is my first glass, actually.” Then she turned to Jen. “The turtlenecks that our dear friend has been wearing lately are to hide the evidence that Rio leaves behind on her neck.”
“I never said that.” Agatha said quickly as she saw Jen’s eyes widen.
“You didn’t have to, dear. Your silence when I asked you spoke for you.”

Agatha groaned and dropped her head into her hands. “Jesus fucking Christ.”
“Oh, he can’t help you now.” She heard Jen say, sounding entirely too pleased. “Agatha Harkness, explain yourself.”
“There’s nothing to explain.” She said as she ran her hands through her hair and sat back up. “We’re two adults who are enjoying each other’s company, that’s it.” She put the last of her food into her mouth.

“So you’re dating?” Lilia asked but Agatha suspected she already knew the answer.
“No.”
“But you are sleeping together?” Jen asked.
“Yes.”
“And it’s just sex, nothing else?”
“Yes.”
“And that’s… you’re okay with that?”
Agatha blew out a breath. “Yes.”

Lilia caught the hesitation, of course she did. “No you’re not.” Both Jen and Agatha turned to look at her. “Your shoulders tensed, you hesitated and you averted your eyes. You know you can’t lie in my presence, Harkness. I don’t know why you continue to try.”
Agatha threw her hands up. “Well what do you want me to say then?”
“The truth.” Lilia said simply, like it was the easiest thing in the world.

Agatha sighed and pinched the bridge of her nose. How on earth did Lilia expect her to articulate the incredibly complicated feelings she had about Rio Vidal?
It wasn’t a simple thread that she could unwind, it was messy and tangled and sometimes too much to think about.

It was sweet and sour, comforting and painful all at the same time. It wasn’t as easy as just talking about it, saying it out loud.
There were feelings linked to this that Agatha would rather stay hidden, untouched, unable to hurt her, and Lilia was asking her to bring them to the surface as if it couldn’t rip her apart.

Neither Jen nor Lilia spoke whilst Agatha was contemplating this request, but she could feel their eyes boring into her.
She knocked back the rest of her wine before stating, “I need another drink.”
As she got up to retrieve the opened bottle of red from the kitchen counter, she heard Lilia say behind her, “You can’t avoid this forever.”
Agatha rolled her eyes. She could fucking try.

Jen and Lilia got up then, clearing the plates and refilling their own glasses, and getting a fresh bottle to take with them into the living room.
They sat in their usual arrangement and Agatha could feel their eyes on her again as she stared into the burgundy liquid in her glass.
She tried not to think about it, tried to block them out, but she couldn’t.

She sighed. “Are you both just going to stare at me for the rest of the night?” She didn’t look up from her glass.
“Until you tell us what’s going on in that head of yours, yes.” Lilia responded gently.
Agatha swirled the wine in her glass the way Rio had taught her. Or she tried to at least. It came very close to spilling over the edge of the glass, so she stopped.

Neither Jen nor Lilia had looked away from her yet so she sighed again. More frustrated this time. “Fucking hell, fine!”
She looked up then, first to Jen sitting on her left, then to Lilia sitting across from her.
Both waiting patiently, both with neutral expressions.

“I like her, okay? I like her a lot. And it kills me to walk away from her, or to see her walking away from me every night. Sometimes I get her to stay a little bit longer by sitting by the window with her and smoking. I’ve driven her home a couple of times just to extend the time we have.
So the truth is, no, no I’m not okay with it. Are you happy now?”
She went back to staring into her glass before taking a sip and keeping her gaze down.

Out of the corner of her eye she saw Jen shift slightly on the sofa.
“We’re happy you told us, we’re not happy that you’re hurting, Agatha.”
“Have you told Rio how you feel?” Lilia added.
Agatha scoffed. “That’s not what she wants.”
“How do you know?” Jen asked softly.

Agatha took another small sip of her wine and looked up again, not really looking at either of them but in between them. “Sometimes it feels like she wants to stay, I can almost see the decision turning around in her head. But then she leaves anyway. Sometimes I make her leave because hearing her say that she doesn’t want to stay would be worse than just watching her walk away. But it’s all painful either way.”

Lilia took a drink from her own glass and nodded slowly. “What if you asked her to stay next time you noticed her questioning if she should? It sounds like she wants to but is waiting for your permission, you need to communicate.”
Agatha swallowed. “She stayed the other night.” She said quietly, as if saying it too loudly would make it untrue.

Agatha noticed Jen moving next to her and she dragged her gaze over to her.
Her eyes were wide and her arms were spread questioningly. “Well there you go then. What’s the problem?”
“It was different.”
Lilia jumped in. “Different how?”

Agatha took a deep, steadying, breath. “We didn’t have sex that night. We were supposed to but when she turned up she had a black eye. Turns out she’d been defending Billy from a gang of drug dealers.” She breathed out a humourless laugh. “I tried to take her to the hospital but she wouldn’t let me, so I cleaned the cut on her face and put some plasters on it. We talked a little bit, but I just wanted to make sure she was alright. So I asked her to stay so that I could keep an eye on her through the night. She resisted at first but then she agreed and we went to bed together.” She gave a small smile that didn’t reach her eyes.

Lilia leaned forwards slightly, resting her forearms on her thighs. “What happened then?”
Agatha ran her hand through her hair, remembering the panic she felt when she woke up alone. “She left before I woke up. She said she didn’t want me to feel like I had to spend my day looking after her. I’d already started planning how I was gonna make it work around lectures. But she didn’t know that.”

Lilia hummed. “She didn’t want to be a burden and she probably wasn't sure how to approach the day since that was the first time you’d spent the night together in… How long has this been going on?”
“Seventeen days.”
“Seven- wow, okay. That was the first time you’d spent the night together in seventeen days. It was new territory. She was probably confused.”

Agatha leant back into the couch, putting her wine glass down and decidedly not centering it on the coaster. “She wouldn’t have been a burden, I told her that.”
Jen angled herself more towards her. “Just give her time, but you do need to talk to her about this. You need to be clear about what you want so that you can see if you’re on the same page. Otherwise you’re both gonna be stuck in this limbo of not knowing.”

Agatha knew they were right. She knew that both she and Rio needed to communicate better. But that didn’t make it feel any less daunting. It didn’t mean that the nausea that sat in her stomach disappeared.
The very real possibility that Rio could reject her was still there, hanging over her, whispering in her ear. Reminding her that she was too much, that she was unloveable. That she didn’t deserve happiness.

Lilia must have sensed her unease because she said, “Something being scary doesn’t mean that it’s inherently bad. It’s good to be scared sometimes. It’s natural, human, normal.”
“And you can’t live in this uncertainty forever,” Jen picked up. “You need to know either way. But the only way to do that is to actually talk to her.”
Agatha picked her glass back up and took a big gulp. “Yeah, yeah, I know.” She looked between Jen and Lilia. “I know.” She repeated, firmer, more solid. Convincing herself as well as her friends.

__________

Agatha told herself that when Rio was better, they would talk.
She would wait for Rio to let her know, and then she would be ready. She’d be able to do this and get an answer. And whichever answer Rio gave, it would be okay.
The world wouldn’t stop spinning, her life wouldn’t end, her mother wouldn’t be right.
She would be okay.

Sunday morning she woke with a sinking feeling in her chest. But for once it wasn’t about Rio, it was about Billy.
Had he told Wanda about the altercation the other night?
Agatha had focused her concern on Rio since she was the injured one in front of her and had reassured her that Billy was fine. But now that she’d had a few days to process what Rio had told her, she knew that she had to tell Wanda.

She would rather do literally anything else than willingly speak to that woman, but she had said to her not too long ago that if there was something she needed to know about Billy, she would tell her. And this definitely counted as something she needed to know.

Billy wouldn’t be happy about it, he’d probably be mad at her, but she couldn’t have this information and not let Wanda know.
She told herself that she could make it right with Billy as she tapped out a message to Wanda.

Agatha: Not sure if Billy has told you but there was an issue the other night regarding him buying weed. He’s fine but you should talk to him.

Wanda replied immediately.

Wanda: No he hasn’t told me. What happened?

Agatha was halfway through typing her reply when her phone rang, Wanda’s name covering her screen.
Absolutely not.
She rejected the call and another text followed before she could hit send.

Wanda: Pick up the phone, this is important!

She hit send on her already typed message.

Agatha: Like I said, you should talk to him. I’ve done my part by letting you know, it’s up to you to have a conversation with him.

Her phone rang again, and she rejected it again.

Wanda: Why are you being so difficult?

She didn’t reply and rejected Wanda’s third attempt at calling her.
She’d done what she needed to do, now Wanda needed to do her job as his mother.

On Sunday night, she texted Rio. Just checking in.

Agatha: How are you feeling? Do you need anything?

The reply came almost instantly.

Rio: I’m feeling better. I can almost make it through the entire day without getting a splitting headache! Though band practice this afternoon probably didn’t help…

Agatha: Yeah, maybe you shouldn’t have done that. Are the headaches less painful at least? How's the cut healing?

She watched the three dots in the bubble appear at the bottom left corner of the screen. She watched them move as Rio was typing. Then she watched them stop and disappear. They picked back up again briefly before stopping again.
She stared at the screen for a moment before her phone lighting up with an incoming call made her jump.
It was Rio.

They didn’t call each other.
They’d never had a phone conversation in the entire time they’d known each other.
They’d had no reason to.

She gingerly accepted the call as if pressing the accept button too hard would alert Rio to her eagerness, and pressed her phone to her ear.
“Hi.” She said, a little more apprehension evident in her voice than she would have liked.
“Hey, sorry. The screen was making my eyes hurt. I hope calling you is okay?”
She could hear the uncertainty in Rio’s voice. The fear that she’d overstepped a boundary.
The knowledge that Rio was just as nervous as she was helped to ease the tightness in her chest.

“Yeah, no. That’s… It’s okay. We don’t have to talk if your head hurts, you can just get some rest.”
“No, I want to talk. I can just do it with my eyes closed this way.”
Agatha chuckled softly. “That sounds like a good idea. I might do the same thing.”
“Mhmm, you should. It’s very relaxing.”
Agatha leaned her head back against her sofa and let her eyes drift closed. “How was band practice?”
Rio was right, it was more relaxing.

She heard shuffling down the line before Rio responded. “Fucking loud.” Rio laughed. “I swear they turned all the amps up to full today.”
“Isn’t that just the done thing with bands these days? All noise and no talent?”
“I’ll tell them you said that.”
“Hmm, you do that. I’d love to see what they do.”

A beat of silence passed before Rio spoke again.
“Your eyes are closed aren’t they?”
Agatha smiled. “How did you know?”
“Your voice. It’s softer, lighter.”
“Maybe talking to you makes me feel at ease.”

Agatha only processed the words once they’d left her mouth, when there was no hope of getting them back.
She had said them out loud to Rio without thinking, without worrying.
She’d said them as a reflex almost.

Her breath caught and her eyes flew open as fear ran through her.
Fear of Rio’s reaction.
Fear of rejection.

There was silence from Rio.
She tried to listen to Rio’s breathing, but that wasn’t there either.
She pulled the phone away from her ear, checking that Rio hadn’t hung up. The line was still connected.
Rio was just silent.

Agatha’s heart started to pound, loud and insistent.
Her blood started to cool as she repeated the words in her head, trying to think of a way she could rephrase it. Trying to find a way she could explain it.
Just as her spiral had reached its peak, Rio finally spoke.

“Talking to you makes me feel like that too.”
It took Agatha’s brain a second to process what Rio had said, to unjumble the words so that they were understandable.
“I think that’s why I still went to you that night. I didn’t want sex, I just wanted you.”

Was this really happening?
Agatha pinched herself just to make sure. Definitely happening.
Okay, that’s fine. She can do this. She can have this conversation, now, over the phone.
It was a little earlier than she had thought it would be but that was okay. It remained the same conversation regardless of when or how it happened.
They were going to do it either way.

“Agatha?”
Rio’s voice drifted into her ear and startled her out of her thoughts.
“Yeah?” She breathed out, voice wavering slightly.
“Did you hear what I said?”
Agatha swallowed. “Yeah. Yeah I did. I just, umm. I just wasn’t expecting you to say that.”
She heard Rio breathe out. “Neither was I, honestly.”

They stayed silent for a moment after that. It gave Agatha some time to gather her thoughts, to be able to form a coherent sentence.
If they truly were doing this then she needed to be able to talk properly, articulate herself well, fully take in what Rio said and not only see the possible negatives.

She took a deep breath in through her nose and exhaled through her mouth, trying to expel the anxiety from her body.
“Why did you leave?” Her voice was quieter than she expected it to be.
Rio took a second before answering. “I guess I panicked. It’s been a long time since I woke up next to someone that I… That I wanted to wake up next to. I needed some time to figure out what that meant. My head was spinning and not just because I got my shit rocked.” Rio laughed gently and Agatha recognised the attempt to add humour to lighten the conversation a little bit.

She smiled along with Rio’s laughter, letting it ground her. “And have you had enough time?” Her voice sounded unbelievably steady considering the way her heart was still battering her rib cage.
“I think so but I’m not really sure how to do this.”
Rio sounded so vulnerable and unguarded. Her voice was soft but it was clear, she wasn’t trying to hide her words or say them quietly so that Agatha might not hear them. She was just being honest.

If Agatha was being honest, then she didn’t know how to do this either.
She had been engaged but still had no idea how to actually start a relationship, if that’s even what this was going to become.
“You and me both.”
“Do you need time?”

Agatha ran her hand through her hair and then let it settle on her chest. Her heart was still beating a little fast, but it had slowed significantly.
“I think we need to have this conversation face to face.”
Rio didn’t respond.

“Rio?”
“Oh shit, sorry. I nodded and forgot that you couldn’t see me. Yeah I agree.”
Agatha breathed out a steady breath. “Let me know when your head’s better and we can go from there?”
“Yeah, sounds like a plan. I might come do some work in your office tomorrow, if that’s okay?”
“Of course, but don’t push yourself if you’re not feeling up to it.”
“I just want to see you.”

Agatha’s breath caught in her throat.
The vulnerability was still there in Rio’s voice, the honesty.
“So do I.”
“Good. I mean- No I-” Rio made a frustrated noise and Agatha found herself smiling at it. “Good. I meant good. I’ll see you tomorrow. Goodnight, Agatha.”
“Goodnight Rio.”

Agatha heard a thud followed by a muffled, “Good?” in a mocking voice followed by some Spanish that she didn’t understand. Except “¡Estúpida!” She managed to work that one out.
She listened to Rio berate herself in Spanish for a moment, obviously unaware that she hadn't hung up, with a growing grin before giving Rio some grace and hanging up herself.

__________

Agatha gave her Monday morning lecture to her first years with a strange feeling of calmness.
She was yet to talk to Rio properly, but the small amount that they’d talked last night had given her hope.
Rio had wanted to wake up next to her.
She didn’t leave because she hadn’t wanted to be there, she’d left because she did.

To anyone else, that was probably confusing. But Agatha understood.
She understood the panic, she understood wanting to be sure, she understood using distance as a tool.
If the roles had been reversed she probably would have done the same thing.

She arrived at her office after the lecture was done and part of her had been expecting to see Rio waiting for her, but she wasn’t there.
She pushed down the disappointment and the twinge of sadness that sat in her chest and let herself in.
She set her bag down on her desk and pulled her laptop out, sitting in the chair opposite the one Rio favoured.

A few more minutes passed without Rio arriving and Agatha began nervously checking her watch.
Maybe Rio had changed her mind.
Maybe she wasn’t feeling up to it.
Surely she would have let her know though.

There was a message from Rio.

Rio: I’m running a bit late, I didn’t want to leave the warmth of my bed and pushed it too close. I’m on my way with coffee though!

Agatha: That’s okay! You don’t need to knock, you can just come straight in

She’d barely opened it an inch when Wanda barrelled past her and into the room, before rounding on her.
“Why the fuck was your door locked? And why the fuck didn’t you tell me about Billy earlier? He could have been seriously hurt, Agatha!”
Agatha blinked. “Good morning to you too, Wanda.”
Wanda crossed her arms. “It’s past twelve.”

She checked her watch in disbelief and sure enough, Wanda was correct.
It hadn’t felt like time had moved that much when she was wrapped up in Rio, she could have happily stayed there for the rest of the day.
Her gaze drifted past Wanda towards Rio subconsciously and Wanda followed her line of sight.

Agatha forced herself to look away from Rio and back to Wanda. The only evidence of what they’d been doing for the past hour was her creased shirt, but that wasn’t anything that Wanda could run with.

Rio swallowed and darted her eyes back to Agatha briefly. “Healing well, thanks.”

Wanda nodded and brought her attention back to Agatha. “We’ll talk about this later.”

Wanda clenched her jaw and breathed out heavily through her nose but didn’t say anything else before she left.

Rio sighed. “I may have omitted a couple of things. I got kicked in the shin and thrown into the wall.”

“Agatha, it’s not that big-”

It just ached for a couple of days but it’s fine now.” She must have noticed the way Agatha was clenching her jaw because she followed it up with a soft, “I promise.” Before she brought Agatha’s knuckles to her lips and pressed a kiss to them.

Agatha swallowed. “I told you. I was a clumsy child, always falling over and walking into things. I fell down the stairs more times than I can count. I just got good at it.”

Agatha smiled, but it wasn’t full. Rio didn’t know the extent of her ‘clumsiness’ as a child and that left an uneasy feeling in her stomach.

__________

Agatha continued to wait for Rio to let her know that she was ready to talk.
Rio helped her with her office hours again and they managed to not touch each other the whole time, even when there was a fifteen minute gap between students.
Agatha was proud of herself for staying strong.

Rio went home when the office hours were done and Agatha continued her work day.
As the day progressed she could feel her body starting to ache. But not in the same way it did after spending the night with Rio. No, this was different.
This felt wrong.

When she was moving into her last lecture of the day she felt a scratchy feeling at the back of her throat and the ache in her muscles had started to fully set in.
Walking around the room whilst she was teaching felt difficult, and the more talking she did, the worse her throat got.
And as the lecture was drawing to an end, she sneezed.
Nothing to worry about as a stand alone event, but when she sneezed a second, third and fourth time in a row, that was cause for concern.

She couldn’t get sick now, she’d made it through the whole of November, December and January without so much as a sniffle and now her immune system was betraying her.
Absolutely ridiculous.

As she drove home she could feel her nose starting to get blocked.
The egregious amount of times she’d sneezed in the last two hours certainly weren’t helping that fact.
She was annoyed.
She had a cold and she was annoyed about it.

She got in the shower, turning up the heat in the hopes that the steam would help clear her sinuses. It didn’t, but it did sooth her sore muscles, so silver linings.
She grumbled her way down to the kitchen and as she searched through her cupboards for some cold and flu tablets that she knew she had squirrelled away somewhere.

She took the tablets, annoyed at having to swallow them one at a time instead of both at once due to her now incredibly sore throat.
She made herself a honey and lemon tea to take back upstairs with her and bundled herself in her fluffy dressing gown before she crawled into her bed with a book.

She was wallowing in self-pity over how run down she felt, not really taking in the words she was reading, when her phone buzzed on her bedside table.
She groaned, hoping it was an email she could ignore. But when she picked it up, she smiled.

Rio: Made it the whole day with no headaches, the bruise and swelling have gone down and I don’t need the band-aids anymore. There’s no band practice tomorrow so how’s tomorrow eve for our talk?

Rio was ready to talk and so was she, but if she felt this bad now then how bad would she feel after a full day of work tomorrow?
She didn’t want to have to push their talk back, but she needed to be in full health. She needed to be able to think clearly.

Agatha: I’m really glad to hear that, but I don’t know if I’ll be able to do tomorrow evening. I’ve come down with a cold and might not be up to it after a full day. I also don’t want to get you sick as well so maybe you shouldn’t come in tomorrow

Rio: Are you okay? We can take a rain check. Let me know if you need anything!

Agatha: I’m fine, annoyed about it, but fine. Hopefully it’ll be a 24 hour thing… It better be a 24 hour thing

Rio: I don’t think, I know! Seriously though, rest up and let me know about tomorrow. No pressure if you’re not feeling up to it

She tried to open her eyes and even doing that hurt.
She already knew that she felt worse today than she had yesterday and that didn’t bode well for her work day.

She got out of bed with a groan and made it to her bathroom.
She had to brace herself against the edge of the sink when she was washing her face so that she didn’t collapse. And when it came to brushing her teeth she actually had to sit on the floor because her legs felt so weak.

The common cold could go fuck itself as far as she was concerned.

She managed to prop herself up long enough to clean the toothpaste out of her mouth and shuffled back into her bedroom using the wall for support.
She sat on the edge of her bed, needing a rest after doing barely anything.
This didn’t feel like a twenty four hour thing.

When her legs felt like they wouldn’t give out underneath her she stood up again and got dressed.
When she made it downstairs – slowly, having to put both feet on each stair before she could take the next one – she made herself another honey and lemon tea, making enough so that she could put the rest into a thermos to take to work with her, and took some more tablets.

She survived the drive to campus, but she almost definitely shouldn’t have driven. Everything felt like it was moving in slow motion around her and she took some risky gaps that she wouldn’t have even taken if she was at full health.

By the time she was giving her first lecture, the tablets had started to kick in and she felt a little bit better. She wasn’t walking around as she was teaching, but she was able to get through it by only stopping to blow her nose three times.
That was as much of a win as she was going to get.

Rio sat back down. “I’m right here. As long as you want me to be.”
Agatha smiled, wide and real, and continued to eat her soup as Rio put a nature documentary on for background noise.

Rio stayed for a few more hours, making commentary on the documentary they were watching.
When Agatha had finished eating, Rio took the tray into the kitchen and washed the bowl and spoon before decanting the remaining soup into a tupperware container which she put in the fridge, and then washed the remaining pots.

Rio had told her what was in it, but Agatha was sure that there was actual magic in the soup because she already felt better.
The clogginess in her sinuses was starting to clear and the pressure behind her eyes lessened.
Her head felt less foggy and her joints weren’t complaining nearly as much as they had been at the start of the day.

Not because it was valentines day, but because the day just so happened to be free. The date and significance assigned to it were irrelevant.
Agatha was never one to pay much attention to Valentine’s Day. She found it tacky, stupid, just a way for Hallmark to make extra money.
Her first year with Wanda, it hadn’t even crossed her mind. It was only when Wanda came to her office with a card and some flowers that she’d even registered what day it was.

Wanda was very into the concept of Valentine's Day so Agatha forced herself to care about it because it made Wanda happy.
She’d buy the card, the flowers, the gift.
She’d go out for the meal at the restaurant that had a ‘special offer’ that ended up being more expensive than it would have been if they ordered normally.
But she’d only done it for Wanda, she could have happily lived without it.

Not quite a date, but something to ease them into it. No expectations, no declarations, just time with each other.
